case_information: A woman in her early 70s presented with a solitary, asymptomatic lump on her scalp. The lesion was present since birth but showed some growth following minor local trauma a couple of months prior to evaluation. No local inflammation, purulent discharge, or systemic symptoms were reported. Medical history included a benign breast nodule resection in teenage years. Family history notable for father who died of metastatic cutaneous melanoma at 83 years old.
physical_examination: Physical findings revealed an ill-defined, infiltrated plaque with a normochromic, exophytic nodule on the scalp vertex measuring 4.2 × 3.8 cm. The lesion had a waxy surface with irregular transverse furrows and overlying alopecia. Dermoscopic evaluation showed a homogeneous yellow hue with no visible vascular or pigmented structures and absence of follicular ostia. The lesion was firm and mildly tender to touch, seemed adherent to the underlying bone. No palpable lymph nodes were detected.
diagnostic_tests: - Imaging Studies:    Brain MRI Title: Paramedian sagittal gadolinium-enhanced T1-weighted brain MRI    Description: Demonstrated a nonenhancing tumor with sharp margins in the subcutaneous tissue of the scalp with no underlying bone or intracranial involvement  - Histopathology:    Punch biopsy findings:    - Infiltration by monomorphic cells with ovoid nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm amid fibrous stroma in lower dermis    - Cells without discernible cell membranes, forming whorls and strands around collagen bundles    - No adnexal structures overlying the lesion, epidermis spared      - Immunohistochemistry:    - Strongly positive: vimentin and epithelial membrane antigen (EMA)    - Focally positive: progesterone receptor    - Ki-67: estimated 1% positivity    - Negative: cytokeratins AE1/AE3, S100, CD45, CD68, factor XIII, actin, glial fibrillary acidic protein, and octamer-binding transcription factor 4
final_diagnosis: Cutaneous meningeal heterotopia (CMH)
reason: The case involves a skin lesion on the scalp with specific histopathological findings and dermoscopic evaluation, indicating a dermatological condition.

case_information: A previously healthy man in his 30s presented with spontaneous bruising, epistaxis, and haematuria. After starting treatment, the patient developed pyrexia after 12 days. Two days later, he developed tender black spots on the scrotum that progressed to painful ulcers over 8 days. As scrotal ulceration progressed, they enlarged and became necrotic with a black eschar. The development and progression of scrotal ulceration coincided with recovery in neutrophil count from 0.3 × 109/L to 1.2 × 109/L and persistent pyrexia.
physical_examination: Tender black spots on the scrotum were observed, which progressed to painful ulcers. The ulcers enlarged and became necrotic with a black eschar.
diagnostic_tests: - Laboratory Tests: Peripheral blood cultures and skin swabs from the lesions did not identify bacterial or viral infection. Neutrophil count increased from 0.3 × 109/L to 1.2 × 109/L.- Imaging Studies: Scrotal ultrasonography showed a subcutaneous hypervascular lesion with no abscess.- Pathology: Histopathology on a skin biopsy showed intense inflammation, necrosis, and mature neutrophils with no evidence of leukemic infiltration. Tissue culture findings for bacteria and mycobacteria were negative.Image Title: Clinical photograph of scrotum and penisImage Description: Shows ulceration and necrosis of penile and scrotal skin with surrounding inflammation.Image Title: Scrotal biopsy histopathologic specimenImage Description: Hematoxylin-eosin stained specimen (original magnification ×20) showing intense inflammation, necrosis, and mature neutrophils.
final_diagnosis: Scrotal ulceration secondary to induction chemotherapy with ATRA
option_b: Scrotal ulceration secondary to induction chemotherapy with ATRA
reason: The case presents with symptoms indicative of a possible infectious process, including necrotic ulcers and pyrexia, despite negative cultures, suggesting a complex infectious or inflammatory condition.

case_information: A female patient in her early 50s presented with multiple (approximately 10) bluish, partially keratotic papules and nodules on the lower legs. The lesions had been growing very slowly in number and size since age 24 and had been bleeding occasionally after trauma. The patient used a wheelchair due to right-sided hemiparesis and hemianopsia caused by an intracranial hemorrhage. At age 4, she had recurrent seizures. She had lipolymphedema of the lower legs attributed to functional venous insufficiency with insufficient venous pump activity, and had been wearing compression stockings for years. Family history revealed similar conditions in the patient's father and aunt, with the father having died of an intracranial hemorrhage in his early 70s.
physical_examination: Multiple bluish, partially keratotic papules and nodules on the lower legs. Lipolymphedema of the lower legs was present. Right-sided hemiparesis and hemianopsia were noted.
diagnostic_tests:
- Sonography: Demonstrated intradermal slow-flow vascular malformations with a maximum diameter of 1.2 cm.

- Histopathology:
  Image Description: Biopsy revealed a well-circumscribed lesion with hyperkeratosis and acanthosis of the epidermis overlying a conglomerate of dilated venous-like malformations with continuous smooth muscle in the upper dermis, partly showing thrombosis.

- Genetic Testing:
  Result: Detection of a heterozygous pathogenic KRIT1 variant.
final_diagnosis: Familial cerebral cavernous malformations
reason: The case presents with skin lesions (bluish, keratotic papules and nodules) and vascular malformations, which are typically evaluated and treated by dermatologists.

case_information: A female patient in her late 20s presented with a 2-year history of multiple, slowly growing, infiltrated erythematous-violaceous patches and plaques, with occasional slight pain extending from her left upper arm to the left side of her chest. No triggers such as local infection, insect bite, or trauma occurred before lesion appearance. She denied fever, weight loss, or fatigue.
physical_examination: Multiple firm, nonscaly, purple erythematous patches and plaques with irregular borders on her left axilla, medial upper arm, and lateral thoracic region. No extracutaneous involvement was observed.
diagnostic_tests: - Histopathological examination:    - Thin-walled, irregularly branched blood vessels dispersed between thickened collagen bundles    - Endothelial cells were plump but displayed no significant cytologic atypia      - Immunohistochemistry results:    - Positive for: CD31, CD34, Ki-67 (<1%)    - Negative for: podoplanin (D2-40), human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8)      - Images:    Image A Title: Clinical presentation    Image A Description: Multiple nonscaly, erythematous-violaceous patches and plaques with irregular borders on the patient's left axilla, medial upper arm, and lateral thoracic region        Image B Title: Histopathological examination (hematoxylin-eosin)    Image B Description: Irregularly branched, thin-walled blood vessels dissecting through collagen bundles within the superficial to mid dermis        Image C Title: Detailed histopathology (hematoxylin-eosin)    Image C Description: Irregularly branched, thin-walled blood vessels with plump endothelial cells dispersed between thickened collagen bundles without signs of atypia        Image D Title: Immunohistochemistry    Image D Description: Endothelial cells positive for cluster of differentiation (CD) 31
final_diagnosis: Microvenular hemangioma (MVH)
reason: The case presents with skin lesions and histopathological findings indicative of a dermatological condition, making Dermatology the appropriate department.

case_information: A teenage girl presented with several months of sinus pressure and facial swelling, and several weeks of external deviation of her nasal septum. No significant past medical history was mentioned.
physical_examination: On examination, a left nasal mass was noted. Mild left-sided proptosis was present.
diagnostic_tests: - Imaging Studies:    CT scan (without and with contrast):    - Image Title: Computed tomographic scans of a heterogeneous mass in the left maxillary sinus    - Image Description: Shows a heterogeneous mass with solid and cystic components completely opacifying the left maxillary sinus. Mass eroded the orbital floor, medial and posterior maxillary walls, and anterior ethmoid air cells. No extension beyond cribriform plate. Displacement of inferior rectus without muscle invasion. Left maxillary alveolar ridge and several molar roots involved. Bony changes showed remodeling and thinning.    - Biopsy Results:    - Tissue analysis showed spindle cell process in a patternless arrangement with significant multinucleated giant cells    - Rare mitotic activity    - No cytologic atypia    - Largest portion measured 7.0 × 4.0 × 2.0 cm

option_d: Left maxillary giant cell reparative granuloma (GCRG)

case_information: A 12-year-old female presented with asymptomatic vulvar edema of 1 month's duration that was previously treated with topical antifungals and corticosteroids with no improvement. She did not report recent travel or sexual relationships. Medical history included growth delay, several months of constipation treated with laxatives, and hemorrhoids.
physical_examination: Examination revealed swelling, erythema, and palpable induration on the labia minora and majora of the vulva. No lymphadenopathy was palpated in the inguinal region.
diagnostic_tests: - Laboratory tests: Slight increase in erythrocyte sedimentation rate, normal angiotensin-converting enzyme levels, negative interferon γ release assay. Fecal calprotectin was 297 μg/g (normal <50 μg/g). Negative stool culture and parasite studies.- Imaging studies:  - Chest radiography: Normal  - Intestinal and pelvic MRI: Normal  - Endoscopic study: Revealed ulcers in duodenal bulb, rectum, sigmoid colon, terminal ileum, and cecum. Erythematous and edematous mucosa with aphthous ulcers in sigmoid and rectal region.- Pathology:  - 4mm punch biopsy from right labia majora showed:    Image Description: Intact epidermis with nodular dermatitis composed of non-necrotizing granulomas in superficial and deep dermis  - Additional histological findings: Aggregated nodules of epithelioid histiocytes without necrosis, poorly compact granulomas with ill-defined borders, associated lymphocytic and eosinophilic infiltrate  - Gastric and intestinal endoscopic biopsies: Granulomas in lamina propria not linked to active crypt injury
final_diagnosis: Metastatic Crohn disease
reason: The case involves a 12-year-old female with vulvar edema and granulomatous changes, which falls under the purview of gynecological issues, particularly in pediatric patients.

case_information: An 11-year-old boy presented with progressive unilateral skin hardening on his right thigh and buttock for 7 years. Recently, the motion of his right limb joint was slightly limited. He was born to healthy parents and did not have any medical disease.
physical_examination: There was an ill-defined, stony-hard plaque involving his right thigh above the patella extending to his right buttocks with loss of skin elasticity. The affected skin was associated with mild hypertrichosis and hyperpigmentation.
diagnostic_tests: - Laboratory tests: Normal results for routine blood tests, autoantibodies, immunoglobulins, C-reactive protein, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate.- Imaging studies:  Image Title: MRI of right thigh  Image Description: Demonstrated slight thickening of subcutaneous tissue and T2 signal abnormality- Pathological examination:  - Histopathological findings: Normal epidermis and mild pigmentation along the basal layer with subtle increase in density of fibroblasts extending to the subcutis and forming adipocyte entrapment but no evidence of inflammation. Dense reticular dermis extended below well-preserved appendages  - Immunohistochemical staining: Increased expression of CD34 in the reticular dermis  - Alcian blue staining: Negative
final_diagnosis: Segmental stiff skin syndrome (SSS)
reason: The case presents with progressive unilateral skin hardening and associated skin changes, which are primarily dermatological issues. The histopathological findings and imaging also support a dermatological condition.

case_information: A woman in her 20s presented with a large erythematous indurated plaque involving the face and neck that had been first noted at age 2 years. The plaque progressively increased in size, and similar plaques developed over the back, right dorsal surface of the hand, suprapubic area, and right thigh over the last 4 years. Scarring developed in the plaques over the face and hand during the course of the disease and led to flexion contracture of the hand with limitation of movement. There were no constitutional symptoms. There was no history of trauma preceding these lesions. She had received multiple previous treatments without significant improvement.
physical_examination: Well-defined erythematous plaque of 7 × 8 cm over the suprapubic area. Additional plaques present on face, neck, back, right dorsal surface of hand, and right thigh. Flexion contracture of the hand with limited movement noted.
diagnostic_tests:
- Laboratory Tests:
  * Routine hematological and biochemical investigations were normal
  * Mantoux test showed an induration of 2 × 1 mm at 48 hours

- Imaging Studies:
  * Chest radiography was normal

- Pathological Studies:
  * Direct potassium hydroxide preparation: Multiple budding yeast cells and arthrospores observed
  * Skin biopsy: Granulomatous infiltrate with giant cells, lymphocytes, histiocytes, neutrophils, and eosinophils. Hyaline hyphae branching at acute angles with multiple spores and budding yeasts, positive for silver methenamine and periodic acid–Schiff stains
  * Culture: Grew Trichosporon species, identified as Trichosporon mycotoxinivorans through PCR analysis and DNA sequencing

- Images:
  * Figure 1A Title: Erythematous Crusted Plaque Over Suprapubic Area
  * Figure 2A Title: Potassium hydroxide preparation showing fungal elements
  * Figure 2B Title: Periodic acid–Schiff staining showing inflammatory infiltrate and fungal elements
  * Figure 2C Title: Culture plate showing Trichosporon colonies
final_diagnosis: Primary cutaneous trichosporonosis caused by Trichosporon mycotoxinivorans
option_b: Deep cutaneous mycosis due to Trichosporon mycotoxinivorans
option_c: Primary cutaneous trichosporonosis caused by Trichosporon mycotoxinivorans
reason: The case presents with skin lesions, specifically erythematous plaques and fungal elements, which are within the scope of dermatological conditions.

case_information: A man in his 20s presented with thickening and swelling of hands after immersion in water, accompanied by burning pruritus for 3 years. The lesions occurred as symmetrical white and transparent papules, white keratosis, excessive wrinkling on the dorsum of hands after water immersion and worsened in summer, and remitted in winter. He was treated with topical tretinoin ointment intermittently at a local clinic with little improvement. The lesions gradually aggravated, and the affected area dispersed to wrists and elbows during past 1.5 years. He attributed these changes to frequent hand washing during the COVID-19 epidemic. No family history of similar skin problems and no history of hyperhidrosis, cystic fibrosis, atopy, or trauma to the hands.
physical_examination: After immersing both hands in water for 10 mins, there were symmetrical white papules, white hyperkeratosis spots, and excessive wrinkling on the thenar eminence, wrist flexure of both hands, and dorsum of fingers and hands.
diagnostic_tests: - Skin Biopsy:  Histopathologic examination revealed remarkable compact orthohyperkeratosis in the epidermis, dilatation of intraepidermal eccrine ducts, and hyperplasia of the eccrine sweat glands.  - Images:    Image Title: Clinical presentation after water immersion    Image Description: A and B - Symmetrical white papules, white hyperkeratosis spots, and excessive wrinkling on hands after water immersion        Image Title: Histopathologic features    Image Description: C and D - Hyperkeratosis, dilated eccrine ducts in the epidermis and dermis, and hyperplasia of the eccrine sweat gland (hematoxylin-eosin staining)
final_diagnosis: Aquagenic syringeal acrokeratoderma (ASA)
reason: The case presents with skin lesions and symptoms related to the skin, specifically involving hyperkeratosis and eccrine sweat glands, which are best addressed by a dermatologist.

case_information: A woman in her late teens with a 1-year history of viral cardiomyopathy presented with decompensated heart failure. Over 5 days of initial treatment, she improved clinically and passed 7 liters of urine. On hospital days 6 and 7, she became increasingly somnolent with urinary incontinence, constipation, and decreased gait stability. Initially, obstructive sleep apnea was considered but she failed to improve with bilevel positive pressure ventilation and was transferred for further management.
physical_examination: Patient appeared euvolemic and had no focal neurologic deficits on examination but was somnolent (Richmond Agitation-Sedation Scale, −3). Initial examination was notable for bibasilar crackles on lung auscultation and lower-extremity edema.
diagnostic_tests: - Cardiac Function:  - Echocardiogram showed left ventricular ejection fraction of 20% to 25%  - ECG Findings:  Image 1 Title: The First Electrocardiogram  Image 1 Description: Shows normal sinus rhythm at 87 beats per minute, normal axis, QT interval of 320 milliseconds (corrected QT interval 362 milliseconds), normal PR interval, high QRS voltage, nonspecific intraventricular conduction delay, 2- to 3-mm ST elevations in the anterior septal leads, and scooping ST depressions in the inferolateral leads    Image 2 Title: The Second Electrocardiogram  Image 2 Description: Shows sinus tachycardia at 123 beats per minute, normal axis, QT interval of 316 milliseconds (corrected QT interval 406 milliseconds), normal PR interval, normal QRS voltage, nonspecific intraventricular conduction delay, and resolution of previously seen ST elevations and depressions  - Laboratory Tests:  - Arterial blood gas: pH 7.34, Pco2 58 mm Hg, Po2 65 mm Hg, oxygen saturation 94%, calculated bicarbonate 31 mEq/L  - Ionized calcium: 11.16 mg/dL  - Whole blood calcium: >26 mg/dL  - Creatinine: 1.6 mg/dL  - Intact parathyroid hormone: 11 pg/mL (low; normal 16-60 pg/mL)  - Thyroid findings: normal  - 25-hydroxyvitamin D: 8 ng/mL (low)
final_diagnosis: Iatrogenic hypercalcemia
option_d: Severe hypercalcemia due to calcium supplementation
reason: The patient presents with symptoms and lab findings suggestive of hypercalcemia and possible parathyroid dysfunction, which are within the scope of endocrinology.

case_information: A 40-year-old man from eastern India presented with a nonhealing ulcer on the tongue present for the last 4 months. The lesion started as a small painless mass on the right lateral aspect of the tongue, which gradually grew and subsequently ulcerated. It caused mild difficulty in eating. No history of trauma or tongue bite preceding the lesion. Patient denied consuming tobacco or alcohol regularly. Medical history includes well-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus for 2 years with oral hypoglycemic agents. No systemic complaints. No history of high-risk behavior for HIV.
physical_examination: Single well-defined ulcer measuring 2 × 2 cm on the right lateral aspect of tongue with a clean base and irregular and elevated heaped-up margins. No underlying induration, friability, or bleeding on manipulation. Rest of the oral cavity was normal.
diagnostic_tests: - Histopathological examination (3-mm punch biopsy from edge of ulcer):  - Dense diffuse infiltrate of lymphocytes, histiocytes, epithelioid cells, giant cells, plasma cells, eosinophils, and neutrophils  - Many histiocytes and giant cells contained intracellular yeasts with a surrounding halo  - Special stains (Grocott-Gomori methenamine-silver nitrate and periodic acid–Schiff) highlighted fungal forms  - Fungal culture on Sabouraud dextrose agar was negative  - HIV-1 and HIV-2 serologic testing were negativeImages:- Figure 1A Title: Tongue ulcer- Figure 1B Title: Biopsy from the ulcer showing a mixed cell infiltrate (hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification ×40)- Figure 1C Title: Intracellular yeast forms within the histiocytes (original magnification ×100)
final_diagnosis: Primary oral histoplasmosis
option_d: Deep fungal infection such as blastomycosis
reason: The case presents a nonhealing ulcer on the tongue with histopathological findings indicating a fungal infection, which falls under the domain of infectious diseases.

case_information: A 64-year-old woman presented to the emergency department with bilateral progressive blurred vision. Symptoms started 1 day after starting ulixertinib, presenting to clinic on day 10 of treatment.

Genetic Testing:       Result: Positive for BRAF mutation

case_information: A woman in her 70s presented with a week of painless, rapidly progressive, edematous, necrotic papules and plaques on the extremities, buttocks, and face with sharp demarcation at the nasolabial folds and extension into the oral mucosa. Notable symptoms included 4 months of extreme fatigue, 20.4 kg weight loss, and a recent episode of hematochezia. Medical history included diabetes, hyperlipidemia, and hypertension that were well controlled with simvastatin, chlorthalidone, hydralazine hydrochloride, lisinopril, and verapamil hydrochloride for 5 years with no new exposures. Age-appropriate cancer screening was up to date.
physical_examination: Patient was afebrile and hemodynamically stable. Examination showed edematous, ulcerated pink plaques confluent on forehead and cheeks with sharp demarcation at nasolabial fold. Retiform purpuric plaque was present on the left leg with overlying desquamation. On hospital day 2, she developed bright red blood per rectum.

case_information: An obese man in his mid-30s with no prior systemic or ocular disorders presented to a local emergency department after waking with vision loss in his right eye. The night prior, he had been drinking alcohol heavily and took 2 buprenorphine hydrochloride/naloxone hydrochloride pills. He denied any trauma. He also experienced pain, numbness, and erythematous induration of his right eyelids and forearm that increased throughout the day.
physical_examination: Visual acuity: No light perception in right eye (OD) and 20/20 in left eye (OS). Right eye showed tense eyelid edema, chemosis, corneal haze, and restricted motility in all fields of gaze. Right pupil was mid-dilated with a relative afferent pupillary defect. Intraocular pressure was 37 mm Hg OD and 21 mm Hg OS. Ophthalmoscopic examination revealed tortuous vessels, serous retinal detachment sparing the inferior periphery, and macular whitening. Left eye examination was normal.

case_information: A male patient in the fourth decade of life, born to an Egyptian family and living in France. case_information: A 17-month-old boy presented with a slow-growing, nontender plaque on the lower back. The plaque was initially 1 × 1 cm and had grown with the child. case_information: A man in his 20s presented to the emergency department with 1 day of chest pressure. In the early morning of the day of presentation, he was awakened from sleep by constant chest pressure radiating to the right jaw, diaphoresis, and 1 episode of vomiting. He reported no medical history.

Cardiac examination revealed a regular rate and rhythm, normal point of maximum impulse without lifts, and no murmurs, rubs, or gallops in supine, sitting, or standing positions.   * Initial serum troponin I level: 6.18 ng/mL
  * Elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein (values increased over next 3 days)

- Imaging and Other Tests:
  * ECG Findings: Normal sinus rhythm, ST-segment elevations with PR-segment depression in leads II, III, and aVF, ST-segment depression in lead V1, and PR-segment elevation in lead aVR
  * Coronary angiography: Normal coronary arteries, left ventricular end-diastolic pressure 12 mm Hg (reference range, 4-12 mm Hg)
  * Transthoracic echocardiogram: Normal results

case_information: A woman in her 70s with a history of recurrent stasis dermatitis treated with long-term topical and systemic corticosteroids presented to the clinic with painful swelling over the right lower leg of 1 week's duration. case_information: An elderly man with undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma enrolled in a clinical trial of neoadjuvant treatment with pembrolizumab and radiation therapy. Six months after starting pembrolizumab, he developed gum pain and bleeding.
physical_examination: The maxillary and mandibular buccal gingivae appeared diffusely enlarged, erythematous, and cobblestoned. case_information: A full-term girl presented at birth with multiple skin lesions. One month later, she returned due to recurring skin eruptions. She was born to healthy, nonconsanguineous parents. case_information: A person was found in their home unconscious and unresponsive. After rhythm analysis, the AED indicated that 1 shock should be administered. After the shock was administered, the patient recovered their pulse. When the emergency medical team arrived, the patient was intubated, ventilated, and transported to the hospital.

case_information: A homosexual man presented with an ulcerative lesion on his penis of 2 months' duration. He had consulted several dermatologists and received different local and systemic treatments including antibiotics, steroids, and antimycotic drugs, with no improvement. The patient had a stable partner and denied both casual and unprotected sex as well as the use of creams or balms on the penis. During counseling, the patient reported using a substance called 'Jungle Juice' during sexual encounters, and could not rule out accidental contact between his contaminated hands and his genitals.

diagnostic_tests:

- Microbiological Tests: Screening for common bacteria and yeasts - negative results
- PCR Testing: Tests for Treponema and Chlamydia species - negative results
- Histologic Analysis: Full epidermal necrosis with infiltration of neutrophils and eosinophils. A diffuse dermal inflammatory infiltrate rich in polymorphonucleocytes, and focal fibrinoid necrosis of superficial vessels
- Patch Testing: International Contact Dermatitis Research Group standard series and single patch test with alkyl nitrite preparation at 2% in water - negative at 48 and 72 hours

final_diagnosis: Irritant (popper) contact dermatitis

case_information: A man in his 50s presented with an asymptomatic, arc-shaped, depressed skin groove on the left side of his forehead, frontal scalp, and vertex area. The result of a hair pull test was negative.

case_information: A man in his 40s presented with sudden-onset slurring of speech and imbalance on walking. He had difficulty swallowing and required a nasogastric tube for feeding. Six months previously, he had left-sided hemiparesis, which had improved significantly. On day 5 of admission, purposeless tapping movements were observed in the patient's right hand. The movements were repetitive, of the same type, and lasted for 30 seconds to 5 minutes. The patient was able to suppress these movements at will. These movements were not preceded by an urge to perform them, and on stopping, there was no development of internal tension. The movements were not associated with any change in sensorium or incontinence. The movements slowly decreased in severity but maintained the same pattern. He was discharged on day 28 when the movements were very mild. At the 1-month follow-up, the movements had almost disappeared.
physical_examination: The patient demonstrated repetitive tapping movements in the right hand that could be voluntarily suppressed.

final_diagnosis: Post-stroke stereotypy secondary to acute left thalamic infarct
option_b: Post-stroke stereotypy secondary to acute left thalamic infarct
reason: The case presents symptoms and findings consistent with neurological conditions, including slurred speech, imbalance, hemiparesis, and stereotypic movements, which are indicative of neurological disorders.

case_information: A white woman in her 60s with history of bone marrow transplant in 2014. case_information: A 78-year-old man presented with painful swelling and ulceration of the glans penis of 1 month's duration. His medical history included an elevated white blood cell count and inguinal lymphadenopathy discovered 9 years prior. Four years after initial presentation, he experienced fatigue, weight loss, and loss of appetite. The current illness began 1 month prior to admission when he noticed asymptomatic 'green-yellow welts' and swelling of the glans penis. The swelling became progressively painful and evolved to the size of an 'orange' over 4 days. Previous treatments with topical antibiotics, antifungal agents, hydrogen peroxide soaks, warm compresses, and cephalexin showed no improvement.
physical_examination: Patient appeared healthy. The glans penis and corona were grossly edematous, with a 3.7 × 3.3-cm tender, firm ulcer on the ventral surface of the penis with overlying black eschar, adherent yellow crust, and granulation tissue. No urethral discharge was present.
diagnostic_tests:
- Laboratory Tests: Routine blood test results were within normal limits. Cultures, assays, and blood tests evaluating for viral, bacterial, or fungal etiology were negative.

- Pathology Studies: Biopsy of the glans penis ulcer showed dermal infiltrate of atypical lymphocytes, which were CD20+, CD79a+, and CD5+, within the background of a reactive T-cell infiltrate. PCR analysis revealed a clonal IgH gene rearrangement.

- Imaging Studies: PET-CT scan demonstrated FDG-avid abdominal and peripancreatic lymph nodes.
  Image Title: Clinical Appearance of the Penis
  Image Description: Grossly edematous glans penis and corona with a tender, firm ulcer on the ventral surface of the penis with overlying black eschar, adherent yellow crust, and granulation tissue.

  Image Title: Histologic Evaluation of Penile Lesion
  Image Description: Hematoxylin-eosin staining showing dermal infiltrate of large, atypical lymphocytes within a reactive T-cell infiltrate (original magnification ×100)
final_diagnosis: Richter's transformation presenting as penile ulcer (transformation of chronic lymphocytic leukemia to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma)
option_d: Richter's transformation presenting as penile ulcer (transformation of chronic lymphocytic leukemia to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma)
reason: The case involves a significant issue with the glans penis, including ulceration and swelling, which falls under urology. Additionally, the findings suggest a possible malignancy, which urologists often manage.

She reported enlargement of the tongue over the past 3 months, leading to difficulty with mastication. She also experienced numbness without weakness of her distal lower limbs for 3 months, which restricted her mobility requiring diapers. Her medical history included IgG λ-type multiple myeloma complicated by anemia and lytic lesions in the calvarium, managed conservatively with transfusions. She was taking folic acid and intramuscular cyanocobalamin supplements due to deficiencies attributed to dietary cause.
physical_examination: Circinate purpuric patches with erosions on the natal cleft, buttocks, inguinal creases, and vulva. Hemorrhagic flaccid bullae on the posterior perineum. Macroglossia, glossitis, and a hemorrhagic erosion on the hard palate. Purpuric macules present periorbitally, on the lips, inframammary folds, forearms, and thighs.
diagnostic_tests:
- Laboratory findings:
  * Platelet count: 171 × 103/μL (reference range, 140-440 × 103/μL)
  * Prothrombin time: 11.7 seconds (reference range, 9.9-11.4 seconds)
  * Activated partial thromboplastin time: 36.0 seconds (reference range, 25.7-32.9 seconds)
  * Serum zinc: 34.4 μg/dL (reference range, 72.4-124.4 μg/dL)

- Biopsy findings:
  * Initial punch biopsies from right inframammary fold and perineal blister were inconclusive
  * Repeated biopsy from left groin showed subepidermal blister lined by fibrin and chronic inflammatory infiltrate, with scattered short eosinophilic bands in the dermis showing apple-green birefringence on polarized light microscopy with Congo red staining
  * Direct immunofluorescence test was negative

- Additional tests:
  * Herpes simplex virus PCR from perineal ulcer swab was negative
final_diagnosis: Bullous amyloidosis
option_d: Acquired Cutaneous Amyloidosis (Secondary to Multiple Myeloma)
reason: The case presents with significant dermatological symptoms including blisters, ulcers, and purpuric patches, which are indicative of a skin condition. The biopsy findings also suggest a dermatological issue.

case_information: A 33-year-old male soldier experienced syncope while deployed overseas. The episode occurred after prolonged standing in a warm environment, with prodromal symptoms of lightheadedness, greying out, diaphoresis, and fatigue. Loss of consciousness lasted less than 30 seconds, followed by a head strike. After regaining consciousness, he experienced several hours of severe headache, clouded thought, and some memory loss. He had multiple near-syncopal events without loss of consciousness over the previous 2 years, each preceded by similar symptoms and associated with prolonged standing. His history was unremarkable, and he was not taking any medications. He denied episodes with exertion, dehydration, emotional stress, or other activities.
physical_examination: Cardiology examination was unremarkable, with no murmurs, gallops, unequal pulses, or neurologic abnormalities.
diagnostic_tests: - Laboratory tests: No anemia, electrolyte abnormalities, or abnormal thyroid function.- Cardiac monitoring:  * ECG showed normal sinus rhythm  * 2-week cardiac event monitor showed no evidence of arrhythmias or pathologic block at rest or with activity  * Graded exercise treadmill test showed excellent functional capacity, appropriate heart rate and blood pressure augmentation with exercise, no exercise-induced arrhythmias or chronotropic incompetence- Imaging:  * Transthoracic echocardiogram showed no valvular abnormalities, normal systolic and diastolic function (ejection fraction 55%-60%), normal left and right ventricular chamber dimensions- Special tests:  * Drug-free tilt-table test induced syncope with ECG showing profound sinus bradycardia to 30 beats per minute, transition to junctional bradycardia during presyncope, followed by sinus pause with >6-second pauses without associated escape rhythm during syncope
final_diagnosis: Vasovagal cardioinhibitory syncope
reason: The case involves syncope and bradycardia, which are primarily cardiac issues. The tilt-table test results indicate a significant cardiac response during syncope.

case_information: A 31-year-old male nursing student with a history of axillary hyperhidrosis presented with excessive sweating of the buttocks, most severe at the intergluteal cleft and sacrum. He had previously treated his axillary condition successfully with 20% aluminum chloride; however, treatment of the intergluteal cleft and sacrum with aluminum chloride was unsuccessful. Due to the severity of the condition, he used absorbent pads yet continued to soak through his pants and was consequently unable to attend work.
physical_examination: The Minor starch-iodine test was performed to help localize the sites of overactive sweating. Areas of significant sweating were identified in the sacral region (10 × 3-cm area) and intergluteal cleft (6 × 8-cm area).

final_diagnosis: Intergluteal and sacral hyperhidrosis
reason: The case involves excessive sweating (hyperhidrosis) localized to specific areas of the body, which is primarily a dermatological condition.

case_information: A woman in her 70s presented to her general physician with impacted cerumen in the right ear. Two attempts at bilateral irrigation were made by a practice nurse. The patient reported pain and hearing loss in the left ear immediately after syringing. She subsequently developed purulent and blood-stained discharge in that ear.
physical_examination: Examination by an ENT specialist found severe otitis externa, with inflammation of the external auditory canal precluding a view of the tympanic membrane. After removal of the wick, the tympanic membrane was visualized and found to have a small anteroinferior perforation. Patient developed a left facial palsy, with lagophthalmos, good static tone of the mouth, but weak movement on smiling (graded as House-Brackman V).
diagnostic_tests: - Imaging Studies:    CT scan of temporal bones:    Title: Axial Computed Tomographic Scan of Temporal Bone 1 Day After Aural Irrigation    Description: Shows fluid in the left middle ear and mastoid air cells, without evidence of bone erosion. Normal external auditory canal.  - Audiological Tests:    Title: Audiogram and Tympanogram 3 Years After Aural Irrigation    Description: Shows mixed sensorineural and conductive hearing loss in the left ear. Tympanometry in the left ear confirms a high volume owing to tympanic membrane perforation.
final_diagnosis: Permanent facial palsy and mixed hearing loss secondary to aural irrigation complications
option_a: Traumatic tympanic membrane perforation with secondary bacterial otitis media and facial neuritis
option_b: Permanent facial palsy and mixed hearing loss secondary to aural irrigation complications
option_c: Bell’s palsy (facial nerve palsy of uncertain etiology)
reason: The case involves ear-related issues, including impacted cerumen, otitis externa, tympanic membrane perforation, and facial palsy, which are all within the scope of Otolaryngology.

case_information: A woman in her 50s presented with 4 days of blurry vision and pain in her left eye after undergoing a routine dental cleaning 1 week prior. She had no history of gingival disease or cavities. Her medical and ocular histories were unremarkable.
physical_examination: Visual acuity was 20/25 OD and 20/50 OS. Intraocular pressures were 15 mm Hg OD and 11 mm Hg OS. Left eye examination showed conjunctival hyperemia, faint keratic precipitates, 3+ cells with fibrin in the anterior chamber, mild nuclear sclerosis, and a whitish focal granuloma at the 4-o'clock position at the pupillary margin. The posterior segment was unremarkable, with no evidence of vitritis, retinitis, or vasculitis. The right eye was unremarkable. At 1-day follow-up, visual acuity declined to 20/100 OS, with development of hypopyon and increased fibrinous material emanating from the iris lesion. No posterior segment involvement was noted.
diagnostic_tests: - Microscopy: Gram stain revealed gram-positive cocci in chains and gram-positive rods in a branching pattern.  Image Title: Gram Stain of Iris Abscess  Image Description: Mixed flora of gram-positive cocci in pairs and chains and gram-positive bacilli (original magnification ×400)- Cultures: Aerobic culture revealed Streptococcus intermedius. The gram-positive bacilli could not be identified more specifically.- Additional Tests: Blood and urine cultures, electrocardiogram and echocardiogram were unremarkable.

option_b: Polymicrobial bacterial iris abscess (Streptococcus intermedius and likely Actinomyces)
reason: The case involves ocular symptoms, including blurry vision and eye pain, along with findings of an iris lesion and hypopyon, indicating a potential infectious or inflammatory eye condition.

case_information: A school-aged girl presented with a 6-year history of hair loss and short hair. Her scalp hair was relatively normal in density and length at birth. case_information: A man in his 20s presented with complaints of intermittent palpitations for 2 days, which had worsened in the previous hour. He had no history of chest pain, dyspnea, congestion, or fever. There was no past cardiac history or family history of similar complaints.

Image B Title: Post-treatment ECG    Image B Description: Normal sinus rhythm at 64 bpm with normal QRS axis. Precordial T-wave inversion in leads V1 to V5, I, and aVL. case_information: A man in his 60s presented with a lesion on the left lower eyelid. His ocular history was notable for a traumatic icicle injury as a child that resulted in loss of the left eye. He had contraction of the conjunctival mucosal tissue across the fornix of the left lower eyelid and increased scleral show of his ocular prosthesis with shortening of his lower eyelid skin. His prosthesis was extruded from his socket due to cicatricial effects causing conjunctival shrinkage and eyelid skin contracture.

case_information: A 59-year-old white man presented for annual follow-up of bilateral choroidal nevi. Medical history includes complete wide excision of a cutaneous melanoma of the left forearm with negative sentinel lymph node biopsy ten years prior. One year before the visit, he developed a left axillary mass with positive biopsy. He received 4 infusions of 240 mg of nivolumab at 2-week intervals, which was discontinued due to elevated liver function test results, hypothyroidism, xerostomia, and dizziness. Current medications include levothyroxine, aspirin, atenolol, and atorvastatin. The patient developed vitiligo on his arms 1 month prior to the eye examination.
physical_examination: Visual acuity of 20/20 OU, early cataracts, and no inflammation. Fundus examination of the right eye showed a persistent flat nevus along the inferior arcade with numerous hypopigmented, yellowish spots of varying size. A previously noted nevus on the nasal side of the optic disc had disappeared. Fundus examination of the left eye revealed the absence of a previously noted nevus in the macula.
diagnostic_tests:
- Imaging Studies:
  1. B-scan ultrasonography: Ruled out any mass or calcification

case_information: A 66-year-old woman with hypertension presented with 2 months of progressive right earache and headache without fever, 2 weeks of mild left-sided weakness, and 1 week of intermittent hallucinations and nonsensical speech. The patient was later found to have type 2 diabetes.

diagnostic_tests: {'Laboratory Tests': ['- Erythrocyte sedimentation rate: 42 mm/h (normal, <20 mm/h)', '- C-reactive protein level: 25 mg/L (normal, <10 mg/L)', '- Glycosylated hemoglobin A1C level: 6.8% (normal, 4.3%-6.1%)', '- Serological tests unremarkable for IgG4, HIV, syphilis, tuberculosis, Toxoplasma gondii, rubella virus, cytomegalovirus, and herpes simplex virus', '- CSF examination revealed no suggestive abnormalities', '- Autoimmune antibody testing: positive for anti-NMDAR antibodies (CSF titer 1:320, serum titer 1:100), CSF anti-AMPAR1 antibody positive at 1:1', '- CSF next-generation sequencing: positive for Candida tropicalis'], 'Imaging Studies': ['- CT scan of temporal bone showed otitis media, mastoiditis, and local bone destruction in the right ear', '- Brain MRI findings:', '  Figure 1A: Coronal FLAIR image demonstrated extensive area of hyperintensity with compressed right lateral ventricle', '  Figure 1B: Coronal contrast-enhanced MRI revealed heterogeneous enhancement in the dura and pia maters, with right thickened meninges extending to mastoid process', '  Figure 2A: Follow-up showing reduced brain lesion size after treatment', '  Figure 2B: Follow-up showing significantly alleviated pathological thickening of the dura mater and pia maters']}
final_diagnosis: Candida tropicalis meningoencephalitis
reason: The patient presents with neurological symptoms such as left-sided weakness, hallucinations, and nonsensical speech, along with imaging findings indicating brain involvement, which suggests a neurological condition.

case_information: A man in his 40s presented with a 10-day history of edema. Prior to presentation, he had been treated with famciclovir for 1 week, during which the lesions kept developing and were accompanied with irregular fever (maximum temperature, 39°C).
physical_examination: Physical examination revealed:- Edema on both eyelids- Multiple papules, blisters, and crusted erosions with thin exudation on right cheek and neck- Erythematous plaques and tense blisters and bullae on his back and on the dorsal surface of both hands
diagnostic_tests: Laboratory Tests:- Complete blood cell count showed elevated eosinophil count (1.36 × 109/L)- Mild increase in eosinophil levels in bone marrow biopsy- Enterococcus faecalis isolated from exudation swab- Blood and tissue cultures negative- Autoantibody profiles (SLE, Dsg-1, Dsg-3, BP-180, BP-230) negative- Direct immunoflourescence for IgA, IgG, IgM, and C3 negativeHistopathologic Examination:- Irregular hyperplasia and spongiosis of the epidermis with hyperkeratosis and localized necrosis- Extensive edema of dermal papillary and mixed infiltrate of marked diffuse eosinophils and lymphocytes in the dermis, accompanied by scattered neutrophilsImages:Figure 1A Title: Clinical presentation of facial lesionsDescription: Edema on both eyelids; multiple papules, blisters, and crusted erosions with thin exudation on right cheek and neckFigure 1B Title: Clinical presentation of hand lesionsDescription: Erythematous plaques, tense blisters, and bullae on both handsFigure 2A & 2B Title: Histopathologic examinationDescription: Hematoxylin-eosin stained sections showing irregular hyperplasia, spongiosis, dermal edema, and inflammatory cell infiltration
final_diagnosis: Bullous Wells syndrome
option_b: DRESS (Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms)
reason: The case presents with significant skin lesions, including edema, papules, blisters, and crusted erosions, which are characteristic of dermatological conditions. The histopathological findings also indicate a dermatological issue.

case_information: A woman in her 70s presented with a pruritic and painful periorbital eruption that had lasted 1 month. Her medical history included lupus nephritis requiring hemodialysis, immune thrombocytopenia, acute myeloid leukemia, chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy, deep vein thrombosis, diverticulitis, and postcolectomy diarrhea. Past treatments included hydroxychloroquine (resulted in retinal toxic effects) and lenalidomide (severely worsened platelet count, with a nadir of 28 ×103/μL).
physical_examination: Physical examination demonstrated scaly, crusted pink plaques that involved the periorbital skin.
diagnostic_tests: - Biopsy Results: Punch biopsy from the left upper eyelid demonstrated vacuolar interface dermatitis with follicular involvement and epidermal atrophy.- Images:  Image Title: Figure 1. Frontal View of Periorbital Lesions Before and After 2 Months of Treatment  Image Description: Frontal view showing periorbital involvement    Image Title: Figure 2. Views of Periorbital Lesions Before and After 2 Months of Treatment  Image Description: Views from the right and left sides
final_diagnosis: Periorbital Discoid Lupus Erythematosus (DLE)
reason: The case involves a pruritic and painful periorbital eruption with specific dermatological findings, including biopsy results indicating vacuolar interface dermatitis, which falls under the expertise of dermatology.

case_information: A man in his 70s presented with a 2-week history of a bullous eruption localized to the hands and feet. He denied having pruritus or spontaneous bleeding but reported discomfort from the pressure of intact bullae. Medical history included diabetes mellitus and hypertension, well controlled with a stable regimen of lisinopril and atenolol for several years. He denied using any new medications or supplements or making recent dose adjustments in existing medications. No history of prior bullous eruption.
physical_examination: Numerous small intact bullae and large erosions on the lateral feet, soles, and toes. The extent of the bullae led to difficulty with ambulation. Intact vesicles present on the lateral palms along with erosions demonstrating evidence of previous bullae formation. No vesicular or bullous lesions on the trunk, arms, legs, or mucosal surfaces.
diagnostic_tests: - Histopathology:    Image Title: Biopsy specimen from foot bulla    Image Description: Revealed a subepidermal bulla with numerous dermal eosinophils and degranulation of eosinophils at the dermal-epidermal junction (hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification ×600)    - Immunological Studies:    - Direct immunofluorescence: Strong linear staining of C3 at the dermal-epidermal junction    - Salt-split skin analysis: Deposits of IgG and C3 on the epidermal roof    - Serum antibodies: Strongly positive for antibodies to BP180 and BP230      - Clinical Images:    Image Title: Clinical presentation of feet    Image Description: Numerous small bullae in various stages of healing and large erosions on the feet with areas of denuded pink dermis
final_diagnosis: Dyshidrosiform pemphigoid
reason: The case presents a bullous eruption with specific histopathological and immunological findings indicative of a dermatological condition, likely bullous pemphigoid, which falls under the expertise of dermatology.

case_information: An elderly man presented to the emergency department after falling out of bed with quadriplegia, urinary and stool incontinence, and hypothermia (temperature, 33.1°C).
physical_examination: Physical examination revealed:- Absent rectal tone- Complete sensory loss- Quadriplegia- Temperature: 33.1°C- Urinary and stool incontinence
diagnostic_tests: - MRI of cervical spine:  Image Title: Magnetic Resonance Imaging of the Cervical Spine  Image Description: Showed anterior and posterior longitudinal ligament, ligamentum flavum, and interspinous disruptions at C4 and C5 with spinal cord compression with anterolisthesis.- Diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI):  Image Title: Axial Diffusion-Weighted Imaging  Image Description: Revealed abnormally hyperintense spinal cord white matter, reflecting reduced diffusion, which outlines the hypointense signal of central gray matter. At the level of C5 and C6, reduced diffusion in the spinal cord white matter, outlining a hypointense signal of the central gray matter.
final_diagnosis: Complete spinal cord injury (SCI) at C4-C5 level with intramedullary hemorrhage
option_a: Acute traumatic cervical spinal cord injury
option_b: Cervical spinal cord injury (C4-C5) with spinal cord compression
option_c: Traumatic spinal cord injury with spinal cord compression and anterolisthesis
option_d: Complete spinal cord injury (SCI) at C4-C5 level with intramedullary hemorrhage
reason: The case involves quadriplegia and spinal cord compression, which are neurological issues requiring evaluation and management by a neurologist.

case_information: A man in his 70s with a 6-year history of psoriasiform dermatitis presented with worsening of his eruption and new eroded and noneroded nodules on his forehead. His condition had been partially controlled with topical corticosteroids, methotrexate (20 mg/wk), acitretin (25 mg/d), and narrowband UV-B phototherapy 3 times weekly. Two months prior, he developed widespread molluscum contagiosum, with negative HIV screening. He denied systemic symptoms including weight loss, fevers, and/or chills. Medical history included multiple nonmelanoma skin cancers (basal and squamous cell carcinomas), in situ melanoma on the back, ocular melanoma, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes mellitus.
physical_examination: Physical examination revealed:- Several pink, shiny, eroded papules and nodules on the right frontal scalp, left forehead and left cheek- Numerous, confluent, umbilicated pink papules on the lower back and buttocks- Keratoderma of the palms- Several infiltrated, pink nonscaly plaques and nodules on the thighs and lower legs- No palpable lymphadenopathy
diagnostic_tests: Laboratory Tests:- Normal white blood cell count- Elevated CD4/CD8 ratio at 310- Flow cytometry showed aberrant CD4-positive T-cell population (44% of total cells)  - CD2, CD4, and CD5 moderately positive  - CD3 dimly positive  - CD7, CD8, CD10, CD16, CD38, CD56, and CD57 negative- EBV DNA elevated (630 copies/mL)- Negative for human T-lymphotropic virus types 1 and 2Imaging Studies:- Positron emission tomography–computed tomography showed small hypermetabolic lymph nodes without visceral involvementPathology:1. Right forehead and left cheek biopsy:- Nodular and folliculotropic atypical lymphoid infiltrate- Predominance of CD20+ B cells- Positive for Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)–encoded small RNAs (EBER)- B-cell rearrangement confirmed2. Left thigh biopsy:- Diffuse and nodular atypical lymphoid infiltrate- Positive for CD3, CD4, and CD5- Loss of CD7- Negative for CD20 and CD30- T-cell rearrangement confirmed
final_diagnosis: Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (CTCL) stage IIIB (T2N0M0B2)
option_c: Mycosis fungoides with large cell transformation
option_d: Peripheral T-cell lymphoma, not otherwise specified
reason: The case involves a complex skin condition with psoriasiform dermatitis, nodules, and molluscum contagiosum, along with significant dermatological findings and biopsies indicating atypical lymphoid infiltrates.

case_information: A woman in her 40s presented with a 3-year history of a complex progressive disorder characterized by:- Emotional lability- Cognitive decline - Generalized ataxia- Autonomic dysfunctionPatient denied paresthesias, dysesthesias, or loss of sensation.
physical_examination: Autonomic testing revealed:- Abnormal cardiac parasympathetic function (without orthostatic hypotension)- Patchy decrease in sweat output on quantitative sudomotor axon reflex test- Markedly abnormal thermoregulatory sweat test with near complete global anhidrosis
diagnostic_tests: - Laboratory tests:  - α-galactosidase activity: 0.056 U/L (normal range: 0.074-0.457 U/L)  - Cerebrospinal fluid analysis:    - Elevated protein levels (95 mg/dL)    - No pleocytosis (WBC: 0/μL)    - Polymorphonucleocytes: 7%    - Lymphocytes: 83%    - Monocytes: 9%  - Imaging studies:  - MRI Brain:    Image Description: Bilateral hyperintensity in the pulvinar region of thalami and global diffuse brain volume loss  - MRI Spine: No spinal cord lesions  - Genetic Testing:  - Positive for pseudo-α-galactosidase allele  - Neuropsychological Testing:  - Showed mild neurocognitive and memory deficits
final_diagnosis: Pseudo-α-galactosidase deficiency (PAGD) syndrome with mild neurocognitive disorder
option_d: Pseudo-α-galactosidase deficiency (PAGD) syndrome with mild neurocognitive disorder
reason: The case presents with cognitive decline, ataxia, and autonomic dysfunction, which are indicative of a neurological disorder. The MRI findings and genetic testing further support a neurological condition.

case_information: A healthy male toddler presented to the emergency department with abdominal pain and distention, fever, and vomiting of 1 day's duration. He was found to have 'bruises' on both flanks. Over the next 2 days, he developed diffuse papules on the trunk and extremities; his condition rapidly deteriorated requiring intubation, vasopressors, and empirical broad-spectrum antibiotics.
physical_examination: Purpuric retiform patches were found on each flank (1 of them studded with 2 pustules) with erythematous to violaceous papules diffusely scattered on the extremities and trunk.
diagnostic_tests: - Laboratory tests:  - Hyponatremia and neutropenia present  - AST: 45 U/L  - ALT: 142 U/L   - C-reactive protein: >270 mg/L  - Erythrocyte sedimentation rate: 43 mm/h  - Ferritin: 603 ng/mL  - Urinalysis showed proteinuria and hematuria- Imaging studies:  - CT chest/abdomen: Cavitary lesions in lungs representing necrotizing pneumonia. Areas of nonenhancement within both kidneys suspected to represent renal abscesses  - MRI brain: Multifocal lesions, likely septic emboli  - Transthoracic echocardiogram: Negative  - Bone scans: Negative- Pathological tests:  - Punch biopsy findings:    - Frozen section: Small organisms within vasculature    - Permanent sections: Large neutrophilic pustule with inflammation throughout dermis and prominent necrosis with basophilic structures filling necrotic vascular spaces    - Tissue Gram staining: Gram-positive cocci in vessels  - Tissue culture, blood culture, bronchial washings, and fluid from bilateral empyemas all showed positive results
final_diagnosis: Community-acquired methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (CA-MRSA) sepsis with septic vasculopathy
option_b: Disseminated Staphylococcus aureus infection with septic emboli
option_c: Community-acquired methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (CA-MRSA) sepsis with septic vasculopathy
option_d: Bacterial sepsis with disseminated intravascular coagulation
reason: The case presents severe systemic infection with skin manifestations, respiratory involvement, and renal abscesses, indicating a likely infectious etiology requiring specialized management.

case_information: A 2-year-old girl presented with skin fragility since early infancy. She had 2 older brothers, and the family had no medical history of note. Symptoms improved in winter and worsened in summer. Physical and mental developments were normal. The mother reported finding the child peeling off skin with marked facility.
physical_examination: Physical examination revealed:- Mild xerosis with superficial skin erosions- Erythematous residual macules from previous erosions- Some lesions had unusual linear geographic contour- Lesions predominantly located at areas of friction- Hair, nails, and mucous membranes were normal- No history of blistering
diagnostic_tests: 1. Laboratory Tests:- Serological markers for celiac disease were negative2. Skin Biopsy Findings:- Hematoxylin-eosin staining showed:  * Complete separation of the stratum corneum  * Clean split just above the stratum granulosum  * Faint psoriasiform hyperplasia  * Mild perivascular and interstitial mononuclear infiltrate in upper dermis3. Immunofluorescence Mapping:- Normal results for:  * Collagen IV and VII  * α6 and β4 integrines  * Laminine-3324. Genetic Study:- Revealed 2 heterozygous mutations in exon 2 of the CDSN geneImages:- Figure A Title: Clinical photograph of disease outbreak  Description: Superficial erosions distributed predominantly around the trunk, some with geometric shape- Figure B Title: Photograph showing localized affectation  Description: Erythemato-desquamative well-demarcated plaque with peeling borders on right foot- Figure C Title: Hematoxylin-eosin staining  Description: Detachment of entire stratum corneum and mild psoriasiform epidermis hyperplasia
final_diagnosis: Peeling skin disease (PSD)
reason: The case presents with skin fragility, erosions, and specific histological findings indicative of a dermatological condition, making Dermatology the appropriate department.

case_information: A man in his 70s with no history of cardiovascular disease presented to the emergency department after a single episode of chest pressure the previous day. He noted substernal pressure that resolved after 10 minutes of rest but did not complain of any other symptoms. He presented to the emergency department 1 day later at the recommendation of his primary care provider. He had not experienced any chest pressure since the single episode.
physical_examination: Patient was hemodynamically stable with a blood pressure of 153/69 mm Hg and heart rate of 63 beats per minute; breathing comfortably on room air. Cardiac examination was normal without any murmurs or gallops. Neck veins were nondistended, and breath sounds were normal.
diagnostic_tests: - Laboratory Tests:    * Blood chemistry tests and complete blood count were within normal limits    * Troponin T hs Gen 5: 0.32 ng/L (reference range, 0-14 ng/L), repeat measurement 0.30 ng/L 1 hour later- ECG Findings:    * Image Title: Figure 1A - Electrocardiographic Results at Presentation    * Image Description: Inverted T waves in leads V2 and V3, biphasic T wave in lead V4. Normal sinus rhythm and regular rate. Conduction delay in lead V1 and nonpathologic Q waves.- Echocardiogram:    * Normal left ventricular ejection fraction with focal hypokinesis of the inferoapical and apical left ventricular walls- Coronary Angiography:    * Image Title: Figure 2A - Coronary Angiographic Results at Presentation    * Image Description: 100% occlusion of the mid left anterior descending coronary artery (LADCA); proximal to the occlusion, the LADCA was aneurysmal. Collaterals to the distal LADCA from the right coronary artery.
final_diagnosis: Wellens syndrome
reason: The case involves a patient with chest pressure and significant coronary artery occlusion, indicating a cardiac issue that requires evaluation and management by a cardiology specialist.

case_information: A man in his 60s with prior heart transplantation presented with intermittent syncope. During episodes of lightheadedness, ECG recordings were obtained.
physical_examination: Clinical examination did not reveal any evidence of rejection.
diagnostic_tests: - Cardiac ultrasonography: Showed normal left ventricular function- ECG findings:  Image Title: 12-Lead ECG in a Patient With Remote Orthotopic Heart Transplantation  Image Description: Shows underlying rhythm with atrial rate of 230 beats per minute, with intermittent pauses up to 1.8 seconds. Two distinct atrial activation patterns observed - flutter waves and separate discrete P-waves with different morphology.- Intracardiac Electrogram (EGM):  Image Title: Diagram of the Suture Line in a Biatrial Anastomosis Orthotopic Heart Transplantation  Image Description: When atrial lead placed in posterior right atrium (recipient portion), atrial flutter was recorded. case_information: A teenaged male presented with a 2-week history of vegetating, bleeding plaques and pustules on his face, scalp, trunk, and extremities. Lesions began as pustules and developed into painful, itchy plaques. Prior treatment included prednisolone tablet 5 mg twice daily, clindamycin hydrochloride 300 mg daily, and fluconazole 200 mg daily, but patient continued to develop new lesions. Patient reported difficulty walking due to skin lesions.
physical_examination: Pustules and hemorrhagic-crusted plaques were seen on the scalp, legs, arms, and trunk along with keloidal plaques on the face.
diagnostic_tests:
- Laboratory Tests:
Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay testing for HIV was negative

- Histopathology:
Punch biopsy from arm showed:
- Epidermal hyperplasia and exocytosis of neutrophils
- Dense dermal-mixed inflammatory cell infiltration
- Microabscesses scattered with eosinophils
- No granulomas or multinucleated giant cells
- Negative periodic acid–Schiff staining

- Images:
Image A Title: Vegetative plaques on extremities
Description: Extensive vegetative plaques with bleeding and ulceration

Image B Title: Lesions on extremities and trunk
Description: Pustules and ulcerated plaques

Image C Title: Histopathologic examination (×100)
Description: Pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia (hematoxylin-eosin stain)

Image D Title: Histopathologic examination (×400)
Description: Dermal neutrophilia and microabscesses with eosinophilia (hematoxylin-eosin stain)
final_diagnosis: Pyoderma vegetans
reason: The case presents with extensive skin lesions, including vegetating plaques and pustules, which are indicative of a dermatological condition. The histopathological findings further support a diagnosis related to skin pathology.

case_information: A patient in their 60s with history of ischemic cardiomyopathy (ejection fraction 25%) and single-chamber primary prevention implantable cardioverter-defibrillator presented with worsening shortness of breath and New York Heart Association functional class IV symptoms. Patient had been on amiodarone treatment previously.

final_diagnosis: Dual tachycardia: Atrial flutter with accelerated idioventricular rhythm (AIVR)
option_b: Dual tachycardia: Atrial flutter with accelerated idioventricular rhythm (AIVR)
option_d: Dual tachyarrhythmias (atrial tachycardia plus slow ventricular tachycardia)

case_information: A young child presented with a 6-month history of an asymptomatic expanding erythematous eruption on the lower legs, abdomen, and buttocks. The eruption would wax and wane, with each episode lasting for approximately 1 week, without residual pigmentation. No family history of autoimmune disease, and the child had not experienced any fevers or exposures to ticks or other arthropods.
physical_examination: Clinical examination revealed faint, nonscaling annular serpiginous, erythematous plaques with central clearing, and barely elevated borders.
diagnostic_tests: {'Laboratory Tests': ['Erythrocyte sedimentation rate: within normal limits', 'Complete blood cell count: within normal limits', 'Antinuclear antibodies: within normal limits', 'Anti-Ro/SSA and anti-La/SSB antibodies: within normal limits', 'Borrelia burgdorferi antibodies: within normal limits'], 'Histopathology': {'Findings': 'Punch biopsy from the left thigh showed superficial and deep, perivascular, and interstitial inflammatory infiltrate consisting of lymphocytes, histiocytes, neutrophils, and eosinophils', 'Images': [{'Title': 'Figure A', 'Description': "Annular serpiginous plaques with areas of central clearing on the patient's right thigh and buttocks"}, {'Title': 'Figure B', 'Description': 'Histopathologic image showing perivascular and inflammatory infiltrate (hematoxylin-eosin)'}, {'Title': 'Figure C', 'Description': 'Histopathologic image showing perivascular and inflammatory infiltrate that includes eosinophils (hematoxylin-eosin)'}]}}
final_diagnosis: Annular erythema of infancy (AEI)

case_information: A man in his 50s with a 10-year history of Crohn disease had intermittent bowel obstructions leading to total proctocolectomy and ileostomy. Five weeks after his surgery, he developed a painful, erosive lesion around his stoma on the anterior abdominal wall. No additional cutaneous or mucosal lesions were present.
physical_examination: Painful, erosive lesion present around the stoma on the anterior abdominal wall
diagnostic_tests: - Microbiological cultures: Repeated cultures were negative- Histopathology:   - Revealed epidermal erosion with suprabasal epidermal splitting with acantholysis  - Direct immunofluorescence of perilesional skin showed intercellular deposition of IgG and C3 throughout epidermis- Laboratory tests:  - Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay showed high level of IgG autoantibodies:    - Against desmoglein 1: 40 IU/mL (normal value: 20 U/mL)    - Against desmoglein 3: 90 IU/mL (normal value: 20 U/mL)- Images:  Figure 1A Title: Erosive lesion around stoma  Description: A painful, erosive lesion around the stoma on the anterior abdominal wall  Figure 1B Title: Histopathology  Description: Hematoxylin-eosin stain showing suprabasal epidermal splitting with acantholysis (original magnification ×100)

case_information: A woman in her 60s presented with an itchy plaque on the mid-back. She had had a lesion at that site since childhood, which had remained asymptomatic and pea sized for most of that time. However, over the 10 years prior to presentation it had gradually increased in size and became itchy. There was also occasional oozing of serosanguineous fluid and bleeding from the lesion.
physical_examination: Examination revealed a 1.5 × 1.0-cm well-defined erythematous plaque with overlying ulceration on the mid-back, 1 cm left of the spine. Adjoining skin showed a horseshoe-shaped oval area of lichenification.
diagnostic_tests: - Histopathological examination:    - Revealed a circumscribed tumor contiguous with adjoining normal epidermis and delineated from underlying dermis by continuous apocrine epithelial lining    - Tumor epithelium with multiple papillary projections with vascular, plasma cell–rich stroma    - Several foci showed papillary projections lined by multilayered epithelium with atypical cells, few mitotic figures, and areas of necrosis but no dermal invasion      - Immunohistochemical analysis:    - p63 staining positive in myoepithelial cell layers    - Adjacent skin showed dermal papillae with congophilic amorphous eosinophilic deposits    - Pan-cytokeratin (AE1/3) immunostain positive  Images:  Figure 1 Title: Clinical Image of the Patient  Description: A 1.5 × 1.0-cm well-defined erythematous plaque with indented margin and overlying ulceration, located on the mid-back 1 cm left to the spine. Adjoining skin shows a horseshoe-shaped oval area of lichenification.  Figure 2 Title: Histopathologic Findings From Lesional Specimens  Description: Multiple microscopic images showing tumor architecture, cellular details, immunohistochemical staining, and dermal deposits.
final_diagnosis: Syringocystadenocarcinoma papilliferum in situ (SCACPIS) arising in a precursor lesion of syringocystadenoma papilliferum (SCAP) with macular amyloidosis
option_c: Syringocystadenoma papilliferum with in situ malignant transformation
option_d: Syringocystadenocarcinoma papilliferum in situ (SCACPIS) arising in a precursor lesion of syringocystadenoma papilliferum (SCAP) with macular amyloidosis
reason: The case involves a skin lesion with specific characteristics and histopathological findings indicative of a dermatological condition.

case_information: A young man presented with large, purple plaques on the left lower extremity. The plaques had been present for years, with noted enlargement and darkening for the past 5 years. The lesions were asymptomatic with no associated pruritus, bleeding, or pain. No prior treatments or diagnostic workup had been attempted. The patient was otherwise healthy and was a never-smoker with no history of hypertension, atherosclerotic disease, or HIV.
physical_examination: Dark violaceous plaques, scattered subcutaneous nodules, and swelling to the mid-shin of the left lower extremity were observed. There was mild warmth noted, but no palpable bruits.
diagnostic_tests: - Laboratory tests: Complete metabolic panel, complete blood cell count, prothrombin, and serology were negative or within normal limits. Immunostain for human herpesvirus-8 was negative.- Histopathology:   Punch biopsy showed superficial lobular capillary proliferation with extravasated red blood cells, hemosiderin deposition, and ectatic muscular deep vessels. Verhoeff-van Gieson elastic tissue and Perls iron stains highlighted malformed vessel walls and hemosiderin deposition.- Imaging studies:  1. Duplex ultrasonography of left lower extremity: No evidence of deep or superficial venous thrombosis or arteriovenous malformations  2. Magnetic resonance angiogram with contrast:     Image Description: Revealed hypervascular soft tissue lesions centered in the lower anterior compartment of the left lower leg and medial malleolar region, with multiple tortuous and ectatic vessels  3. Interventional radiologic angiography:     Finding: Confirmed presence of prominent AVMs without high-flow arteriovenous shunting
final_diagnosis: Stewart-Bluefarb syndrome
reason: The case presents with skin lesions (purple plaques) and vascular abnormalities, which are typically evaluated by dermatology, especially given the histopathological findings of capillary proliferation.

case_information: A 56-year-old man presented with a 1-month history of localized, painful, migratory skin lesions. The eruption had begun as erythematous macules on the perineal area and had spread to the buttocks, inner thighs, and lower extremities within several days. The patient had been receiving oral medication (250 mg/d) for 3 months prior to the skin manifestations.
physical_examination: Physical findings revealed coalescing, eroded, erythematous plaques with scales on both lower extremities and buttocks, especially in the perineal, inguinal, and thigh regions. These lesions had coalesced, and some of them had been rubbed off. No mucosal lesions or active changes of the hair or nails were observed.

case_information: An asymptomatic male patient in his 40s with no relevant ocular, medical, or family history was referred for assessment of a retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) defect in his right eye by an optometrist. Over the next 4 years of monitoring, he remained largely asymptomatic, except for mild metamorphopsia reported on his most recent assessment.
physical_examination: Visual acuity was 20/20 OU (both eyes). Examination of his right eye showed a pigment epithelial defect (PED). His left eye showed no retinal abnormalities. During follow-up examinations, the PED in his right eye persisted largely unchanged, with two notable occasions where the PED resolved and then relapsed within an hour during clinic visits.
diagnostic_tests: - Imaging studies:    1. Initial presentation:       Image Title: Color photograph and OCT of right eye       Image Description: Color photograph showing pigment epithelial detachment; OCT showing PED of the right eye        2. 18 months follow-up:       Image Title: OCT Images of right eye       Image Description: First OCT showing absence of PED with small volume of residual sub-RPE fluid; Second OCT (1 hour later) confirming PED        3. 4-year follow-up:       Image Title: OCT Images of right eye       Image Description: First OCT showing very shallow PED; Second OCT (1 hour later) showing relapsed PED
final_diagnosis: Central serous chorioretinopathy-related pigment epithelial detachment (CSCR-related PED)
option_b: Central serous chorioretinopathy-related pigment epithelial detachment (CSCR-related PED)
reason: The case involves a retinal pigment epithelium defect and visual assessment, which falls under the specialty of ophthalmology.

case_information: A woman in her 70s presented with an enlarged and variegated plaque on her left axilla, which she had had for 4 years. The lesion started as a small eczematous, pink-to-brown plaque. As the lesion was asymptomatic and slow growing, she did not initially seek treatment. Recently, the color of the lesion had changed to an alarming dark brown color. No breast mass or lymphadenopathy was observed. Her medical and family history was unremarkable.

case_information: A woman in her 20s presented with a 6-month history of dyspnea during exercise and an inspiratory stridor when lying down, as well as dysphagia and a globus sensation for 2 months. She was known to have asthma and allergic rhinitis.
