Although stroboscopy could not be performed owing to a limited field of view, bilateral pseudosulcus vocalis were seen, suggesting subglottic swelling as well.
diagnostic_tests: - Imaging Studies:    1. CT scan of the neck:       Title: Axial image of the CT scan       Description: Demonstrated diffuse swelling of the epiglottis and bilateral aryepiglottic folds, with compression of the piriform sinus. The vocal cords and bony structures appeared normal and no cervical lymphadenopathy was noted.        2. Barium swallow test: Findings were not aberrant.        3. PET-CT scan: Excluded tumor and other systemic conditions.      - Pathological Examination:    Title: Histopathologic Analysis    Description: Revealed densely packed sheets of CD68-positive histiocytes in D2-40-positive (podoplanin) dilated lymphatic vessels.      - Laboratory Tests: Multiple tests were performed over 5 years of follow-up, showing no evidence of systemic inflammatory or malignant disease.
final_diagnosis: Primary intralymphatic histiocytosis (ILH) of the larynx
option_b: Primary intralymphatic histiocytosis (ILH) of the larynx
reason: The case involves significant upper airway symptoms, including dyspnea, stridor, and dysphagia, along with findings of epiglottic swelling, which are directly related to ENT conditions.

case_information: A 20-year-old woman was being monitored for a left ciliary body mass for 3 years presented with declining vision in her left eye. Her best-corrected visual acuity was 20/20 OD and 20/50 OS.
physical_examination: Pupils, intraocular pressures, anterior chambers, and lenses were unremarkable in both eyes. In the left eye, a nasal mass posterior to the lens was evident, which had grown considerably in size since her last visit. Ophthalmoscopic examination showed a large white mass protruding into the vitreous cavity.
diagnostic_tests: - Ultrasound biomicroscopy:  Image Title: Ultrasound biomicroscopic image  Image Description: Round, cystoid mass with a stalk attached to the nasal pars plana- Ultra-widefield imaging:  Image Title: Ultra-widefield fundus pseudocolor image  Image Description: White mass emanating anteriorly from the nasal ciliary body and protruding into the vitreous cavity; view to the optic nerve and macula is blocked- Histopathological examination:  - Vitreous aspirate cytology: Negative for malignant cells  - Microscopic findings: Hypovascular myxoid lesion composed of loosely arranged spindle and stellate cells with spindle nuclei. Hypocellular core with abundant myxoid stroma, relatively denser cellular area in cortex. No epithelial components, mitoses, or atypical cell-shape features- Immunohistochemical studies:  - S100 (neural crest marker): Positive  - Glial fibrillary acidic protein (astrocyte marker): Patchy positive  - CD34 (fibroblast marker): Negative  - Smooth muscle actin: Negative
final_diagnosis: Ciliary body myxoma
reason: The case involves a ciliary body mass and declining vision, which are directly related to eye health and conditions, making Ophthalmology the appropriate department.

case_information: A man in his 50s presented with a 12-year history of itchy eruptions over the whole body. Multiple nodules appeared on the upper back 1 year previously and gradually increased in number and size. The patient was otherwise healthy and denied a family history of inherited ichthyosis or atopy.
physical_examination: Physical examination revealed extensive, dry scaly patches on the trunk, arms, and legs. Several 0.5- to 1-cm, dome-shaped, red papules and nodules were found on the upper back. Mildly enlarged lymph nodes were observed on the cervical, axillary, and inguinal regions.
diagnostic_tests:
- Laboratory Tests:
  - Routine blood tests, biochemistry analyses, and peripheral blood flow cytometry tests were within normal limits
  - No atypical cells were found in the peripheral blood
  - DNA analysis from paraffin sections showed clonal amplification product for the γ-chain of the T-cell receptor

- Histopathology:
  - Biopsy from back nodules showed:
    - Atrophy of the epidermis with focal orthokeratosis
    - Extensive, dense infiltrate of lymphocytes in the entire dermis
    - Small to medium-sized, atypical lymphocytes with focal areas of epidermotropism
  - Immunohistochemical staining showed:
    - Positive for CD2, CD3, CD4, and CD45RO
    - Few small reactive CD8+ T cells and CD7+ T cells in dermis

- Images:
  Title: Clinical and Histopathologic Images
  Description: Clinical images showing multiple dome-shaped nodules on the back and extensive, dry scaly patches on the leg. Histopathologic images showing small to medium-sized atypical cells, focal areas of epidermotropism, and CD4 on immunohistochemical analysis
final_diagnosis: Ichthyosiform mycosis fungoides
reason: The case presents with skin-related symptoms including itchy eruptions, dry scaly patches, and nodules, along with histopathological findings indicative of a dermatological condition.

case_information: A woman in her 30s presented a 3-month history of scattered asymptomatic cutaneous nodules. Medical history included urticaria of 8 years' duration and diarrhea of 14-months' duration. She had received prednisone for 2 weeks to treat urticaria before the onset of skin nodules. At presentation, she was emaciated with no other known chronic medical conditions. She had not traveled recently but had contact with a domestic hamster 1 month before skin lesion onset.
physical_examination: Physical examination revealed four 1- to 2-cm diameter nodules with central ulceration or thick adherent crust on the left side of her face, left axilla, and bilateral forearms without lymphadenopathy. Findings of the general physical examination were normal.
diagnostic_tests: - Skin Tests:  - Skin lesion exudate smear and skin biopsy revealed numerous yeast cells within histiocytes; yeast cells were rarely extracellular  - Skin biopsy specimens yielded a thermally dimorphic fungus  - Internal transcribed spacer sequence 5 DNA sequencing performed (GenBank accession number: sysu2014.sqn sysu2014 KP260922)- Other Laboratory Tests:  - Fungal cultures of blood, urine, and stool were negative  - CD4+ count: 570.96/mL  - CD8+ count: 287.92/mL  - HIV antibody test: normal  - Serum immunoglobulin: normal  - Complement C3 and C4: normal- Imaging Studies:  - Chest radiography: normal  - Capsule endoscopy: revealed ileal mucosa multiple hyperplasia and ulceration- Pathology:  - Intestinal biopsy and immunostaining performedImages:1. Title: Facial emmonsiosis lesion   Description: Crusted nodule at the left corner of mouth2. Title: Fungal Morphological Features in Skin Lesion Exudate and Biopsy Specimen   Description: A) Numerous oval yeast cells within histiocytes; extracellular yeast cells were rare (Wright's stain)   B) Numerous oval yeast cells within histiocytes and some narrow-based budding yeast cells; extracellular yeast cells were rare (Grocott methenamine silver stain)
final_diagnosis: Cutaneous disseminated Emmonsia pasteuriana infection with cytomegalovirus (CMV) enteritis
option_b: Cutaneous disseminated Emmonsia pasteuriana infection with cytomegalovirus (CMV) enteritis
reason: The case involves cutaneous nodules associated with a thermally dimorphic fungus, indicating a fungal infection, which falls under the specialty of Infectious Disease.

case_information: A 33-year-old white man presented with a 5-month history of a progressively necrotic plaque on the nose and scattered nodules on the extremities. The plaque first appeared as a small inflammatory papule on the left nostril. Shortly thereafter, the patient was hospitalized for multifocal pneumonia and treated for a methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus infection of his nose. Despite antibiotic therapy, the papule continued to grow and ulcerate and eventually became necrotic. One month before presentation, the patient began developing erythematous papules on his arms and legs. The papules enlarged and ulcerated. Some healed spontaneously with poxlike scars. He had no recent history of travel.
physical_examination: At admission, the patient was tachycardic and febrile to a temperature of 38.5°C. Physical examination revealed a necrotic plaque with surrounding erythema on the distal nose. A 1 × 1-cm crateriform papule with central necrosis was present on the left malar cheek. Multiple nodules with central, dry necrosis and areas of poxlike scarring were scattered across the extremities. Slight contractures of his fingers were also noted.
diagnostic_tests:
- Laboratory tests:
  - Routine laboratory testing revealed normocytic anemia (hemoglobin, 7.7 g/dL)
  - EBV load: 78,400 copies/mL
  - Negative results for bacterial and fungal cultures
  - Negative serologic screening for HIV
  - Negative autoantibody screen (including antinuclear and antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies)
  - Negative testing for Fanconi anemia

- Imaging studies:
  - Head CT: Soft-tissue mass encasing the nasal bone and extending into the right maxillary sinus and left nasal cavity
  - Chest CT: Bilateral pulmonary nodules
  - PET-CT: Involvement of lymph nodes and spleen

- Pathology:
  - Biopsy findings: Surface ulceration with angiocentric and angiodestructive infiltrate composed of atypical lymphocytes with increased mitotic figures
  - Immunohistochemistry: Positive for CD20, PAX-5, CD30; Negative for CD3 and CD56
  - EBER in situ hybridization: Positive with >50 EBER-positive cells per high-power field
  - Bone marrow biopsy showed involvement
final_diagnosis: Lymphomatoid granulomatosis grade III
reason: The patient's presentation, including necrotic lesions, lymphadenopathy, and biopsy findings suggestive of a lymphoproliferative disorder, indicates a likely malignancy, warranting evaluation by oncology.

case_information: A 66-year-old man with history of type 2 diabetes, hypertension, and dyslipidemia presented with a 3.1-cm left adrenal mass, detected on a CT scan during evaluation of bilateral lung infiltrates and chronic cough. He had no headache, palpitations, fatigue, muscle weakness, or weight change. His medications were glipizide, metformin, metoprolol, and atorvastatin. He had no history of fractures or osteoporosis.
physical_examination: Blood pressure 139/88 mm Hg, heart rate 92 beats/min, and body mass index 37.0. No purple striae, proximal muscle weakness or supraclavicular fat pads were present.
diagnostic_tests: - Imaging Studies:    CT scan showed a 3.1-cm left adrenal mass that was round and homogenous with CT attenuation of 24 Hounsfield units (HU)    Image Title: CT scan of adrenal mass    Image Description: Round, homogenous left adrenal mass measuring 3.1 cm  - Laboratory Tests:    - 1-mg overnight dexamethasone suppression test (DST): Cortisol between 1.9-5 μg/dL    - ACTH: Suppressed levels    - 24-hour urinary-free cortisol: 26 μg/dL (reference range: 3.5-45 μg/dL)    - DHEA-S: Reduced levels
final_diagnosis: Subclinical hypercortisolism due to adrenal incidentaloma
option_a: Adrenal adenoma with subclinical Cushing’s syndrome
option_d: Subclinical hypercortisolism due to adrenal incidentaloma
reason: The case involves an adrenal mass with hormonal evaluation indicating possible adrenal dysfunction, which falls under the domain of endocrinology.

case_information: A 47-year-old African American man with a medical history significant for hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and gastroesophageal reflux disease. He had been previously tried on various statins but experienced hip pain and elevated liver enzymes.
physical_examination: No specific physical examination findings were reported in the case.
diagnostic_tests: - Laboratory Tests (December 2013):    * Fasting lipid profile with LDL-C: 232 mg/dL (off lipid-lowering agents)      - Serial Laboratory Tests:    * June 2014: Direct LDL-C: 113 mg/dL    * October 2015: Direct LDL-C: 115 mg/dL    * December 2015: Calculated LDL-C: 170 mg/dL      - Additional Laboratory Tests (April & June 2016):    * Fasting lipid profiles    * Direct and calculated LDL-C measurements    * Apolipoprotein B (Apo B)    * Lipoprotein (a) [Lp(a)]      Table Reference: The case mentions a table showing lipid values demonstrating marked difference between direct and calculated LDL-C levels
final_diagnosis: Elevated Lipoprotein(a) causing discordance between direct and calculated LDL cholesterol measurements
option_b: Elevated Lipoprotein(a) causing discordance between direct and calculated LDL cholesterol measurements
reason: The case involves a patient with significant lipid abnormalities and a history of hypertension and diabetes, which are relevant to cardiovascular health.

case_information: A 69-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and stage IA estrogen receptor–positive and progesterone receptor–positive and ERBB/neu receptor–negative invasive ductal carcinoma of the left breast presented with blurry vision in both eyes. The patient had started receiving 1 mg of anastrozole daily 6 months prior to her presentation. She was not using any other notable medications, denied any recent changes to her regimen, and had never previously used tamoxifen.
physical_examination: Best-corrected visual acuity was 20/40 OD and 20/25 OS. Pupils were equal, round, and reactive without an afferent pupillary defect. Intraocular pressures were normal. Anterior segment examination was only notable for mild cataracts in both eyes. Fundus examination was notable for parafoveal shimmering golden crystalline deposits in the right and left eyes.
diagnostic_tests:
- Imaging studies:
  1. Fundus examination:
    Image Description: Parafoveal shimmering golden crystalline deposits in both eyes. The crystalline deposits did not display autofluorescence, suggesting that they were not lipofuscin granules.

  2. Spectral-domain optical coherence tomography:
    Image Description: Crystalline deposits located at the level of the outer plexiform layers with some extension into the inner nuclear area subfoveally.
final_diagnosis: Anastrozole-associated crystalline retinopathy
reason: The case involves a patient presenting with blurry vision and specific ocular findings, including crystalline deposits in the eyes, which are best evaluated and managed by an ophthalmologist.

case_information: A man in his 80s without a prior history of arrhythmia presented to the emergency department with cough and shortness of breath during the COVID-19 pandemic. He subsequently developed palpitations.
physical_examination: On arrival:- Temperature: Afebrile- Heart rate: 89 beats/min- Respiratory rate: 26 breaths/min - Blood pressure: 107/68 mm Hg- Jugular venous pressure: normal- Cardiac auscultation: Regular rate and rhythm without murmurs, rubs, or gallops- Pulmonary auscultation: Inspiratory crackles in bilateral bases of the lungs
diagnostic_tests: - Laboratory tests:  SARS-CoV-2 PCR test: Positive- ECG findings:  - Regular, narrow complex tachycardia with rate of 170 beats/min  - T waves in inferior leads terminate with negative deflection corresponding to P wave in lead V1  - Superiorly directed P waves (negative in leads II, III, and aVF)  - Long RP interval (RP interval > PR interval)  - Short P-wave duration, most evident in lead V1  - Echocardiogram:  Finding: Mild diastolic dysfunction- Images mentioned:  Image Title: Figure 1. Initial Electrocardiogram During the Episode of Palpitations  Image Title: Figure 2. RP Interval Examples
final_diagnosis: Atypical Atrioventricular Nodal Reentrant Tachycardia (Atypical AVNRT)
option_b: Atypical Atrioventricular Nodal Reentrant Tachycardia (Atypical AVNRT)
reason: The patient presents with palpitations and ECG findings indicative of arrhythmia, which falls under the expertise of cardiology.

case_information: A woman in her 80s presented with an 8-month history of a growing, painful tumor on her right buttock. The patient felt well otherwise and denied experiencing fevers, chills, sweats, weight loss, or malaise. Her medical history was notable for chronic kidney disease and genital herpes simplex virus (HSV). She reported no history of genital warts, HIV, or inflammatory bowel disease.
physical_examination: Physical examination findings revealed a 5 × 7-cm verrucous, exophytic tumor with scant yellow drainage on the right medial buttock extending to the perianal skin. Findings from the remaining skin examination were normal.
diagnostic_tests: - Bacterial Cultures: Superficial bacterial cultures were obtained from the lesion and grew methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. Microbial cultures were negative for deep fungal infection and acid-fast bacteria but positive for HSV type 2.- Biopsy and Histology:  Image Title: Clinical and Histological Images (Figure 1)  Image Description: A) Clinical image of verrucous tumor on right medial buttock  B) Hematoxylin-eosin stain showing hyperplastic epidermis with ulceration, necrosis, and dense inflammatory infiltrate  C) Hematoxylin-eosin stain showing plasma cells and focal multinucleated keratinocytes with gray-blue cytoplasm- Immunohistochemistry:  Image Title: Immunohistochemical Staining (Figure 2)  Image Description: Positive staining for herpes simplex virus types 1 and 2 within epithelial cells, including multinucleated keratinocytes
final_diagnosis: Herpes vegetans
option_b: Chronic herpetic ulcer with secondary bacterial infection (MRSA)
reason: The case involves a skin tumor with specific characteristics, including verrucous appearance and HSV involvement, which are primarily managed by dermatology.

case_information: A patient in their 40s presented to the emergency department with acute-onset breathlessness for 2 hours. The patient had chronic kidney disease and was receiving regular hemodialysis, but had missed their last 2 dialysis sessions. No history of chest pain, palpitation, or cough with expectoration.
physical_examination: - Pulse rate: 52 beats/min (bradycardia)- Blood pressure: 160/100 mm Hg- Respiratory system: Coarse crepitations on both lung fields
diagnostic_tests: - ECG Findings:  Image Title: 12-Lead Electrocardiogram  Image Description: Shows junctional escape rhythm with heart rate of 60 beats/min, coved ST-segment elevation of 2 mm with downsloping ST segment and T-wave inversion in V1, ST-segment elevation of 2 mm with saddleback type ST segment with T-wave inversion in lead V2. Other leads showed tall, peaked T waves with narrow base. Absent P waves and bradycardia noted.- Laboratory Tests:  - Electrolyte panel: Potassium value of 7.2 mEq/L
final_diagnosis: Brugada phenocopy induced by hyperkalemia
reason: The patient has chronic kidney disease and missed dialysis sessions, leading to hyperkalemia (high potassium level), which is critical in nephrology.

case_information: A woman in her 70s with a medical history of atrial fibrillation, asthma, gastroesophageal reflux disease, Schatzki ring status after multiple dilations, pulmonary hypertension, and hypothyroidism presented with a more than 10-year history of dysphagia. The patient reported difficulty swallowing dry and heavy-consistency foods. She denied odynophagia, otalgia, hematemesis, or hemoptysis. In the past, she had multiple esophagogastroduodenoscopies with dilations for her Schatzki ring that provided some relief; however, they did not completely resolve her symptoms.
physical_examination: Clinical and video swallow evaluation revealed hypertrophy of the cricopharyngeus muscle. During surgery, a palpable thick broad cricopharyngeus muscle was identified.
diagnostic_tests: - Imaging Studies:    1. Preoperative esophagographic imaging       Image Title: Preoperative barium swallow imaging       Image Description: Showing obvious hypertrophy of the cricopharyngeal muscle. Thumbprint sign with cricopharyngeal bar was present on esophagram.        2. Postoperative imaging       Image Title: Postoperative day 1 barium swallow imaging       Image Description: Showing no retained cricopharyngeal bar as well as no esophageal leak.  - Pathological Examination:    Histopathologic examination revealed:    - Nonnecrotizing granulomas and mononuclear inflammatory infiltrates in the endomysium    - Adipose tissue deposition    - Endomysial fibrosis    - Increased variation in muscle fiber size    - Increased internal nuclei    - Rare necrotic fibers    Special stains for acid-fast, fungal, and bacterial microorganisms were negative.
final_diagnosis: Granulomatous myositis of the cricopharyngeus muscle due to sarcoidosis
option_a: Inflammatory Myopathy (such as Inclusion Body Myositis)
option_d: Granulomatous myositis of the cricopharyngeus muscle due to sarcoidosis
reason: The case involves dysphagia related to a structural issue in the pharynx (hypertrophy of the cricopharyngeus muscle), which falls under the expertise of Otolaryngology.

case_information: A female patient receiving antiestrogen therapy experienced dry skin with associated erythema and pruritus. She carried a prescribed 385-mL bottle of ammonium lactate 12% cream for her condition while traveling.
physical_examination: Patient presented with dry skin, erythema, and pruritus.
diagnostic_tests: No specific diagnostic tests were performed as part of the medical evaluation.
final_diagnosis: Drug-induced skin xerosis secondary to antiestrogen therapy
option_d: Drug-induced skin xerosis secondary to antiestrogen therapy
reason: The patient is experiencing skin-related symptoms (dry skin, erythema, pruritus) which are best addressed by a dermatologist.

case_information: A White man in his 60s presented with a 2-month history of diplopia and pain. Medical history was significant for recurring forehead lesion, first excised 6 years prior to presentation. Initial histopathologic findings showed a Breslow thickness of 6 mm, 14 mitotic figures/mm2, no ulceration, and extensive perineural and intraneural invasion. The lesion recurred twice: two years prior to presentation (excised with negative margins) and eight months prior to presentation (excised with clear margins, followed by 48-Gy brachytherapy to the glabella).
physical_examination: Visual acuity was 20/20 bilaterally without afferent pupillary defect. Examination revealed left proptosis and resistance to globe retropulsion with edema, erythema, and ptosis of the left upper eyelid. Adduction was limited on the left, with associated strabismus and forehead anesthesia in the V1 division of the trigeminal nerve.
diagnostic_tests: - Imaging Studies:    1. MRI finding: Left superior orbit mass extending along the supraorbital nerve to the cavernous sinus, with indistinct borders and fat stranding       Image Title: T1-Weighted Coronal Magnetic Resonance Image of Orbit With Gadolinium Contrast       Image Description: Intense enhancement of the V1 branch of the left frontal nerve with associated fat stranding        - Pathological Examination:    1. Frontal nerve biopsy:       Image Title: Malignant Melanoma in a Nerve       Image Description: Cross section of nerve showing malignant cells with mitotic activity, effacing residual nerve axons, disrupted neuronal cells, and peritumoral and intratumoral lymphocytes
final_diagnosis: Neurotropic melanoma with orbital spread
option_a: Perineural spread of metastatic melanoma to the orbit
option_b: Malignant melanoma with perineural and orbital metastasis
reason: The case involves a recurrent malignant melanoma with neurological involvement, indicating a need for oncological assessment and management.

case_information: A woman in her mid-30s presented to the emergency department with chest pain and persistent weight loss. She had long-standing history complicated by cardiac arrests. Her weight was 40.5 kg, with a body mass index of 14.
physical_examination: Physical examination revealed:- Cachexia- Mild diffuse abdominal tenderness- Cardiac examination was unremarkable
diagnostic_tests: - Laboratory tests:  * Glucose: 40 mg/dL  * Serum potassium: 2.7 mEq/L   * Serum magnesium: 2.1 mg/dL  * Troponin T: <0.01 ng/mL- ECG findings:  Image Title: Initial Electrocardiogram  Image Description: Shows normal sinus rhythm at 81 beats/min, increased P-wave amplitude, diffuse ST depressions and T-wave inversions in leads II, III, aVF, and V3 through V6, ST-segment elevation in aVR and a prolonged QTc interval with TU wave fusion
final_diagnosis: Severe hypokalemia in the setting of anorexia nervosa
option_c: Severe hypokalemia in the setting of anorexia nervosa
option_d: Anorexia nervosa with severe malnutrition and electrolyte imbalance
reason: The patient presents with significant weight loss, hypoglycemia, and electrolyte imbalances, which suggest a possible endocrine disorder such as adrenal insufficiency or other metabolic issues.

case_information: A White man in his 50s presented with painful oral erosions that began 2 years before. Medical history included recurrent respiratory infections and diarrhea. A previous intestinal biopsy had shown unspecific findings and absence of apoptosis. He reported a 5-kg weight loss attributed to impaired intake due to oral lesions. He was being evaluated for a mediastinal mass detected during chest radiography performed for pneumonia.
physical_examination: Physical examination revealed whitish edematous lacy patches with erosions on the dorsal and lateral aspects of the tongue and buccal mucosa. Skin and nails were not involved.
diagnostic_tests: - Biopsy & Immunofluorescence:    - Lingual biopsy showed epidermal acanthosis with scattered necrotic keratinocytes, basal-layer vacuolation, and band-like lymphohistiocytic infiltrate    - Direct immunofluorescence showed fibrinogen deposition along basement membrane    - Indirect immunofluorescence testing (using monkey esophagus, salt-skin split, and rat bladder) was negative    - ELISA and immunoblot analysis negative for multiple antibodies  - Laboratory Tests:    - Normal liver function    - Negative for hepatitis B and C    - Decreased IgG serum level: 465 mg/dL (normal: 750-1600 g/L)    - Normal IgA and IgM levels    - Decreased total B lymphocyte count    - Increased CD8+ T count with inverted CD4:CD8 ratio  - Imaging:    - Positron emission tomography revealed a 10-cm hypercapturing extrapulmonary mass    - Surgical excision and histopathology of mediastinal mass showed type AB thymoma, Masaoka-Koga stage 2A  Images:    - Figure A: Lacy, white erosive lesions on the tongue    - Figure B: Epidermis with acanthosis, parakeratosis, necrotic keratinocytes, and dermal band lymphocytic infiltrate    - Figure C: Fibrogen deposition along the basement membrane    - Figure D: Hypercapturing, heterogeneous mass in right anterior hemithorax
final_diagnosis: Good syndrome
reason: The patient presents with painful oral erosions and lesions in the oral cavity, which falls under the expertise of Otolaryngology. Additionally, the mediastinal mass and respiratory history may also involve ENT considerations.

case_information: A man in his 40s presented with a 10-year history of pruritic lesions on the scrotum and buttock. He was previously treated at a local clinic with little improvement. He had no relevant medical history and no family history of similar skin problems.
physical_examination: Scattered, well-defined, annular gray hyperkeratotic plaques with an atrophic center and a slightly elevated edge on the scrotum, buttock, groin, and intergluteal cleft. There was no inguinal adenopathy.
diagnostic_tests: {'Laboratory Tests': 'Routine blood work, including blood biochemistry, syphilis serologies, and HIV testing, were normal or negative.', 'Histopathological Examination': {'Specimens': 'Two specimens taken from the scrotum and buttock', 'Findings': 'Revealed hyperkeratosis, irregular papillomatosis, parakeratotic columns (cornoid lamella) overlying dyskeratotic keratinocytes, and hypogranulosis with a perivascular infiltration of lymphocytes in the dermis', 'Images': {'Figure 1A': 'Clinical photograph showing scattered, well-defined, annular gray hyperkeratotic plaques with an atrophic center with a slightly elevated edge on the scrotum, buttock, groin, and intergluteal cleft', 'Figure 1B': 'Biopsy findings showing hyperkeratosis, irregular papillomatosis, parakeratotic column (cornoid lamella), and several dyskeratotic keratinocytes in the epidermal invagination with hypogranulosis and perivascular infiltration of lymphocytes in the dermis (hematoxylin-eosin)'}}}
final_diagnosis: Genital porokeratosis (GP)
reason: The case involves pruritic skin lesions with specific histopathological findings indicative of a dermatological condition.

case_information: An adolescent girl presented with an asymptomatic slightly reddish verrucous plaque on the right temple. The skin lesion was nail sized when first noticed 1½ years earlier, then gradually developed over the 8 months prior to presentation. The patient denied any associated fevers, weight loss, or night sweats.
physical_examination: Physical examination revealed a slightly reddish verrucous mass with translucent papules and plaques on the right temple, about 5 cm in diameter, with surface hemorrhagic crust in the side adjacent to right eyebrow arch. The lesion was nontender with no purulent discharge and no severe necrotic changes. There was no hepatosplenomegaly or superficial lymphadenopathy.
diagnostic_tests: - Laboratory tests: Blood cell counts, urinalysis, and kidney and hepatic panels revealed no abnormalities.- Imaging studies:  - Cerebral CT and MRI findings: Skin thickening and a soft-tissue mass in the right frontotemporal region near the orbit  - Chest CT and abdominal ultrasonography: No evidence of metastases- Histopathology:  Image Title: Figure B  Image Description: Papillomatous epidermal hyperplasia, edema of dermal papillae, and neoplastic infiltration consisting of small round blue cells with alternating areas of dense and loose cellularity  Image Title: Figure C  Image Description: Small, round blue cells in the dermis with round, fusiform, or oval hyperchromatic nuclei, conspicuous nucleoli, and scant cytoplasm  Image Title: Figure D  Image Description: Tumor cells positive for MyoD1- Immunohistochemistry: Positive for MyoD1, myogenin, vimentin, and desmin. Negative for myeloperoxidase, CD45, CK, Ki-67, CD31, CD34, CD1a, CD117, and SOX-10.
final_diagnosis: Primary cutaneous embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma
reason: The case involves a skin lesion with specific characteristics and histopathological findings that suggest a dermatological condition.

case_information: A 48-year-old man with a 17-year history of treatment for proliferative diabetic retinopathy in his left eye. A small, nonpigmented vitreous cyst was noticed growing from the tip of a stalk in his left eye. Over 8 years, the cyst expanded while remaining tethered. Initially asymptomatic with visual acuity of 20/25 OS, it eventually began blocking central vision. The patient had no other ocular history except for treated PDR. Systemically, the patient had no other diseases.
physical_examination: - Anterior chamber examination revealed pseudophakia- Intraocular pressure was within normal levels- Posterior segment showed treated PDR- The cyst had mild gray and yellow coloration, was translucent, had a smooth surface, and was spherical in shape- Cyst was tethered with minimal motion during ocular movement- Visual acuity decreased to 20/40 OS when cyst became symptomatic, associated with a central scotoma
diagnostic_tests: - Imaging studies:  Image Title: Color fundus photographs showing development and growth of vitreous cyst  Image Description A: Left eye with retinal pigmented epithelial atrophy due to treatment, with a small stalk, showing absence of cyst  Image Description B: Same eye years later showing new small, nonpigmented, gray and yellow vitreous cyst, tethered at the tip  Image Description C: Progressive growth of the cyst at 5 years  Image Description D: Progressive growth of the cyst at 8 years
final_diagnosis: Acquired nonpigmented vitreous cyst associated with regressed neovascularization of the disc (NVD) from proliferative diabetic retinopathy
option_a: Acquired nonpigmented vitreous cyst associated with regressed neovascularization of the disc (NVD) from proliferative diabetic retinopathy
option_b: Fibrovascular proliferation cyst associated with diabetic retinopathy
option_c: Secondary vitreous cyst related to treated proliferative diabetic retinopathy
reason: The case involves a patient with a vitreous cyst affecting vision, which falls under the specialty of ophthalmology.

case_information: A woman in her 30s was first noted to have the apex beat located on the right side of her chest at 2 years of age by her mother. She was referred for a cardiac evaluation after an electrocardiogram performed on a routine health evaluation. The patient did not have chest wall deformity.
physical_examination: The maximal cardiac impulse was noted to be in the right seventh interspace. A pathological diastolic murmur was detected at apex and the third and fourth intercostals at the right side of the sternum.
diagnostic_tests: - ECG findings:  - Initial ECG showed P wave was positive in leads I and II, and negative in lead aVR  - PR interval was 140 milliseconds  - QRS duration was prolonged (140 milliseconds) with slurred R waves in leads V1 through V6  - Repeated ECG with relocated lead electrodes:  - Shows rS pattern in lead V1 and slurred R waves in leads V5 and V6- Transthoracic echocardiography findings:  - Heart located in right hemithorax  - Right atrium and right ventricle on right side  - Left atrium and left ventricle on left side  - Mitral valve stenosis  - Aortic valve insufficiency   - Enlargement of left atrium and both ventriclesImage Titles and Descriptions:1. Figure 1: Initial Electrocardiogram on Presentation2. Figure 2: Electrocardiogram After Correction3. Figure 3: Anatomical Diagrams of the Normal Heart, Mirror-Image Dextrocardia, and Dextroversion
final_diagnosis: Dextroversion with left bundle branch block
option_a: Isolated Dextrocardia with Complex Congenital Heart Disease
option_d: Dextroversion with left bundle branch block
reason: The case involves a cardiac evaluation with findings of dextrocardia, valve abnormalities, and specific ECG changes, which are all related to cardiology.

case_information: A female teenage high school student presented with fatigue, recurrent sinus infections, migraines, and anemia. She had one prior episode of immune thrombocytopenic purpura (which required intravenous immunoglobulin treatment), with negative autoimmune workup results. She experienced episodic bouts of abdominal pain since childhood, initially diagnosed as irritable bowel syndrome, with recent colonoscopy results demonstrating collagenous colitis. No family history of autoimmune disorders or chronic infections was reported.

case_information: A man in his 50s presented to the emergency department with 1 hour of acute, severe precordial chest pain radiating to his left arm, accompanied by sweating and nausea. case_information: A patient in their 50s presented with recurrent abdominal pain and syncope after drinking alcohol, with symptoms persisting for 2 years but worsening on admission. The symptoms usually occurred 6-20 hours after alcohol ingestion and lasted 5-10 minutes. Syncope occurred only after large alcohol intake. Past medical history included hypertension diagnosed 3 months prior. Social history notable for smoking and alcohol overconsumption (250g/week) for about 20 years.
physical_examination: No specific physical examination findings were documented in the case report.
diagnostic_tests:
- Laboratory Tests:
  - High-sensitivity troponin I: 0.01 ng/mL (normal)
  - Serum potassium: 4.6 mEq/L (normal)

- ECG/Holter Findings:
  Image Title: ECG Recording A
  Image Description: High-degree atrioventricular block and premature ventricular contractions. ST segments elevated 4-6 mm in leads II, III and aVF, with ST depression in leads V2-V6

  Image Title: ECG Recording B
  Image Description: Sinus rhythm with short bursts of ventricular tachycardia. Widespread ST-segment elevations (4-15 mm) in leads II, III, aVF, and V2-V6

- Coronary Angiography:
  Results showed 10% stenosis in proximal left anterior descending artery (LAD) and right coronary artery (RCA). No stenosis in left main and circumflex coronary artery
final_diagnosis: Alcohol-induced Prinzmetal variant angina
reason: The patient's recurrent abdominal pain and syncope after alcohol ingestion suggest a gastrointestinal issue, possibly related to alcohol-induced pancreatitis or liver dysfunction, which falls under Gastroenterology.

case_information: A woman in her 20s with a history of biopsy-proven psoriasis and juvenile dermatomyositis (DM) presented for management of worsening skin condition in 2018, at a time when her juvenile DM had been in remission for several years. Her DM had remained stable during treatment with anti-TNF and anti-IL-12/23 medications. After starting new medication, she described fatigue, difficulty picking up her child, and climbing stairs.

case_information: A woman in her 30s presented with a 15-year history of generalized asymptomatic papules on her body. case_information: A man in his 50s presented with new and progressive satellite lesions while undergoing pembrolizumab therapy. Two years earlier, he had undergone a wide local excision with graft repair for a left posterior auricular scalp lesion. An incidentally resected lymph node was found to be focally involved, with no evidence of distant metastatic disease. Within months, multiple unresectable satellite lesions appeared. He received 4 cycles of ipilimumab, followed by a second wide local excision when new lesions appeared. Additional satellite lesions developed and he began pembrolizumab therapy, but after 5 cycles, local progression occurred in the satellite lesions.
physical_examination: Multiple satellite lesions were present on the left posterior auricular scalp area. After treatment, clinically regressed lesions with persistent black pigmentation were noted.
diagnostic_tests: - Histopathology:    Initial findings: Incidentally resected lymph node showed focal involvement        Post-treatment biopsy findings:    - H&E sections showed intense mixed superficial and deep dermal inflammatory infiltrate composed of numerous neutrophils, histiocytes, eosinophils, and lymphocytes    - Immunostaining results:      * SOX-10 and MART-1: Highlighted normal melanocytes in basal layer of epidermis only      * CD163 and myeloperoxidase: Highlighted histiocytes and neutrophils respectively        Images referenced:    Figure 1. Title: Recurrent Melanoma Lesions on the Left Posterior Auricular Scalp Before and After T-VEC Therapy    Figure 2. Title: Histopathologic Findings of T-VEC–Treated Melanoma Lesions    Description: Shows complete tumor regression and neutrophil-rich mixed inflammation; MART-1 immunostain confirms complete tumor regression
final_diagnosis: Stage IIIC (T4aN3) melanoma with satellite metastases
option_a: Stage IIIC (T4aN3) melanoma with satellite metastases
reason: The case involves a patient with recurrent melanoma and treatment with immunotherapy, indicating a need for oncology expertise.

case_information: A man in his 60s presented with painful swelling of the proximal nail folds, dripping of blood from his fingernails and toenails for the last year, and occasional pus discharge. - Hyperkeratosis
- Hypergranulosis
- Acanthosis
- Basal cell degeneration
- Numerous apoptotic keratinocytes in the epidermis
- Dense bandlike lymphohistiocytic infiltrate in the papillary dermis

Description: Shows hyperkeratosis, hypergranulosis, acanthosis, basal cell degeneration, Civatte bodies in the epidermis, and dense bandlike lymphohistiocytic infiltrate in the upper dermis

case_information: A woman in her 50s presented with a large annular erythematous plaque on her lower back that appeared in June (1 month previously) and had centrifugally expanded. She complained about mild pruritus that had not responded to conventional antihistamine therapy or topical steroids. No history of arthropod bite or travel outside Spain. 20-year history of similar annular plaques recurring on the trunk every summer and spontaneously resolving by autumn. Lesions never appeared on face, hands, or feet. No relation to hobbies or skin care products.
physical_examination: Large, 35-cm semicircular erythematous plaque on lower back with central clearing and a distinctive, well-demarcated papular border.
diagnostic_tests: - Histopathologic examination: No epidermal changes, mild edema of the papillary dermis, and superficial sparse perivascular inflammatory infiltrate composed mainly of lymphocytes and few neutrophils. Periodic acid–Schiff staining negative for fungal microorganisms.- Direct immunofluorescence: Negative for IgG, IgM, IgA, complement, and fibrin deposition.- Laboratory tests: Complete blood cell count and biochemical studies showed no significant findings. Serological analyses including Borrelia burgdorferi antibodies were negative.- Images:  Image A Title: Large erythematous semicircular plaque  Image A Description: Large erythematous semicircular plaque with central postinflammatory hyperpigmentation on the lower back    Image B Title: Histopathologic examination  Image B Description: Absence of epidermal changes, mild edema of the papillary dermis, and a superficial sparse perivascular inflammatory infiltrate    Image C Title: Inflammatory infiltrate composition  Image C Description: Inflammatory infiltrate composed mainly by lymphocytes and few neutrophils    Image D Title: Follow-up image  Image D Description: Clinical resolution in October
final_diagnosis: Erythema papulosa semicircularis recidivans (EPSR)
reason: The case presents a skin condition characterized by annular erythematous plaques, which is a typical presentation for dermatological issues. The history of recurrent plaques and the histopathological findings further support a dermatological diagnosis.

case_information: A 62-year-old man with hypertension and left superior oblique palsy underwent inferior oblique recession under retrobulbar anesthesia using lidocaine, 2%, delivered by a 25-gauge 1.5-in needle. After removal of the patch the next day, the patient noticed substantial vision loss.

case_information: A 78-year-old woman with no prior medical history, including no autoimmune disease. In February 2010, she was diagnosed with a stage IIA melanoma on the left leg (Breslow thickness, 2.5 mm; no ulceration, negative sentinel lymph node). In June 2019, she developed an iliac lymph node metastasis. After lymph node dissection, she received nivolumab treatment from September 2019 to September 2020. In February 2021, she presented with marked skin thickening and painful swelling of the limbs.
physical_examination: Patient presented with painful cutaneous sclerosis on the limbs, flanks, and abdomen (pain visual analog scale: 8 of 10; Rodnan score: 33 of 51). Multiple plaque-type lesions with ulcerated areas were observed. Physical examination revealed skin thickening.
diagnostic_tests: - Laboratory Tests:    * Blood tests showed eosinophilia (1200/mm3)    * Autoantibody panel was negative    * Cytokines assay showed:      - TNF-α: 30.1 pg/mL (normal <10.85 pg/mL)      - IL-8: 30 pg/mL (normal <28.75 pg/mL)      - IL-6: 10.3 pg/mL (normal <5.96 pg/mL)  - Imaging Studies:    * PET scan showed no signs of fasciitis    * CT scan revealed an unresectable iliac lymph node without distant metastasis  - Pathological Examination:    * First skin biopsy: Showed histiocytic and neutrophilic reticular dermal infiltrate with slight edema    * Second skin biopsy: Revealed thickening of upper dermis with broad sclerotic collagen bundles in horizontal pattern, lymphocytic perivascular infiltrate, and neutrophils diffusing within collagen bundles. Blood vessel linings were thickened and hyalinized.
final_diagnosis: Immune checkpoint inhibitor-induced generalized morphea
reason: The patient has a history of melanoma and presents with skin thickening and painful swelling, which may indicate progression or a new malignancy related to her previous cancer.

Image Title: Computed Tomographic Image Without Contrast      Image Description: A) Coronal view of right temporal bone showing middle ear opacification, cochlea dysplasia, and no evidence of tegmen defect. B) Axial view showing malformed cochlear and vestibular dysplasia.        - Auditory Tests:      - Initial ABR: Moderate sensorineural hearing loss on left side and severe sensorineural hearing loss on right      - Follow-up ABR (1 year post-surgery): Mild sensorineural hearing loss on left side and severe sensorineural hearing loss on right

case_information: A healthy, immunocompetent 30-year-old man undergoing basic military training presented with a 4-day history of a progressive vesiculopustular eruption of the anterior neck and chin. The patient denied symptoms of pruritus, burning, or fever at time of presentation. He had not received the smallpox vaccination but had engaged in simulated unarmed combat with individuals who had recently been vaccinated. Medical history was noncontributory, and the patient was not taking any medications. During hospitalization, the patient developed fevers to 39°C, progressive edema of the face, and anterior cervical lymphadenopathy.
physical_examination: More than 2 dozen monomorphic, broad-based folliculocentric pustules with central umbilication, overlying serum crust, and surrounding erythema and edema of the anterior neck, chin, and inferior cheeks.
diagnostic_tests: - Histopathologic examination (Punch biopsy):     - Demonstrated viral changes to the epidermis with ballooning degeneration of keratinocytes with intracytoplasmic inclusions (Guarnieri bodies) and a brisk lymphocytic and neutrophilic infiltrate    - PCR Test:    - Confirmed presence of vaccinia virus      - Electron Microscopy:    - Demonstrated viral particles within the Guarnieri bodies      - Images:    Figure 1 Title: Clinical Findings    Description: Vesiculopustules with central umbilication in the beard area at time of presentation        Figure 2 Title: Histopathologic Findings From Lesional Skin of the Right Cheek    Description: Shows epidermal necrosis, intraepidermal edema, ballooning degeneration, necrotic keratinocytes, neutrophilic infiltrate, and Guarnieri bodies within keratinocytes
final_diagnosis: Sycosis vaccinatum
reason: The case presents a skin condition characterized by a vesiculopustular eruption and histopathological findings indicative of a viral infection, which falls under the expertise of dermatology.

case_information: A 3-month-old boy presented with multiple cutaneous red papules first noticed at birth. case_information: A man in his 70s presented with a persistent eruption of 5 years' duration. Repeat molecular studies showed no evidence of clonal rearrangement.- Pathological findings:  First biopsy: Dense infiltrate of atypical CD4+ small to medium-sized lymphocytes in the upper dermis admixed with eosinophils and plasma cells. Epidermotropism was not identified.  Second biopsy: Similar to prior findings, but with more dense and atypical infiltrate showing epidermotropism.- Images:  Figure 1 Title: Clinical Presentation  Figure 1 Description: Multiple smooth, firm plaques and nodules on the superior buttocks and intergluteal cleft.    Figure 2 Title: Histopathological Findings  Figure 2A Description: Scanning view shows dense infiltrate filling the papillary dermis and extending into the reticular dermis  Figure 2B Description: Higher power shows dense, atypical infiltrate of small to medium-sized lymphocytes

option_c: Cutaneous pseudolymphoma arising as Wolf's post-herpetic isotopic response

case_information: A 68-year-old man presented with progressive painless red eye and blurred vision for 2 months. case_information: A man in his 60s with a history of hypertension presented to the emergency department with acute chest pain that had begun 30 minutes prior to arrival, which he described as 'an intense pressure radiating to the back.'
physical_examination: Blood pressure recordings were 150/90 mm Hg and 157/91 mm Hg in his right and left arms, respectively. There was no jugular venous distention or pedal edema.

  • Troponin I level: within normal limits

- ECG Findings:
  Image Title: Electrocardiographic Findings
  Image Description: Initial ECG showed left anterior hemiblock, ST-segment elevation in leads I, aVL, and V1 to V6, ST-segment depression in leads II, III, and aVF. Prominent J points and J waves in precordial leads. J point in lead V1 higher than R wave. Repeat ECG after 15 minutes showed sinus bradycardia and right bundle-branch block.

- Imaging Studies:

  • Computed tomography angiography of chest: revealed type B aortic intramural hematoma (involving only the descending aorta)
final_diagnosis: Type B aortic intramural hematoma-induced coronary artery spasm

case_information: A young girl presented with a history of chronic, unilateral middle ear effusion that was treated with a pressure equalization (PE) tube by an outside otolaryngologist. She had persistent otorrhea that did not improve with multiple courses of ototopical antibiotics.
physical_examination: On examination, there was serous drainage from the left PE tube, and the external ear canal was mildly erythematous but otherwise normal appearing. Endoscopic examination revealed a well-circumscribed, flesh-colored, hairy mass in the cartilaginous eustachian tube.

case_information: A woman in her 40s presented with unilateral rhinorrhea, metallic taste, headache, neck stiffness, and photophobia. Medical history was notable for idiopathic intracranial hypertension and removal of nasal polyps over 20 years before presentation.
physical_examination: Physical examination revealed clear rhinorrhea from the right side. Flexible nasopharyngoscopy revealed a mass in the right anterior middle meatus, but did not identify the source of the fluid.

case_information: A man in his 40s with hypertension was brought to the emergency department after becoming unresponsive during descent on a commercial flight. He was alert and oriented by emergency medical services evaluation and in the emergency department. He had no recollection of the event, with history notable only for more than usual alcohol use the 2 days prior, including drinking just prior to boarding the plane.
physical_examination: - Alert and oriented- Normal heart rate and blood pressure- Jugular venous pressure less than 5 cm H2O

case_information: A 16-year-old male with chromosome 18q deletion and well-controlled epilepsy presented after four days of fever and one generalised seizure at home. Although he had no respiratory symptoms, his mother was ill with a cough. Patient's medical history included a normal echocardiogram from 2016 done for evaluation of a possible atrial septal defect, which showed no abnormal cardiac anatomy and normal cardiac function.
physical_examination: The patient presented with hemodynamic shock requiring:- Intubation- Intravenous crystalloid fluids (>40 mL/kg)- Intravenous epinephrine infusion (0.4 μg/kg per min)- Intravenous stress-dose hydrocortisone (100 mg)

case_information: A 44-year-old previously healthy man suddenly became confused and began to sweat heavily on a domestic flight approximately 10 minutes after departure. He vomited, collapsed, and lost consciousness. After an emergency landing, the man was admitted to the toxicology unit of a local hospital approximately two hours after symptom onset. The patient was later transferred to Charité-Universitätsmedizin Berlin at the request of his family.
physical_examination: Initial examination at transfer showed:- Bradycardia (44 beats per minute)- Hypothermia (34.4°C)- Wide pupils non-reactive to light- Intermittent myoclonic movements under sedationSubsequent examination at Charité showed:- Mild bradycardia (51 bpm, declining to 33 bpm)- Hypersalivation- Hypothermia (33.5°C)- Increased diaphoresis- Small pupils not reactive to light- Decreased brainstem reflexes- Hyperactive deep tendon reflexes- Pyramidal signs
diagnostic_tests: Laboratory Tests:- Decreased levels of butyrylcholinesterase in plasma- Increased levels of amylase, lipase, high-sensitivity troponin T, and sodium in plasma- Complete inhibition of acetylcholinesterase in red blood cells- Drug screening identified several drugs including atropineImaging Studies:- Cranial CT scan: within normal ranges- MRI scan: within normal rangesOther Tests:- Cerebrospinal fluid analysis: within normal ranges- Short-latency somatosensory evoked potentials: within normal ranges- Plasma neuron-specific enolase concentration: within normal ranges- Electroencephalogram: consistent with sedation- Electrophysiological examinations showed:  - Repetitive responses after single supramaximal electrical stimulus  - Decrement-increment response pattern at frequencies of 10 Hz or greater  - Prolonged variation in action potential timing (jitter) on single-fiber electromyography
final_diagnosis: Severe poisoning with a Novichok nerve agent (organophosphorus nerve agent)
option_a: Cholinergic crisis due to other acetylcholinesterase inhibitors
option_d: Severe poisoning with a Novichok nerve agent (organophosphorus nerve agent)
reason: The patient's symptoms and examination findings suggest a neurological issue, particularly with signs of altered consciousness, bradycardia, and myoclonic movements, which are indicative of a central nervous system problem.

case_information: A 24-day-old female neonate was admitted to the paediatric cardiac intensive care unit. She was born at term with a birthweight of 3.75 kg to a mother with a history of RT-PCR-positive, mild COVID-19 at 31 weeks gestation. The mother was RT-PCR-negative at delivery. Following an uncomplicated vaginal delivery, the neonate required supportive care for 5 days in a neonatal intensive care unit for mild tachypnoea and was subsequently discharged home with normal clinical, radiological, and laboratory parameters. She stayed well at home until day 22 of life when she required admission to a local hospital with heart failure and systemic hypoperfusion. There was no preceding history of fever, rash, loose stools, abdominal distention, lethargy, or seizures.
physical_examination: Patient was afebrile, drowsy, tachycardic (heart rate: 160 beats per minute), hypotensive (mean blood pressure: 25 mm Hg), and tachypnoeic (respiratory rate: 55 breaths per minute), with chest retractions, oxygen saturation of 97% on supplemental oxygen, cool peripheries, and delayed capillary refill. The precordium was hyperdynamic, with no cardiac murmurs; the chest was clear. Hepatomegaly was present. Neither neurological nor musculoskeletal abnormalities nor dysmorphisms were noted. Erythema was noted at pressure points—over the occiput and at bilateral gluteal regions; no other skin or mucosal lesions were present.
diagnostic_tests:
- Laboratory Tests:
  • Cardiac markers:
    - N-terminal-pro-B-type natriuretic peptide: 157,000 pg/mL
    - Creatine kinase myocardial band: 14.7 ng/mL
    - Troponin T: 1.23 ng/mL
  • Liver function:
    - Aspartate aminotransferase: 2240 IU/L
    - Alanine aminotransferase: 866 IU/L
  • Renal function:
    - Blood urea: 75 mg/dL
    - Serum creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL
  • Inflammatory markers:
    - Serum ferritin: 56,400 ng/mL
    - Serum lactate dehydrogenase: 6280 U/L
    - C-reactive protein: 6.5 mg/L
    - D-Dimer: 20 μg/mL
  • Complete blood count:
    - Leucocyte count: 16,400 cells per microlitre (75% neutrophils)
    - Platelet count: 185,000 cells per microlitre
  • Antibody testing:
    - Maternal SARS-CoV-2 IgG titre: 20.11
    - Neonatal SARS-CoV-2 IgG titre: 10.00
    - IgM antibodies: Not detected

- Imaging Studies:
  • Electrocardiogram: Showed sinus rhythm
  • Chest X-ray: Showed cardiomegaly with normal lung fields
  • Echocardiogram: Showed severe biventricular dysfunction with left ventricular ejection fraction of 10% and global hypokinesia. Coronary arteries were normal in origin and luminal dimensions but appeared prominent and hyperechoic
  • Cranial ultrasound: No intracranial bleeding
final_diagnosis: Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome in Children (MIS-C) following prenatal COVID-19 exposure
option_a: Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome in Children (MIS-C) following prenatal COVID-19 exposure
option_b: Neonatal multisystem inflammatory syndrome (MIS-N) associated with maternal SARS-CoV-2 exposure
option_d: Neonatal multisystem inflammatory syndrome (MIS-N) associated with perinatal SARS-CoV-2 exposure
reason: The case involves a neonate with heart failure and severe biventricular dysfunction, which are primarily cardiac issues requiring evaluation and management by a cardiology specialist.

case_information: A 23-year-old woman presented with a 10-day history of vomiting, myalgia, and upper abdominal pain. Three days before presentation, she received clarithromycin from her general practitioner without improvement. Two days later, she developed jaundice and pruritus. Medical history includes ulcerative colitis with a pan-proctocolectomy and end ileostomy. She took no regular medication, rarely drank alcohol, and had no history of travel abroad or recent blood transfusions. On the third day of hospital admission, she developed bilateral parotitis and an itchy maculopapular morbilliform rash across her back and torso, which rapidly spread to the proximal aspects of all four limbs.
physical_examination: Patient was jaundiced, with fever (38.0°C) and tachycardia (120 beats per minute). Other vital signs were normal. She had tenderness in the upper abdomen, but neither the liver nor spleen was palpable, and she had no signs of chronic liver disease. The stoma was pink and healthy. Oropharyngeal examination was normal, and she had no lymphadenopathy or organomegaly.
diagnostic_tests:
Laboratory Tests:
- ALT: 374 U/L (normal 10–36 U/L)
- ALP: 326 U/L (normal 30–130 U/L)
- Bilirubin: 108 μmol/L (normal <21 μmol/L)
- C-reactive protein: 7.2 mg/L (normal <5 mg/L)
- Haemoglobin: 151 g/L (normal 120–160 g/L)
- White cell count: 18.1 × 10⁹ per L (normal 3.9–11.1 × 10⁹ per L)
- Lymphocytes: 14.48 × 10⁹ per L (normal 1.0–3.2 × 10⁹ per L)

Imaging Studies:
1. Transabdominal ultrasound:
- Thick-walled gallbladder with multiple stones
- No intrahepatic or proximal extrahepatic biliary duct dilatation
- Enlarged spleen measuring >12 cm

2. MRCP:
- No evidence of choledocholithiasis
- Confirmed splenomegaly

Serological Tests:
- Positive glandular fever screen
- Negative EBV nuclear antigen IgG
- Positive EBV viral capsid IgG antibody
- Positive EBV viral capsid IgM antibody
final_diagnosis: Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) hepatitis
option_d: Acute Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) infection / Infectious Mononucleosis
reason: The patient presents with jaundice, abdominal pain, and elevated liver enzymes, indicating a potential liver or biliary issue, which falls under Gastroenterology/Hepatology.

case_information: A 31-year-old man with no medical history of note was buried under snow during a ski accident at 2500 m above sea level. His hand remained exposed, leading to quick discovery and excavation after 3-5 minutes. The patient never lost consciousness and recalled being unable to breathe due to compacted snow blocking his airways. When uncovered, he was cyanotic but conscious and able to clear his airway himself. The patient denied hitting any rocks or objects during burial.
physical_examination: Initial examination revealed:- Fully oriented patient- Peripheral and central cyanosis- Tachypnoea- Frank haemoptysis- No injuries on Advanced Trauma Life Support body check- No pain on thoracic compression- No oral bleeding wounds- Bilateral rales and crackles on pulmonary auscultation- Oxygen saturation: 93% on 100% oxygen via mask- Normal heart rate and blood pressure

final_diagnosis: Negative pressure pulmonary oedema with pulmonary haemorrhage

option_d: Non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema (avalanche lung/negative pressure pulmonary edema)
reason: The patient presents with respiratory distress, cyanosis, and pulmonary infiltrations, indicating a primary issue with the lungs.

case_information: A 17-year-old Thai woman, 33 weeks and 4 days into her first pregnancy with no significant medical history, presented to the emergency room with a one-day history of fever, cough, and sore throat. She was carrying twins with estimated body weights of 1900 g and 2000 g at the time of presentation. The patient had no vaccination history during pregnancy.

case_information: A 32-year-old woman presented with a 2-week history of back and loin pain, heaviness in her thighs, intermittent fever, and rigors. Medical history included trigeminal neuralgia and pervasive anxiety, for which she had recently started quetiapine.
physical_examination: Temperature was 39°C. No other abnormal physical findings were noted.

final_diagnosis: Peripheral T-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma

Past medical history also includes previous central lines inserted on both sides.

case_information: A woman in her mid-60s presented to the emergency department with sudden, dull left flank pain, rated 8 of 10, radiating to the lateral abdomen and accompanied by nausea. Medical history included hypertension, basal cell carcinoma in remission, and an autoimmune condition diagnosed 16 years ago. Patient had been on long-term azathioprine therapy (125 mg daily, later reduced to 100 mg daily) and sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim. Four years after initial diagnosis, she experienced unintentional weight loss, fever, polyarthralgia, and fatigue.

case_information: A 33-year-old Hispanic bisexual man with HIV diagnosed 8 years prior (not receiving antiretroviral therapy) presented to the emergency department with dysuria and penile discharge. case_information: A 74-year-old woman presented with 1 week of impaired vision. Medical history included metastatic neuroendocrine tumor (primary lung), treated with combination immunotherapy (nivolumab and ipilimumab) for 7 months, then transitioned to nivolumab monotherapy due to immune-mediated grade 2 diarrhea.

Temporal Artery Doppler:   Description: Bilateral circumferential wall thickening (halo sign)3. case_information: An 83-year-old man presented with months of fatigue and a 20-pound unintentional weight loss. Medical history includes: two instances of colon cancer treated with surgery and 5-fluorouracil in the 1970s, squamous cell carcinoma of the right palatine tonsil treated with radiation, squamous cell carcinoma and basal cell carcinoma of the skin. Family history notable for various cancers without clear genetic cause. Initial laboratory evaluation revealed new pancytopenia, which later showed recovery of all cell lines.
physical_examination: No specific physical examination findings were detailed in the case report.

case_information: A 94-year-old woman with diastolic heart failure, atrial fibrillation, chronic iron deficiency anemia (baseline hemoglobin level approximately 100 g/L), and a prior stroke was hospitalized due to cellulitis and myositis. Initial treatment included intravenous piperacillin-tazobactam, vancomycin, and linezolid. On discharge, oral linezolid was continued for 4 more days to complete a 3-week course.
physical_examination: Patient was afebrile and hemodynamically stable. Examination showed scattered bruises without petechiae, bilateral lower extremity edema, and mild induration of the right calf without erythema.
diagnostic_tests: - Laboratory Tests:    Initial discharge labs: leukocyte count 5.2 × 10⁹/L, hemoglobin 92 g/L, platelet count 171 × 10⁹/L    One week post-discharge: leukocyte count 3.9 × 10⁹/L, hemoglobin 81 g/L, platelet count 38 × 10⁹/L    5 days later: platelet count decreased to 17 × 10⁹/L    Emergency department: leukocyte count 3.8 × 10⁹/L, hemoglobin 76 g/L, platelet count 17 × 10⁹/L    Additional tests: Low reticulocyte count, normal vitamin B12 and folate levels      - Blood Smear:    Showed pencil cells without blasts, tear drop cells, or dysplastic cells      - Figure Information:    Title: Leukocyte count, hemoglobin level, and platelet count trends over time

reason: The case presents significant hematological issues, including chronic iron deficiency anemia and a critical drop in platelet count, indicating a need for hematological evaluation and management.

case_information: A 53-year-old man with a history of stage III right-sided renal cell carcinoma after right radical nephrectomy presented with extensive metastatic recurrence to the liver, bone, and abdominal soft tissue five years later. DNA sequencing of tumor cells revealed TFEB translocation. The patient received debulking surgery of an L1 bone metastatic site and completed adjuvant radiation therapy. Two days after his first nivolumab infusion, he presented with progressive widespread petechial rash and purpura in his bilateral lower extremities. He reported mild leg discomfort and generalized fatigue without pain or pruritus.
physical_examination: Physical examination revealed progressive widespread petechial rash and purpura in bilateral lower extremities. No signs or symptoms of systemic involvement were noted.
diagnostic_tests: - Laboratory Tests:    * Elevated acute-phase reactants including erythrocyte sedimentation rate (75 mm/h), C-reactive protein (13.3 mg/dL), and ferritin (504 ng/mL)    * Positive anti-nuclear antibody (ANA) with 1:160 titer, speckled pattern    * Negative results for viral studies, autoimmune and rheumatologic disease work-up    - Pathological Examination:    * Skin biopsy of right leg    Image Title: Histopathology of right leg biopsy    Image Description: Shows perivascular neutrophilic infiltrates, perivascular fibrin deposition with neutrophil karyorrhexis    * Direct immunofluorescence: Small vessel-wall positivity with C3 and fibrinogen; negative for IgG, IgA, and IgM
final_diagnosis: Leukocytoclastic vasculitis induced by immunotherapy (nivolumab)
reason: The patient's presentation of petechial rash, purpura, and elevated acute-phase reactants suggests a hematological issue, potentially related to a blood disorder or reaction to treatment.

case_information: A healthy 27-year-old Hispanic man presented with a 3-month history of daily fevers with chills, night sweats, generalized weakness, a 25-pound weight loss, poor appetite, and a sore throat. No history of recent infections, trauma, surgery, or travel. Review of systems was negative for shortness of breath, cough, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and changes in bowel or urinary habits.

case_information: A 49-year-old truck driver presented to the emergency department with acute, central abdominal pain rated 8/10 in severity, associated with one episode of bilious vomiting. He had two similar episodes of lower-intensity abdominal pain and nausea two days prior. He experienced a frontal headache two weeks before. No changes to bowel habits, urinary symptoms, fevers, or rigors were reported. Medical history included sexual dysfunction diagnosed in 2015, with normal testicular ultrasounds, normal testosterone levels, normal sex hormone-binding globulin levels, and mildly elevated estrogen level. He had been taking anastrozole for three months before presentation.

case_information: A 73-year-old woman with a medical history of stage 4 chronic kidney disease (CKD) and ischemic cardiomyopathy with an ejection fraction of 15% to 20% presented with acute decompensated heart failure. The movements were consistent with myoclonus with both positive and negative myoclonus that sometimes occurred frequently enough to give the appearance of shivering. No fever or hypothermia was present.

case_information: A 68-year-old woman presented with three months of progressive decline in mental status. case_information: A 61-year-old woman with cirrhosis secondary to alcohol use disorder in remission. Past medical history included esophageal varices, rectal varices, ascites, spontaneous bacterial peritonitis, and recurrent pleural effusion. Risk factors included a remote history of intranasal cocaine use and multiple tattoos. No history of blood transfusions before 1990, intravenous drug use, or high-risk sexual behavior. Three years after initial evaluation, she developed clinical decompensation requiring multiple paracenteses, thoracenteses, and blood transfusions for gastrointestinal bleeding. Three months into this period of decline, she had a dental extraction.
physical_examination: Patient presented with hepatic encephalopathy, acute kidney injury, and recurrent pleural effusion. Mental status showed acute decline. Progressive deterioration led to increased encephalopathy with concurrent hypotension requiring critical care unit transfer.

case_information: A 53-year-old man with history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus type 2, heart failure with recovered ejection fraction presented to the emergency department with left arm and left leg weakness that began 90 minutes before. Five months previously, the patient was hospitalized with cardiac issues, and cardiac magnetic resonance imaging showed an ejection fraction of 30% with global hypokinesis. The patient underwent CABG with Impella 5.5 support and was discharged home on postoperative day 7.

case_information: A 54-year-old man presented with symptoms of nausea, vomiting, and weight loss that started 6 months previously. One year after initial presentation, he developed liver lesions, increased pancreatic mass size, and peritoneal involvement. Nine months later, he was admitted with hyperglycemia, hypokalemia, vomiting, psychosis, and weakness, initially thought to be caused by poorly controlled diabetes mellitus.

case_information: A 34-year-old Thai man with a history of hypertension and tobacco use disorder, and a family history significant for polycythemia, hypertension, and stroke in his father. He initially presented with worsening bifrontal headaches, nausea, vomiting, and right-sided blurry vision. He was not adherent to his antihypertensive regimen. Three months later, he presented again with right-sided frontal headache, photophobia, tingling in his right fingers, nausea, and vomiting. He reported missing a few doses of his carvedilol and had cut down on his smoking.

On second presentation, systolic blood pressures were 150 to 170 mm Hg. National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale score was 2 because of complete left homonymous hemianopsia.

case_information: A 56-year-old woman with a history of hypothyroidism and hyperlipidemia presented for follow-up. Medical history includes 20-year history of oral and ocular sicca symptoms, asymptomatic elevation of creatinine kinase levels with negative myositis and muscular dystrophy panel, negative muscle biopsy results, and chronic stable autoimmune thrombocytopenia. Previous medications included methotrexate and low-dose steroids. Currently on hydroxychloroquine 200 mg daily. Does not take calcium or vitamin D supplements. Review of systems was positive for mild dryness of mouth and throat and Raynaud phenomenon. No skin tightening, esophageal reflux, dysphagia, or telangiectasis reported.
physical_examination: Vital signs were within normal limits. Oral mucosa was dry. Painless pinpoint white nodules present in the subcutaneous plane of the right fifth finger. No lymphadenopathy, telangiectasis, skin lesions, or mucosal or skin ulcers observed. Joints had full range of motion without erythema, swelling, or tenderness. Remainder of physical examination findings were normal.

case_information: A 71-year-old man with a history of hypertension, carotid artery dissection, and stroke in 2002 initially presented with fever, headache, polyarthralgia, abdominal pain, perineal pain, and swelling. Four months after initial presentation, he developed left leg pain. The patient later experienced symptoms involving multiple organs, including diplopia secondary to abducens nerve palsy. He experienced rapid weight loss of more than 13 kg. Past medical history includes hypertension.
physical_examination: Physical findings included pedal edema and cutaneous leukocytoclastic vasculitis.

case_information: A 66-year-old female with a history of epilepsy, thyroid cancer status post thyroidectomy and radiation, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and obstructive sleep apnea with nightly continuous positive airway pressure use. She presented with progressively worsening dyspnea on exertion over 9 months. Initially, she could walk over 1 mile on flat land without stopping, but the condition progressed to requiring multiple breaks during household activities and needing a walker for short distances. No associated lower extremity edema, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, chest pain, palpitations, dizziness, or lightheadedness. She is a lifetime nonsmoker.

case_information: A man in his mid-60s presented with episodes of palpitations, dyspnea, and dizziness during the last half year before referral. The patient was otherwise healthy. The element moved toward the aortic valve during systole, while in early diastole it was dragged further back into the LVOT, forming a thin circular structure. case_information: A 56-year-old woman with locally advanced, unresectable pancreatic adenocarcinoma. She initially received four cycles of Folfirinox chemotherapy without significant response, followed by gemcitabine and nab-paclitaxel therapy. After 20 cycles of combined therapy and 16 additional cycles of nab-paclitaxel alone, she developed bilateral facial drooping, inability to close her eyelids, and difficulty raising her eyebrows. Prior to this, she had experienced grade 1 peripheral neuropathy which remained stable while taking vitamin B6 supplements, and had developed severe edema due to capillary leak which led to discontinuation of gemcitabine.

case_information: A 43-year-old woman with mild intermittent asthma since childhood, well controlled on inhaled fluticasone and salmeterol. She experienced progressive dyspnea, fatigue, anorexia, and weight loss. She was treated for an asthma exacerbation with a steroid taper without improvement. After starting a new medication at low dose (25 mg per day divided into two doses) for two days, the dose was increased to 25 mg twice daily on the third day. She was discharged on the fifth postoperative day but was readmitted the same evening.

case_information: A 71-year-old man presented with painful lower-extremity nodules and polyarthralgia developing over several months. Medical history included recurrent bladder cancer post-resection and local chemotherapy (complicated by bladder-wall perforation and intraperitoneal mitomycin leak requiring surgical management), coronary artery disease, essential hypertension with diastolic dysfunction, and tobacco use. No previous history of gastrointestinal disease or significant family history of rheumatologic conditions or cancer.
physical_examination: Patient had painful nodules on the anterior shins and inner left thigh. The left wrist, hand, and metacarpophalangeal joints were edematous and tender to palpation, with marked synovitis. Bilateral lower extremities were edematous with varicosities, and toes and dorsal feet were edematous and exquisitely tender. No jaundice, scleral icterus, or abdominal tenderness was noted, and patient was tolerating a full diet.

case_information: A 55-year-old man presented with debilitating dysphagia, nausea, and postprandial vomiting. Symptoms began almost immediately after the procedure, including severe nausea after any oral intake, difficulty swallowing solid foods, and frequent vomiting resulting in recurrent hospitalizations for intravenous fluid administration. case_information: A 43-year-old woman of Northern European ancestry, born to nonconsanguineous parents, presented with persistent back and bilateral hip pain. Family history notable for maternal aunt with hemorrhagic stroke from cerebral aneurysm. Birth measurements: ninth percentile for weight, 58th percentile for length, and fourth percentile for head circumference. Patient had septate uterus leading to hysterectomy at 42 years.

case_information: A 55-year-old African American woman presented with a diffuse pruritic rash that started 48 hours after the third dose (first booster) of the mRNA COVID-19 Moderna vaccine. Medical history included allergic rash due to penicillin but no reactions to previous vaccines, including two prior doses of the mRNA COVID-19 Moderna vaccines. No past or family history of neoplasm or autoimmune disease. Current medications included gabapentin for chronic back pain. The rash worsened after 72 hours, becoming larger with itching and burning pain associated with bilateral ankle pain.
physical_examination: Initial examination showed maculopapular, erythematous, non-blanching lesions predominantly involving bilateral upper and lower extremities. Follow-up examination revealed coalescing erythematous patches with palpable purpura involving upper and lower extremities with areas of desquamation.

case_information: A 58-year-old man presented with progressive pain and swelling in the left clavicular area. Medical history included: 60-pack-year smoking history (quit 7 years ago), venous thromboembolism 3 years ago, and chronic low back pain secondary to lumbar spondylosis with radiculopathy. Recent symptoms included decreased appetite, 30-pound weight loss over several weeks, productive cough for 1 week, and night sweats for 2 weeks along with left clavicular pain. case_information: A 76-year-old man with numerous cardiovascular comorbid conditions presented with weeks of worsening renal function leading to hospitalization. Home medications included rosuvastatin, aspirin, prasugrel, sacubitril-valsartan, metoprolol succinate, ezetimibe, furosemide, and ferrous sulfate. Several weeks after starting a new medication, he experienced decreased appetite, weakness, and fatigue, which persisted for several months. The medication was discontinued after approximately 3.5 months of treatment (two weeks before hospitalization). Despite discontinuation, he still experienced poor appetite and profound weakness, needing a wheelchair. He had one fall approximately one week before presentation, during which he was briefly immobilized.
physical_examination: Patient required wheelchair for mobility. No evidence of physical trauma or findings concerning for compartment syndrome was noted. Subsequently developed reduced left ventricular ejection fraction, oliguria, and rapid atrial fibrillation.
diagnostic_tests: - Laboratory Tests:    * Serum creatinine increased to 760.24 µmol/L (8.61 mg/dL)    * Creatine kinase level: 10,698 U/L    * Urinalysis showed myoglobinuria    * Urine sediment showed acute tubular necrosis with muddy brown casts    * Additional findings: hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, lactic acid increased to 10 mmol/L      - Other Tests:    * ANA: Negative    * Tickborne panel: Negative      - Imaging:    * CT abdomen and pelvis showed no hydronephrosis      Figure Title: Serum creatinine relative to medication initiation/discontinuation

case_information: A 72-year-old man presented with poor appetite and fatigue for a week. No history of Raynaud phenomenon, swollen fingers, rashes, joint pain, coughing, or wheezing. Daily urine output decreased to less than 50 mL/d after admission.

Current medications include insulin detemir, lispro, amlodipine, aspirin, atorvastatin, carvedilol, bumetanide, duloxetine, hydralazine, isosorbide mononitrate, and lisinopril.
