case_information: A 54-year-old man with a medical history of hypertension and squamous cell carcinoma of the subglottis (treated with cisplatin and radiation therapy 8 months prior) presented to the emergency department with abdominal pain and shortness of breath. The patient rapidly deteriorated, requiring intubation and multiple vasopressors. His hospital course lasted 2 months and was complicated by pulmonary embolism, atrial fibrillation, and gastrointestinal bleeding.
physical_examination: The initial presentation showed signs of respiratory distress. The patient's condition rapidly deteriorated requiring intubation and hemodynamic support with multiple vasopressors including norepinephrine, phenylephrine, and vasopressin.

  * Serum calcium levels were within normal range (2.33–2.40 mmol/L [9.3–9.6 mg/dL])
  * Baseline estimated glomerular filtration rate >60, serum creatinine = 65.58 micromoles/L (0.86 mg/dL)

- Imaging Studies:
  * Initial CT: Right-sided pneumonia with empyema
  * Serial CT scans: Development of diffuse calcification of the LV myocardium over 6 days
  * Coronary angiography: Demonstrated nonobstructive coronary artery disease
  * Cardiac MRI: Revealed dilated LV with severely reduced ejection fraction and extensive subepicardial late gadolinium enhancement
  * PET scan findings: Initial normal myocardial FDG uptake, followed by reduced uptake, and later normalized FDG uptake

- Image Descriptions:
  * Figure 1: CT chest showing diffuse, thick, and linear LV calcification 6 days after admission
  * Figure 2: Cardiac MRI showing dilated LV with reduced systolic function
  * Figure 3: Serial CT scans showing calcification progression and reduction over 3 years
  * Figure 4: Serial PET scans showing FDG uptake changes
final_diagnosis: Reversible left ventricular calcification postsepsis
reason: The case involves significant cardiac issues including dilated left ventricle, reduced ejection fraction, and myocardial calcification, indicating a primary concern for cardiology.

From 2014 onwards, she experienced recurrent abscesses, indurated erythematous plaques, and sclerosis on both upper legs. She showed no symptoms of autoinflammation or autoimmunity besides periodic fever.

case_information: A 74-year-old woman with hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and chronic kidney disease presented with severe exertional dyspnea. She underwent aortic and mitral valve–replacement surgery. On postoperative day 5, she experienced a bradycardic episode leading to cardiac arrest requiring resuscitation and intubation. She developed progressive acute worsening of renal function complicated by pulmonary edema and hyperkalemia refractory to medical therapy (peak creatinine, 4.42; baseline, 1.5). The patient had not received adequate enteral feeding for 48 hours.

case_information: A 78-year-old White woman, with a medical history of well-controlled hypothyroidism, presented with a pruritic, erythematous rash for 2 months. The rash began as an annular, erythematous lesion on the left side of her abdomen. One week later, the rash spread to her cheeks and periorbital area. The patient initially experienced mild improvement with oral steroids but had persistent, pruritic macules and papules in a patchy distribution on her face and arms. The rash progressed over the following 3 months, extending into the scalp, neck, legs, and arms with up to 50% skin involvement in these areas. The annular lesions enlarged and exhibited a collarette of scale.

case_information: An 83-year-old man with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with metformin was admitted for a left foot ulcer secondary to vascular disease. During admission, he was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation and asymptomatic SARS-CoV-2 infection. Seven days after discharge, the patient consulted again, presenting with new skin lesions consisting of violaceous pretibial lesions with areas of necrosis and intense pain in the right lower limb. The patient had been administered subcutaneous abdominal heparin, with no lesion in the site of injection. No history of cocaine use, fever, dyspnea, chest pain, or other systemic symptoms. No previous hospitalizations or heparin administration.

case_information: A 77-year-old woman presented to the emergency department with shortness of breath, fatigue, and weakness for a few days. case_information: A 64-year-old nonsmoking woman with a history of dyslipidemia presented to the emergency department with one week of progressive dyspnea. She was initially seen at urgent care. case_information: A previously healthy 22-year-old man, vaccinated with two doses of BNT162B2 approximately five months prior, was brought by emergency medical services after collapsing at home. case_information: A 34-year-old man with a history of asthma presented with chest pain. He had pleuritic and positional chest pain five days prior without infectious symptoms. case_information: A 65-year-old man was readmitted for worsening fever, chills, and shortness of breath following a recent hospitalization. case_information: A 63-year-old woman presented with difficult-to-treat hypertension. case_information: A 62-year-old woman presented with one month of progressive bilateral lower extremity pain and weakness resulting in decreased mobility. case_information: A 61-year-old woman presented with worsening dyspnea over the previous six months, with acute exacerbation. Medical history included a 20-year history of autoimmune condition with joint involvement, complicated by usual interstitial pneumonia pattern interstitial lung disease four years prior and keratoconjunctivitis sicca. Patient was alert but chronically ill-looking and cachectic. Normal breath sounds on auscultation, no increased work of breathing or accessory muscle use. No jugular venous distention, normal heart sounds. Pupils equal and reactive, no conjunctival injection or scleral icterus. No skin rashes, ulcerations, palpable purpura, or nodules. No palpable lymph nodes. Abdomen soft, nontender, nondistended with normal bowel sounds. Muscle tone normal, power 5/5, no cranial nerve deficits. Bilateral ulnar deviation at metacarpophalangeal joints with swan neck deformities at third and fourth fingers bilaterally. No joint swelling, warmth, or redness, but tenderness noted.

case_information: A 45-year-old Filipino woman presented with a 2-day history of right-sided headache and emesis of clear fluid. case_information: A 30-year-old woman presented with a 15-year history of recurrent ankle swelling and intermittent painful and tender nodules on her legs and feet. Her symptoms worsened during two pregnancies, which were carried to term. One and a half years before admission, she experienced escalation of symptoms, with nodules progressing to painful leg ulcers, and developed intermittent oral and vaginal ulcerations. Previous treatments included wound care, leg compression, systemic corticosteroids, methotrexate, hydroxychloroquine, aspirin, and rivaroxaban.
physical_examination: Patient had large, extremely tender, irregularly shaped circumferential leg ulcers, with violaceous and purpuric borders, areas of eschar, and a fibrinous base. Reticulated erythema and purpura were present on hands. Faintly erythematous, blanching macules and papules coalescing into patches and thin plaques were observed on bilateral thighs. Genital and oral ulcers were also present.
diagnostic_tests: - Laboratory findings: Elevated C-reactive protein, elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, mildly elevated C3, leukocytosis, and hyperglycemia.- Imaging studies:  - Doppler ultrasound of lower extremities showed venous stasis  - Systemic imaging revealed splenomegaly and involvement of retroperitoneal, pelvic, and inguinal lymph nodes- Pathological findings:  - Skin biopsy (left thigh): Monomorphic, perivascular, and periadnexal atypical lymphocytic infiltrate  - Skin biopsy (purpuric edge of leg ulceration): Epidermal necrosis with numerous fibrin thrombi and intra-/perivascular atypical lymphocytic infiltrate showing monotony and hyperchromasia  - Immunohistochemical staining: CD3-positive T cells coexpressing CD4 and CD8 with preserved expression of CD7  - Flow cytometry: Phenotypically abnormal T-cell population with CD52 expression

  * Serum lactate: elevated at 3.5 mmol/L

  Figure 3: Bladder leak visible on CT of abdomen

case_information: A 71-year-old man presented with three weeks of jaundice, weight loss, abdominal pain, and dark-colored urine. He also reported bilateral lower-extremity weakness that was most noticeable when attempting to arise from a chair, resulting in several ground-level falls. He had no history of autoimmune or neuromuscular conditions. Despite his recent falls, he did not have any prolonged periods of being down that could contribute to muscle injury. case_information: A 65-year-old man with a history of hepatitis B, hepatitis C, rheumatoid arthritis, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and obesity presented with several months of facial swelling, dysphagia, and dysarthria. Shortly thereafter, he developed a pruritic rash on his trunk and upper extremities. He did not report a personal or family history of angioedema. His medications included lisinopril, atorvastatin, albuterol, and ibuprofen for rheumatoid arthritis. The patient had discontinued etanercept six months before presentation. He presented to the emergency department two weeks after seeing his primary care provider for a persistent periorbital, chest, and upper extremity rash. His rash worsened, and he noted new throat swelling and weakness.
physical_examination: Vital signs were stable on arrival. Physical examination was notable for anasarca and a diffuse coalescent erythematous rash over the extremities, chest, and abdomen, with scaling and crusting of the back. There was a heliotrope rash and erythematous lip swelling. He had weakness to resistance in all extremities and a muffled voice without tongue swelling. Over several days, the patient's shoulder and hip weakness progressed, and he could not lift his arms above his head or stand without assistance.
diagnostic_tests: - Laboratory Tests:    - Basic metabolic panel and complete blood count were unremarkable    - Elevated C-reactive protein and erythrocyte sedimentation rate    - Negative viral respiratory panel    - C4, C1q, and C1 esterase inhibitor were unremarkable    - Normal serum and urine protein electrophoresis    - Elevated transaminases    - Elevated anti-Sjögren syndrome–related antigen A autoantibodies    - High antinuclear antibody titers    - Negative anti-Jo antibody    - Elevated creatine kinase    - Positive myositis panel for anti-SAE antibodies  - Imaging Studies:    - CT neck: Mild submental inflammatory stranding with no discrete fluid collection or abscess    - Liver ultrasound: Hepatic steatosis    - CT chest: Multiple nodular and airspace opacities, including right lower lobe nodule  - Pathology:    - Skin biopsy results were consistent with Wong-type presentation
final_diagnosis: Wong-type Dermatomyositis
reason: The patient presents with symptoms and lab findings consistent with an autoimmune condition, including a rash, muscle weakness, and elevated autoantibodies, which are typically managed by rheumatology.

case_information: A 52-year-old woman presented with a mass on her left parotid gland causing otalgia. She did not report any constitutional symptoms initially. Eighteen months after initial presentation, the patient developed facial swelling, abdominal bloating, easy bruising, 30-lb weight gain. Past medical history was unremarkable.
physical_examination: Initial examination: Blood pressure was 120/78 mm Hg, normal. Later examination (18 months): Blood pressure elevated to 193/113 mm Hg. Physical findings included facial swelling, abdominal bloating, easy bruising, and significant weight gain (30 lbs).
diagnostic_tests: - Initial Imaging: Head, neck, and chest imaging showed a 2.4-cm parotid mass and a 2.7-cm level IIB lymph node.- Fine-needle aspiration biopsy: Showed features of a salivary gland neoplasm with atypia.- Laboratory Tests (18 months after presentation):  * Serum cortisol: 1151 nmol/L (normal range: 133-537)  * ACTH level: 78.5 pmol/L (normal range: 1.6-13.9)  * Random blood glucose: 16 mmol/L (elevated)  * Potassium: 3.0 mmol/L (normal range: 3.5-5.0)  * Aspartate aminotransferase: 62 IU/L (normal: <33)  * Alanine aminotransferase: 51 IU/L (normal: <32)  * 24-hour urine cortisol: 1375 mmol/d (normal: <275) on day 1, 1228 mmol/d on day 2  * Midnight salivary cortisol: 68.6 and 59.7 nmol/L (normal: <11.3) on two consecutive nights- Histological Examination: Stage T2N2B, with metastases in 5 of 47 lymph nodes, lymphovascular and perineural invasion- Immunohistochemical staining: Positive for ACTH in 30-40% of invasive tumor cells; negative for synaptophysin and chromogranin
final_diagnosis: Acinic cell carcinoma (ACC) with high-grade transformation and ACTH-dependent Cushing syndrome
option_b: Acinic cell carcinoma (ACC) with high-grade transformation and ACTH-dependent Cushing syndrome
option_d: Ectopic ACTH syndrome due to malignant parotid neoplasm
reason: The case presents features of Cushing's syndrome due to elevated cortisol levels and ACTH, indicating an endocrine disorder. Additionally, the parotid mass and associated symptoms suggest a possible endocrine tumor.

case_information: A 31-year-old African American man originally from the Togolese Republic presented with right foot/ankle swelling and pain. He reported associated fevers that began the morning before presenting. Medical history includes a condition diagnosed at 8 years old.
physical_examination: Patient was tachycardic, diaphoretic, and febrile. Several areas of skin over his face, chest, and abdomen showed hardened plaque and depigmentation. Over the upper extremities, hardened nodules of varying sizes were noted, along with larger hardened masses that were fixed and nontender to palpation. The right foot/ankle was fluctuant and tender to palpation.

case_information: An 84-year-old man with a medical history of hyperlipidemia, hypertension, hypothyroidism, and tobacco use was admitted for evaluation of an asymptomatic abdominal mass with pulsations. The patient had a 20-pack-year smoking history and had been smoking pipe tobacco for the past 10 years. The patient did not report shortness of breath, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, lower extremity weakness, or abdominal, back, or chest pain. A previous scan 9 years prior showed the mass was 3 cm.

Examination revealed a well-defined large pulsatile mass palpable in the epigastric region with a soft bruit audible on auscultation. Pulses were palpable in the lower extremities bilaterally.

The right ureter was significantly displaced anterolaterally. Dense calcifications of iliac vessels present without narrowing. No signs of impending rupture. Aneurysmal neck angulation greater than 60 degrees with neck tortuosity noted.

case_information: A 64-year-old man with a medical history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, hypothyroidism, and hypertension presented with a 1-month onset of worsening dyspnea and unintentional 10-lb weight loss.
physical_examination: Patient was afebrile, had a blood pressure of 100/60 mm Hg, respiratory rate of 42/min, heart rate of 110 beats/min, and oxygen saturation 77% on room air. Physical examination revealed bilateral vesicular breathing with diffuse rhonchi on lung auscultation; no lymphadenopathy was identified.
diagnostic_tests: - Laboratory Tests:    * Hemoglobin: 11.2 g/dL    * Leukocyte: 10.2 ×10³/mcL    * Platelets: 410 ×10³/mcL    * C-reactive protein: 23.4 mg/dL    * Lactate dehydrogenase: 280 EnzU/L    * Other tests: Respiratory viral panel, SARS-CoV-2 PCR, fungal pneumonia work-up were negative. QuantiFERON TB test, hepatitis panel, and HIV were nonreactive.  - Imaging Studies:    * CT Chest: Showed innumerable ill-defined nodular opacities within both lungs, air bronchogram pattern, superimposed pneumonia, and an ill-defined 6.3 × 5.8-cm right hilar mass narrowing the right central bronchi    * CT Abdomen/Pelvis: Showed splenomegaly    * PET scan: Showed marked FDG-avid uptake at the lung lesion, right neck lymph node, and left acetabular bone marrow, with a splenic focus  - Pathology:    * CT-guided lung biopsy: Revealed patchy areas of large atypical lymphoid cells with necrosis    * VATS wedge resection: Showed infiltration of lung parenchyma by malignant neoplasm, mixed inflammatory infiltrate, marked nuclear pleomorphism with atypical mitotic figures, vascular involvement, and areas of parenchymal necrosis

case_information: A 25-year-old woman presented to her local emergency department with right-sided weakness, right-sided facial droop, left gaze deviation, and aphasia. She was last seen at baseline about 6 hours prior. Three years prior, she had experienced a similar event requiring mechanical thrombectomy, with the cause remaining unknown. Medical history included well-controlled hypertension, obesity, migraines, and recurrent immune thrombocytopenia in childhood. Current medications were aspirin, lisinopril, and atorvastatin. She had a history of tobacco use, which stopped after her first event. Family history was notable for a similar condition in her older sister in her early 20s.
physical_examination: Vital signs: Temperature 37.6°C, respiratory rate 14, heart rate 78 beats/min, blood pressure 179/98 mm Hg, body mass index 38.9 kg/m². Patient was alert but nonverbal and did not follow commands. Neurologic examination revealed left gaze preference, right facial droop, right upper- and lower-extremity weakness, and intact sensation throughout. Initial National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale score was 22. Cardiovascular, pulmonary, and abdominal examinations were unremarkable.
diagnostic_tests: Laboratory Tests:- Leukocytes: 11.1 × 10⁹/L (elevated)- Hemoglobin: 11.0 g/dL (low)- Platelet count: initially 110 × 10⁹/L, reached nadir of 83 × 10⁹/L, then normalized to 164 × 10⁹/L- Sodium: 133 mmol/L (low)- Albumin: 3.3 g/dL (low)- Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL (normal)- Reticulocyte percent: 2.71% (elevated)- Lactate dehydrogenase: 322 U/L (elevated)- Haptoglobin: 121 mg/dL (normal)- Total bilirubin: 1.0 (normal)- ADAMTS13 activity: 3% (severely deficient)- ADAMTS13 inhibitor: negativeImaging Studies:- Noncontrast head CT: hypodensities in left frontal and temporal lobes without mass effect, midline shift, herniation, or hemorrhage- CT angiography: left MCA M1 occlusion- Brain CT perfusion: occluded left MCA at M1 segment, left MCA-distribution infarction- Brain MRI: showed left middle cerebral artery distribution infarctionImage Title: Brain MRIImage Description: Left middle cerebral artery distribution infarctionAdditional Studies:- Peripheral blood film examination: presence of schistocytes (red cell fragments)Image Title: Peripheral Blood FilmImage Description: Shows the presence of red cell fragments or schistocytes
final_diagnosis: Congenital Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (cTTP)
reason: The patient presents with acute neurological deficits consistent with a stroke, specifically a left middle cerebral artery infarction, which falls under the domain of Neurology.

case_information: A 69-year-old man with history of uncomplicated robot-assisted prostatectomy for localized prostate cancer. He was initially discharged on postoperative day 2 on aspirin 81 mg daily. Three weeks later, he presented to the emergency department with left lower leg swelling and dyspnea on exertion.

Later developed acute right upper quadrant abdominal pain radiating to the right shoulder, abdominal distension with peritoneal signs, hypotension, and bradycardia.

case_information: A 35-year-old man presented with a 2-year history of dilated cardiomyopathy and progressive exertional chest discomfort during the past year. No dyspnea, orthopnea, syncope, or lipothymia reported. No medical history of myocardial infarction, myocarditis, tuberculosis, rheumatic fever, chest irradiation, or sepsis. No classic risk factors present. No family history of heart disease.
physical_examination: Physical examination revealed:- Irregular heart rate- Ejection murmur at the aortic area with radiation into the carotid artery- Bilateral gynecomastia- Remainder of physical examination was normal
diagnostic_tests: Laboratory Tests:- Normal kidney function tests- Normal calcium and phosphate plasma levels- Normal thyroid and parathyroid hormones- Normal vitamin D levels- Normal serum proteins and fractions- Negative serological tests and inflammatory markers24-hour Holter Monitor:- Sinus rhythm- Frequent supraventricular and ventricular ectopic activity- Isolated and paired extrasystoles- Episodes of nonsustained atrial and ventricular tachycardia- No pathologic pausesImaging Studies:1. Chest Radiograph:- Cardiomegaly- Thickened pericardium- Calcification within cardiac silhouette2. Cardiac Catheterization:- No evidence of coronary artery disease- Diffuse and extensive calcification involving myocardium and fibrous valve tissue- Intense mitral and aortic valve fibrocalcification3. Echocardiogram:- Dilated left ventricle- Moderate systolic dysfunction- Akinesia of inferolateral walls- Hypokinesia of anterior walls- Severe aortic stenosis with moderate aortic regurgitation- Moderate mitral stenosis and regurgitation4. CT Scan:- Massive myocardial calcification affecting all left ventricle segments except basal septum- Calcification around aortic and mitral valves, right ventricle, and left atrium wall- Preserved pericardium and coronary arteries5. Cardiovascular Magnetic Resonance (1.5 T):- Diffuse myocardial thickening- Hypointense areas on T1- and T2-weighted images- Late enhancement in underlying myocardium, non-ischemic distribution- Moderately depressed ejection fractionGenetic Testing:- Identified rare heterozygous variant c.10702C>T (p.Arg3568Trp) in ANK2 gene

case_information: A 55-year-old woman with a history of complete heart block (with permanent pacemaker implantation one year prior), hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus presented with worsening intermittent dyspnea over the past week. case_information: A 59-year-old man presented with fever (38.5°C), dysphagia, and odynophagia with neck and floor-of-mouth swelling. Symptoms started 4 days ago but worsened in past 24 hours, tolerating only fluids. He was on oral cefaclor 750 mg twice daily for 3 days. No history of tooth pain or recent trauma. Medical history significant for goiter and hypothyroidism. Regular medication was L-thyroxine 100 mcg daily. No known drug allergies, no tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drug use.
physical_examination: Patient was alert, mildly febrile (37.6°C) with a 'hot potato' voice. Vital signs normal. Examination revealed trismus and left-sided floor-of-mouth swelling extending to left posterior third of tongue, firm and tender on palpation. No pus on submandibular duct opening. Deviation of tongue tip to left, more prominent on protrusion. No fasciculations, atrophy, or lesions of tongue noted. Tonsils and oropharynx normal. Cranial nerve examination (III−XI) unremarkable. Flexible nasolaryngoscopy showed patent airway. Neck examination revealed firm, tender, 2-cm swelling on left submandibular triangle.

case_information: A 22-year-old Japanese man (BMI: 22.7 kg/m²) with no medical history or family history developed fever and erythema on trunk and extremities 3 days after receiving first dose of Moderna vaccine. On the 12th day after second vaccination, he developed fever. Initial symptoms gradually worsened leading to hospitalization on the 24th day after second vaccination. physical_examination: Initial presentation included fever and erythema on the trunk and extremities. During readmission, patient presented with chest pain that was refractory and persistent.

case_information: A 40-year-old man presented to the emergency department with slurred speech of 2 days' duration. case_information: A 64-year-old White woman with epilepsy and osteoporosis presented with a 10-day history of worsening, intermittent epigastric pain, distention, and constipation. Pain was nonradiating and cramping. She reported fever, chills, and anorexia. No recent illness, weight loss, dysphagia, vomiting, change in stool caliber, melena, or hematochezia. No gastrointestinal medical or surgical history. Family history included ulcerative colitis in her mother. Prior endoscopic work-up included two screening colonoscopies (as recent as five months prior), but no upper endoscopy.

case_information: A 29-year-old Hispanic woman in her 30th week of pregnancy presented to the emergency department for abdominal pain. case_information: A 52-year-old Caucasian man presented with septic shock and bilateral lower extremity soft-tissue wounds. Medical history includes alcohol use disorder and newly diagnosed type 2 diabetes (hemoglobin A1c of 7.5%). The patient had no history or findings suggestive of cirrhosis and had not traveled outside Southern California.
physical_examination: Patient presented with bilateral lower extremity soft-tissue wounds. Additional physical examination details were not provided in the case report.

final_diagnosis: Hypervirulent Klebsiella pneumoniae (hvKp) infection with multifocal manifestations including bacteremia, tibial osteomyelitis, pyogenic liver abscess, and multifocal osteomyelitis

case_information: A 65-year-old White man with a medical history of hyperlipidemia presented to the emergency department with complaints of severe epigastric abdominal pain. The pain started suddenly about 12 hours before arrival and was constant, radiating to his back, nonpositional, and not associated with food intake. The pain was associated with nausea, an episode of vomiting, and cold sweats. He did not report diarrhea, melena, fever, or recent sick contacts. Emergency medical services noted his blood pressure to be 180/110 mm Hg. The patient was administered full-dose aspirin and nitroglycerin without much relief from his pain.
physical_examination: Vital signs: Blood pressure 144/85 mm Hg, pulse 72 beats/min, and temperature 99 °F. The abdomen was soft, nondistended, and positive for epigastric tenderness without guarding or rigidity. Bowel sounds were present. Bilateral dorsalis pedis pulses were 2+. The rest of the physical examination was benign.

He had received the Johnson & Johnson COVID vaccination approximately 4 weeks before presentation.

case_information: A 59-year-old Japanese man presented with malaise and chills that began the day before his visit. Medical history included hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Four months prior, he was diagnosed with acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) and had a history of perianal abscess during induction chemotherapy. The current admission was for maintenance chemotherapy with idarubicin and cytarabine. On day 10 of hospitalization, he experienced a 40.2°C fever, chills, and right upper quadrant abdominal pain when breathing deeply or coughing.

case_information: An 82-year-old man with a 60 pack-year history of tobacco use presented with progressive dysphagia, first to solids and then to liquids, over a three-month period. case_information: A 78-year-old man presented to the emergency department for left lower-extremity pain, swelling, and rapidly enlarging hemorrhagic blisters three days after he fell and scraped his left knee at an airport. His medical history is significant for multiple comorbidities, including type 2 diabetes mellitus and atrial fibrillation managed with apixaban. On the day of the incident, the patient scraped his left knee with minimal reported pain.
physical_examination: Initial examination showed left lower-extremity wound progression distally with extensive blistering, draining bloody fluid. The anterior lower leg distal to the knee was extremely tender to light palpation with extensive bruising with induration extending from the point of impact proximally to the left thigh. The patient was tachycardic, afebrile, and without leukocytosis. His foot and distal left leg were neurovascularly intact.
diagnostic_tests:

  Description: Demonstrates extensive edema of the subcutaneous posterior compartment

- Laboratory Studies:
  - Wound cultures revealed no organism growth

- Surgical Findings:

case_information: A 74-year-old Amish woman presented with recurrent abdominal pain, anorexia, nausea, and vomiting for several days. She denied fevers, chills, jaundice, acholic stools, melena, or hematochezia. Notable past medical history includes severe ischemic cardiomyopathy and admission one month prior for small bowel obstruction, during which a 4 cm gallstone was removed via exploratory laparotomy. The gallbladder was left in place due to dense adhesions near the liver. All other medical and family history was noncontributory.
physical_examination: Vital signs: Blood pressure 174/95 mmHg, afebrile, respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute. Physical examination revealed moderate abdominal distention and tenderness in the right lower quadrant. No guarding or rebound was present. A well-healing midline incision from previous exploratory laparotomy was noted.

case_information: A 52-year-old man presented with sudden, pressure-like, substernal chest pain that started at rest and radiated to the left jaw, associated with nausea, dyspnea, and diaphoresis. Symptoms began approximately 6 hours before arrival. Two hours after intervention, the patient reported a new onset of fever and worsening chest pain that was retrosternal and sharp in quality, but not affected by positional changes or exertion.
physical_examination: Initial examination: Patient was tachycardic, with no murmurs. No crackles were present on lung auscultation. Jugular venous pressure was normal. Follow-up examination: Temperature of 38.3°C, auscultation revealed a new pericardial friction rub located over the left sternal border.
diagnostic_tests:
- Laboratory Tests:
Initial troponin levels were 14 µg/L

- Imaging Studies:
1. Initial ECG showed ST-segment elevations in leads II, aVF, and V3-V5
2. Coronary angiography findings: acute thrombotic total occlusion of the mid-segment of the left anterior descending artery with TIMI 0 flow. Ventriculography demonstrated an ejection fraction of 55% to 60%
3. Second ECG: complete resolution of ST-segment elevation in V2-V3 with persistence of ST-segment elevation in II, III, aVF, and V4-V6 without reciprocal changes
4. Third ECG (24 hours later): diffuse ST-segment elevation on II, III, aVF, and V3-V5 accompanied by PR-segment depression in I and II and PR-segment elevation in aVR without reciprocal changes
5. Transthoracic echocardiogram: no evidence of pericardial effusion, no wall motion abnormalities, ejection fraction of 55% to 60%
final_diagnosis: Peri-infarction pericarditis (PIP)
option_a: Acute coronary syndrome with early post-infarction pericarditis
reason: The case presents with symptoms and findings indicative of acute coronary syndrome, including chest pain, ST-segment elevations, and troponin elevation, which are all within the domain of cardiology.

case_information: An 81-year-old man initially developed a cough, subjective fever, and shortness of breath. He was first treated with azithromycin for bronchitis, followed by levofloxacin after a right upper lobe infiltrate was found. His symptoms progressed despite antibiotics. Medical history includes coronary artery disease with coronary artery bypass (two years prior), atrial fibrillation on rivaroxaban, heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, stage 3 chronic kidney disease, and type 2 diabetes mellitus (HbA1c: 8.1%). He had spent time at a Northern Minnesota cabin but reported minimal outdoor exposure. Previous missionary work in Colombia ended two years before admission. Never smoked and rarely consumed alcohol.
physical_examination: Vital signs: Temperature 38.6°C, Pulse 130 beats/min, Blood Pressure 114/61 mm Hg, Respiratory Rate 22 breaths/min, Oxygen Saturation 82% (improved to >90% with 5 L/min oxygen). Lung sounds were diminished in the right upper lobe, with diffuse crackles in the right lung base. No clubbing or cyanosis. Cardiac examination showed tachycardic irregularly irregular rhythm, systolic ejection murmur, and mild pitting edema to the knee bilaterally. No cervical or axillary lymphadenopathy. Neurologic and skin examinations were normal. Later developed right-sided ptosis and anisocoria with an asymmetrically miotic right pupil (more evident in dark environment).
diagnostic_tests:

- Leukocytosis: 15,000/mm³
- Procalcitonin: 0.77 ng/mL
- Positive Blastomyces urine antigen
- Positive Histoplasmosis blood antigen
- Negative results for Mycobacterium tuberculosis
- Negative antigen tests for Cryptococcus, Legionella, and influenza
- Negative Paracoccidioides serum antibody

Imaging Studies:

2. CT and MRI

Description: Both showed no acute process

Other Tests:
Bronchoscopy findings: Moderate clear secretions with erythematous and edematous bronchial mucosa
Bronchoalveolar lavage: Spherical broadly based budding yeast on Grocott-Gomori methenamine silver stain
final_diagnosis: Horner syndrome secondary to invasive Blastomyces pneumonia
option_d: Horner syndrome secondary to invasive Blastomyces pneumonia
reason: The patient presents with respiratory symptoms, positive fungal antigen tests, and imaging findings consistent with pulmonary infections, indicating a likely infectious etiology.

case_information: A 54-year-old woman living in upstate New York with a medical history significant for idiopathic CD4 lymphocytopenia (ICL) originally diagnosed in 2015 with an annual CD4 cell count ranging between 14 and 18 cells/µL. She initially presented to her primary care physician with a sore throat. When symptoms did not improve after one week, she was referred to an otolaryngologist. The sore throat persisted despite a trial of omeprazole and fluctuated in intensity over the following months. Several months later, the patient began to experience dysphonia along with odynophagia. Throughout this course, the patient had no systemic symptoms (fever, weight loss, myalgias) or pulmonary symptoms.
physical_examination: Laryngoscopy revealed thickening of the epiglottic mucosa with irregularity and white plaques. A repeat laryngoscopy demonstrated progression of the plaques.
diagnostic_tests:
- Laboratory Tests:
  * Laryngeal cultures initially grew Streptococcus mitis, Streptococcus salivarius, Rothia mucilaginosus, Neisseria flavescens/subflava, and Candida albicans
  * Urine histoplasma antigen: positive at 0.3 ng/mL
  * Acid-fast stain and culture: negative

- Imaging Studies:
  * Computed tomography of the chest revealed subtle ground-glass opacities in the left upper lobe

- Pathological Examination:
  * Laryngeal biopsy revealed rare hyphae and yeast forms on Grocott methenamine silver stain with no evidence of malignancy or granulomas
  * Fungal culture grew Histoplasma capsulatum, identified by typical tuberculate microconidia

- Images:
  * Figure 1 Title: Laryngoscopy findings
  * Figure 1 Description: Patient's epiglottis (A) and larynx (B) showing white plaques and thickening of the mucosa
  * Figure 2 Title: Microscopy findings
  * Figure 2 Description: (A) Mold with cottony texture and white-tan reverse after 16 days incubation, (B) Lactophenol cotton blue tease mount preparation showing large, thick-walled, round tuberculate macroconidia at 400× magnification
final_diagnosis: Laryngeal histoplasmosis
reason: The case primarily involves laryngeal symptoms, findings from laryngoscopy, and a diagnosis related to the throat and larynx, which falls under the expertise of Otolaryngology.

diagnostic_tests: - Laboratory Tests:    * Microcytic hypochromic anemia    * Low fibrinogen levels (178 mg/dl, normal range 200–400)    * Antiphospholipid antibodies (IgM 47.30 U/ml, normal range <25.0)    * Elevated serum TSH (6.880 μIU/ml, n.r. 0.270–4.200)    * Low folic acid (1.27 ng/ml, n.r. 3.21–20.00)    * Elevated lactic acid (26 mg/dl, n.r. 3.0–12.0)    * Altered hemoglobin pattern (Hb A 93.1%, Hb A2 5.5%)- Imaging Studies:    * CTA and MRI Title: Aortic Arch and Carotid Imaging    * Description: Revealed bilateral lesions in middle cerebral artery territories, right subclavian artery originating from middle part of aortic arch, left and right common carotid arteries sharing common origin, fusiform dilatation of left ICA, and left occipital artery arising from left ICA dilatation    * MRI with Gadolinium and MRS Title: Brain Lesion Assessment    * Description: Hyperintense lesion on long TR sequences in left precentral gyrus with mild frontal lobe swelling, no contrast enhancement, normal tCho/NAA ratio    * Transtoracic Ecocardiography Findings:      - Right-to-left shunt at rest and during Valsalva      - Patent foramen ovale (15mm length, 4mm maximum amplitude)      - Annuloaortic ectasia (49mm)      - Ascending aortic ectasia (40mm)    * Ultrasonography: Legs and abdominal veins showed no deep venous thrombi
final_diagnosis: Bilateral minor embolic stroke of undetermined source (ESUS)
option_b: Paradoxical embolic stroke (through patent foramen ovale)
option_c: Transient ischemic attack (TIA) secondary to paradoxical embolism via patent foramen ovale
option_d: Bilateral minor embolic stroke of undetermined source (ESUS)
reason: The case presents with transient neurological symptoms (facial and arm weakness) and imaging findings indicative of cerebral lesions, which are primarily evaluated by the neurology department.

case_information: A 67-year-old male with a past medical history of hypertension and coronary artery disease presented with episodes of prominent dizziness, vertigo, intermittent left arm shaking, and bouts of dull response that occurred while playing Mah-Jong with his friends. During the attacks, he was partially aware of what was happening but unable to think. Each episode lasted about 5 minutes. The attacks recurred more than 10 times a day. He had no prior history of seizures.
physical_examination: Blood pressure was 200/110 mmHg at triage. Neurological examination was unremarkable except for the presence of a dull response during the events. There were no focal brainstem signs, left-right disorientation, dyslexia, dysgraphia, or finger agnosia. No extraocular movement deviation, trismus, or incontinence was observed.
diagnostic_tests: - Laboratory tests: Basic laboratory data were within normal limits.- Imaging studies:  Brain MRI revealed non-specific white matter changes with no signal alterations in the posterior circulation or brainstem.  - EEG findings:  Title: Right hemispheric rhythmic activities  Description: Rhythmic epileptiform discharges originating from the right frontal area with ipsilateral hemispheric spreading and relatively limited homologous contralateral involvement. Activities appeared in a quasi-periodic fashion at intervals of about one second, during which the patient presented significant dizziness, vertigo and dull response.
final_diagnosis: Non-convulsive seizures (NCSs)
option_b: Focal onset epilepsy (right frontal lobe epilepsy)
reason: The patient's symptoms of dizziness, vertigo, and episodes of altered awareness, along with EEG findings indicating epileptiform discharges, suggest a neurological condition, making Neurology the appropriate department.

case_information: A Caucasian male patient in his early fifties was brought to the Emergency Department by ambulance and police escort. He was found naked in the street, covered in blood from the genital area. Past medical history includes polysubstance abuse since age 13 and attention deficit disorder diagnosed in his early thirties. He had received intermittent treatment with methylphenidate 108 mg daily. The patient had a history of childhood abuse and neglect, limited education (completed secondary school), and has been mostly unemployed living on welfare benefits. A few days before the incident, staff at his supported housing reported that he was exhibiting unusual behavior.
physical_examination: The patient presented with complete penis amputation, scrotal injury with a deep incised wound exposing but leaving uninjured both testicles, and multiple cuts in both eyelids. The penile incision was clean-cut, consistent with injury from a sharp knife. X-ray imaging demonstrated a right distal diaphyseal ulnar fracture and a left lateral clavicle fracture.

case_information: A 66-year-old female patient with osteoporosis presented with complaints of back pain. The pain was radiating to the left side and gradually worsening in recent months. The back pain had not improved despite left nephrectomy due to kidney stones about 1 year ago. The patient was taking alendronate 70 mg once a week for osteoporosis. Family history was unremarkable.
physical_examination: Physical examination revealed a scar of incision on the left lumbar region and mild left costovertebral angle tenderness. Neurologic examination showed negative babinski sign and normal deep tendon reflexes on both lower limbs. There were neither sensory loss nor motor neurologic deficit.
diagnostic_tests: - Laboratory tests: Comprehensive laboratory investigations including serum creatinine, calcium, phosphate, parathyroid hormone, thyrotropin and thyroid hormones were normal.- Imaging studies:  1. Lumbar spine X-ray: Demonstrated degenerative changes of the vertebral bodies  2. Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry: T-scores of both the lumbar spine and proximal femur were less than -3  3. MRI findings:     Image Title: T1-weighted sagittal image with contrast     Image Description: A 35 × 9 mm sized mass occupying the spinal canal at T8-T9 level. Well-circumscribed intradural extramedullary lesion, hypointense on T1-weighted images and heterogene hyperintense on T2-weighted images. The lesion compressing the spinal cord from posterior showed peripheral rim enhancement around the central cystic area after contrast media injection.- Histopathological examination:  Description: Tumor consisted of elongated spindle cells with vesicular nucleus arrayed in a palisade pattern among large cystic cavities lined by single-layer squamous epithelium. Markedly nuclear pleomorphism present in some tumor cells.  Immunohistochemical analysis: Neoplastic cells were negative for epithelial membrane antigen, pancytokeratin and desmin but diffuse positive for protein S-100. Ki67 proliferation index was 1%.
final_diagnosis: Ancient schwannoma
reason: The case involves a spinal mass with histopathological features suggestive of a neoplasm, indicating a need for oncology evaluation.

case_information: A 12-month-old Caucasian boy presented with convulsive seizures lasting 3-4 seconds, characterized by faltering, smirking with withdrawal of the head and eyes. First convulsive seizures noted at 8 months. Psychomotor development was normal for age. No family history of similar conditions.

option_d: Clivus chordoma associated with Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC)
reason: The case presents a significant neoplasm in the brain, along with genetic mutations associated with tumor syndromes, indicating a need for oncological evaluation and management.

diagnostic_tests: - Imaging Studies:    * Chest X-ray: Shows tumor in the center, pleural effusion on left side, and diffuse granular shadows on right side    * Chest CT: Shows bronchial wall thickening and numerous granular shadows      - Biopsy Results:    * TBLB (1mm specimen):       - HE staining showed lymphocyte infiltration, no fibrosis      - EVG staining showed no elastic fibers    * TBLC (6mm specimen):      - HE staining showed inflammatory cell infiltration and fibrosis around bronchioles      - EVG staining revealed hypertrophy of elastic fibers      - Other Tests:    * Respiratory function test showed decreased forced expiratory volume in 1s    * Blood sampling showed high cold agglutinin reaction
final_diagnosis: Diffuse panbronchiolitis (DPB)
reason: The case involves respiratory symptoms, imaging findings related to the lungs, and biopsy results indicating lung pathology, which are all relevant to pulmonology.

case_information: A young woman presented with repeated first trimester pregnancy loss following assisted reproductive technology. She had normal puberty and regular menstrual cycles after treatment for polycystic ovaries syndrome during adolescence. Height: 170 cm, weight: 64kg. She reported language disability as a child, treated by speech therapy. Family history: mother had multiple miscarriages, maternal uncle had azoospermia, and sister has moderate intellectual disability with coordination and orientation problems.
physical_examination: Normal height and weight. No dysmorphic features detected. Secondary sexual characteristics well developed. No signs of hyperandrogenism. No behavioral problems or learning difficulties. No developmental delay or documented congenital abnormalities.
diagnostic_tests: {'Cytogenetic Analysis': '- G-banding karyotype showed translocation between chromosome 1 and 8, with additional material on chromosome 9    - Whole chromosome painting FISH confirmed translocation t(1;8) with part of chromosome 8 translocating to another chromosome    - Chromosomal microarray analysis (CMA) detected [GRCh37]8p23.3p23.1(158,048–11,945,856)×3;[GRCh37]9q34.3(140,751,848–141,020,389)×1        Image Title: G-banded karyotype    Image Description: Arrows indicate the rearrangements at 1p, 8q and 9q        Image Title: Whole chromosome painting FISH    Image Description: Shows chromosome 1 (Green) and chromosome 8 (Orange) with various translocations', 'Cardiac Evaluation': 'Cardiac ultrasound showed no structural abnormalities'}
final_diagnosis: Unbalanced complex chromosomal rearrangement (CCR) with 8p23.1 duplication syndrome
option_a: Complex chromosomal rearrangement (CCR) involving chromosomes 1, 8, and 9
option_c: Unbalanced complex chromosomal rearrangement (CCR) with 8p23.1 duplication syndrome
option_d: Unbalanced translocation involving partial duplication of chromosome 8p and partial deletion of chromosome 9q
reason: The case involves repeated pregnancy loss and reproductive health issues, which are primarily managed within the Obstetrics & Gynecology department.

case_information: A 65-year old male presented with persistent high-grade fever, nausea, vomiting and generalized weakness for 10 days. Prior history included one month of intermittent high-grade fever, vomiting, loss of weight and night-sweats. Medical history significant for hypertension (6 months) and benign prostate hyperplasia (2 years) with regular medication.
physical_examination: Patient was conscious, well-built and oriented but lethargic. Temperature: 101°F. Physical findings included mild hepatosplenomegaly and conjunctival pallor.
diagnostic_tests: - Laboratory Tests:    * Complete Blood Count: Hemoglobin 9.4 g/dL, leukocyte count 2.94 × 103/μL, platelet count 90 × 103/μL, MCV 78 fL    * Chemistry: Elevated liver transaminases (>3x normal), total bilirubin 0.85 mg/dL, LDH 1552.30 IU/L, ferritin >1700ng/mL, hyponatremia (117 mmol/L), total protein 4.72 g/dL    * Serology: Negative for hepatitis B/C, HIV, malaria, dengue, and scrub typhus    * Culture: Negative blood, urine, and sputum cultures- Imaging Studies:    * Radiological evaluation showed hepatosplenomegaly with fatty liver, mild urinary bladder wall thickening    * CECT thorax and abdomen: Mild hepatomegaly and prostatomegaly    * PET Scan: Hepatomegaly with external iliac lymphadenopathy- Bone Marrow Studies:    Title: Bone marrow and trephine biopsy    Description: Erythroid hyperplasia with megaloblastic erythropoiesis and evidence of erythroid and lymphophagocytosis    - Molecular Testing:    TrueNat MTB/RIF Assay: MTB detected with Rifampicin indeterminate
final_diagnosis: Disseminated Tuberculosis with Hemophagocytic Lymphohistiocytosis (TB-HLH)
option_c: Hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH), possibly secondary to tuberculosis
reason: The patient presents with persistent fever, hepatosplenomegaly, and evidence of mycobacterial infection (MTB detected), indicating a likely infectious process.

case_information: A 53-year-old woman presented with a 3-year history of a lump on the posterior aspect of a right knee joint. The patient had no underlying diseases. She complained of a lump growing at the posterior aspect of her right knee joint, along with pain and discomfort while walking or standing with the knee joint extended.
physical_examination: - Range of right knee motion (ROM): 10-130°- No internal swelling of the knee joint - No tenderness of medial or lateral joint line- Normal Lachman test results- Normal valgus and varus stress tests- 3 x 3 cm sized palpable lump at posterior aspect of right knee joint
diagnostic_tests: - Radiographic findings:  * Normal knee joint and lower limb alignments  * Mild osteoarthritis (Kellgren-Lawrence grade 1) in both knee joints- MRI findings:  * Multi-lobulated cyst measuring 3.3 cm × 3.0 cm × 3.9 cm at popliteal fossa  * Popliteal artery running on anteromedial side of the cyst  * No unusual findings in ligament, cartilage, and meniscus  Image Title: Preoperative MRI viewsImage Description: Shows multi-lobulated popliteal cyst in sagittal, axial and coronal views, located next to posterior aspect of popliteal artery
final_diagnosis: Atypical popliteal cyst
reason: The case involves a knee joint issue with a palpable lump and MRI findings of a popliteal cyst, which falls under orthopedic conditions.

case_information: A 57-year-old man with a history of hypertension, asthma since childhood, former smoker (30 pack-year, quit 3 years ago), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and treated localized prostate cancer. Patient reported shortness of breath and dry cough when exposed to allergens like dust, cutting grass and trees, and hot weather. He had been using short-acting bronchodilators (Levalbuterol) 1-2 times per day. Denied persistent productive cough, fever, hemoptysis, and night sweats. No recent travel history, and no use of intravenous or inhalational drugs.
physical_examination: Physical examination was unremarkable except for supraumbilical left paramedian incisional hernia. Vital signs were stable.
diagnostic_tests: - Laboratory Tests:    - White blood cells: 6 K/μL with 7.9% eosinophils    - C-reactive protein: <0.29 mg/dl    - IgE level: 799 IU/ml    - Aspergillus antibody by complement fixation: negative (<1:8)    - PSA: <0.01 ng/ml    - PPD test: negative    - HIV test: negative    - BAL fungal cultures: grew Curvularia species after nine days    - AFB smears and cultures: negative      - Imaging Studies:    - CT chest without contrast:      Title: Right Upper Lobe Mass      Description: Lobulated solid partially calcified mass in the right upper lobe, compromising the upper lobe bronchial system with distal tree-in-bud abnormality, bilateral small lung nodules, no hilar or mediastinal lymphadenopathy        - PET scan:      Title: PET Scan Findings      Description: Irregular lobulated right upper lung mass with faint or mild irregular FDG uptake, scattered bilateral tiny lung nodules with no avid FDG uptake      - Pathology:    - Fine needle aspiration: Mixed inflammatory cells including numerous eosinophils and Crystalline debris, no malignant cells    - Endobronchial biopsy: Benign respiratory mucosa with acute and chronic inflammation with lymphocytes, plasma cells, neutrophils, and eosinophils. No fungal elements seen, PAS and GMS negative
final_diagnosis: Curvularia lung infection presenting as a solitary lung mass
option_b: Allergic Bronchopulmonary Mycosis (ABPM) due to Curvularia
option_c: Curvularia lung infection presenting as a solitary lung mass
reason: The patient presents with respiratory symptoms, a lung mass, and a history of COPD, making pulmonology the most relevant department for evaluation and management.

case_information: A 55-year-old man presented with acute onset of vomiting blood, passing black tarry stools, and epigastric pain. Notable history includes persistent hiccups over the past 5 years and esophageal varices found on EGD 5 years ago. No history of planting rice, living near water bodies, or heavy alcohol use. Patient had SARS-CoV-2 seven months before admission, with occasional episodes of difficulty breathing and dry cough after discharge. No history of tuberculosis infection.
physical_examination: Physical exam revealed:- Tender epigastrium- No spleen or liver enlargement - Crepitations heard in both lower lung fields
diagnostic_tests: Laboratory Tests:- Hematology and biochemistry blood work-ups showed no pathology- Normal/negative results for:  * Erythrocyte sedimentation rate  * Rheumatoid factor  * Antinuclear antibody  * Anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody  * Anti-citrullinated protein antibody  * IgG4  * Syphilis rapid plasmin reagin  * Wuchereria bancrofti enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay  * Hepatitis B surface antigen  * Hepatitis C antibody  * HIV testsImaging Studies:1. Chest X-ray findings:- Bilateral interstitial infiltrates- Blunted costophrenic angles- Cardiomegaly- Widened mediastinum2. CT chest/abdomen findings:- 3 cm partial stenosis of superior vena cava- Dilated azygous veins- Irregular thickening of right pleura and pericardium- Interlobular septal thickening in right lung3. EGD findings:- Dilated blood vessels in distal third of esophagus- Large sliding hiatal hernia4. Abdominal ultrasound:- No obvious pathology
final_diagnosis: Idiopathic Fibrosing Mediastinitis
reason: The patient presents with gastrointestinal symptoms such as vomiting blood and black tarry stools, along with a history of esophageal varices, indicating a potential upper gastrointestinal bleed. Gastroenterology is the most relevant department for managing these conditions.

case_information: A 30-year-old male presented with a 6-year history of recurrent respiratory symptoms and acute exacerbation with dyspnea for 1 day. Past medical history included hospitalization in intensive care unit one year ago requiring mechanical ventilation for over 10 days. Prior pulmonary function tests showed severe mixed ventilation dysfunction with FEV1 PreD of 26% and FEV1/FVC percent of 56%. Patient had previously scored 9 on the Asthma Control Test and 6 on the Asthma Control Questionnaire.
physical_examination: Vital signs on admission:- Temperature: 35.5°C- Pulse: 121 beats/min- Respiratory rate: 32 times/min- Blood pressure: 169/100 mmHg- SpO2: 83% (without oxygen)Physical findings:- Orthopnea- Cyanosis of the lips- Profuse sweating- Three-concave sign- Hyperresonance in percussion of both lungs- Accelerated respiration- Loud and diffuse wheezing rales in both lungs
diagnostic_tests: Laboratory Tests:- Blood gas analysis: pH 7.137, PCO2 74.7 mmHg, PO2 95.0 mmHg, SO2 94.0%, FiO2 41.0%, oxygenation index 232 mmHg- Complete blood count: WBC 15.51 × 109/L, neutrophil percentage 74.2%, eosinophil percentage 7.2%- Other biochemical and coagulation parameters were normalImaging Studies:- Chest CT  Title: Chest CT examination  Description: No major abnormalities observed in both lungs and heartPulmonary Function Tests:- Bronchodilator test: increase in absolute FEV1 of 250 mL, improvement rate of 24%- Follow-up tests showed FEV1: 2.2L, FVC: 3.77L, FEV1%pred: 56.9%, FEV1/FVC%: 69.8%, PEF: 5.88L/s
final_diagnosis: Near-fatal asthma with type II respiratory failure and respiratory acidosis
option_b: Near-fatal asthma with type II respiratory failure and respiratory acidosis
reason: The case presents with recurrent respiratory symptoms, acute dyspnea, and significant pulmonary function abnormalities, indicating a need for specialized respiratory care.

case_information: An 85-year-old man was admitted due to skin ulceration in the left upper limb, lethargy and fever for 1 day. One day prior, he was stabbed in the left upper limb while cleaning sea shrimps and then developed drowsiness and fever, with a maximum body temperature of 38.8°C. The patient had a history of diabetes for more than 20 years and a long-term history of alcoholism.
physical_examination: Patient was lethargic, with low spirit. Left hand and forearm showed:- Large areas of fluid exudation- Local tension blisters- Dark purple ecchymoses at the base- Slightly cool ends of the five fingers- Extensive swelling from proximal middle segment to wrist- Scattered petechiae and ecchymosis on skin of whole body
diagnostic_tests: Laboratory Tests:- White blood cell count: 11.77 × 109/L- Procalcitonin: > 100 ng/mL- Lactate: 4.28 mmol/LMicrobiology:- Blood culture: Positive for Gram-negative bacilli- NGS analysis of blood sample performed- Microscopic examination showed comma-like, flagellate, spore-free bacteria- Culture on blood agar showed round, slightly convex, moist, gray, opaque and grass-green β-hemolytic coloniesImages:Figure 1A: Shows left upper limb swelling with tension blisters and dark purple ecchymosesFigure 1D: Direct microscopic examination of bacteria in blood cultureFigure 1E: Colony growth in blood agar plateFigure 1F: NGS technology detection results
final_diagnosis: Vibrio vulnificus sepsis
option_d: Septic shock secondary to bacterial infection
reason: The patient presents with skin ulceration, fever, and signs of systemic infection likely due to a stab wound, along with positive blood cultures for Gram-negative bacilli, indicating a possible infectious process.

case_information: Male patient, born in 2013, with frequent respiratory episodes during first year of life. Initial sweat tests were uncertain (42-60 mmol/l). At 8-10 months, developed Pseudo-Bartter's syndrome (hypochloremia, hyponatremia, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis). Genetic testing at 12 months revealed F508del/3849 + 10kbC-T mutation. From December 2015 (age 2) to 2018, regular oropharyngeal samples showed bacterial presence in amounts of 102-104 colony-forming units.
physical_examination: Physical examination showed no significant aggravation from 2015 to 2022. Blood chemistry had no significant deviations, and vitamin D level was within normal range.
diagnostic_tests: - Laboratory Tests:    - Regular sputum microbiological examinations from 2014 to 2022    - Regular PCR tests of sputum samples (at least 4 per year from 2016)    - Blood chemistry tests showing no significant deviations      - Imaging Studies:    - Computer tomography confirmed inflammatory alteration of the paranasal sinuses    - Lung computer tomography showed no signs of damage      - Microbiological Tests:    - February 2019: Sputum sample negative, nasal lavage fluid showed 32 colony-forming units/ml    - MALDI TOF mass spectrometry and whole genome sequencing confirmed taxonomic affiliation    - Protein profile analysis showed homogeneity of isolates from 2015-2020
final_diagnosis: Burkholderia cenocepacia-associated paranasal sinusitis
reason: The patient has a history of frequent respiratory episodes, bacterial presence in oropharyngeal samples, and imaging studies indicating inflammatory alterations in the paranasal sinuses, which are all related to pulmonary health.

case_information: A male in his forties presented with abdominal distension, constipation, unexplained fever and weight loss for three months. He had a history of surgery for right inguinal region swelling (possibly right undescended testis) three months prior, though no surgical records were available. No comorbidities were noted. On scrotal examination, right testicle was missing.
physical_examination: Physical findings included:- 6 × 5 cm intra-abdominal mass in the right iliac fossa- Multiple large bulky bilateral inguinal lymph nodes- Hepato-splenomegaly- Absent right testicle
diagnostic_tests: Laboratory Tests:- Complete blood count and hemogram: within normal limits- Biochemical parameters:  * Urea: 112 mg/dL  * Serum creatinine: 5.2 mg/dL  * Uric acid: 12.4 mg%  * 24-h urine protein: 74 mg/dL  * Serum albumin: 3.10 g/dl (slightly decreased)  * Beta-HCG: 38286 mIU/L (reference: 200-800 mIU/L)  * LDH: 5345 U/L (reference: 140-280 U/L)  * AFP: 21.88 ng/ml (reference: 0-40 ng/mL)Imaging Studies:- Ultrasonography: Multiple enlarged lymph nodes in left iliac fossa and right inguinal region. Left iliac fossa lymph node measured 10.9 × 5.4 cm, compressing left ureter causing hydronephrosis- CT and MRI: Confirmed lymph node findings and revealed multiple hypointense lesions in liverBone Marrow Studies:- Bone marrow aspirate: Showed focal clusters of metastatic tumor cells- Bone marrow biopsy: Negative for metastasisPathology:- Lymph node biopsy: Sheets of large polygonal tumor cells with abundant vacuolated cytoplasm and large pleomorphic nucleus- Immunohistochemistry: Positive for SALL-4 and CD117; Negative for LCA (CD45) and CD30
final_diagnosis: Nonseminomatous germ cell tumor metastatic to the lymph nodes, liver and bone marrow (stage T4 N3 M1b)
option_a: Nonseminomatous germ cell tumor metastatic to the lymph nodes, liver and bone marrow (stage T4 N3 M1b)
option_b: Non-seminomatous Germ Cell Tumor (e.g., Embryonal Carcinoma)
reason: The case presents with signs of a malignancy, including an intra-abdominal mass, enlarged lymph nodes, and elevated tumor markers (Beta-HCG and LDH), indicating a likely testicular cancer with metastasis.

case_information: A 69-year-old male was admitted to the hospital, asymptomatic. His medical history included a Bentall procedure and coronary artery bypass grafting nine years prior. The patient had previously experienced chest pain nine years ago.
physical_examination: Physical examination revealed no abnormalities. Electrocardiogram demonstrated sinus rhythm and a first-degree atrioventricular block. Echocardiography showed mild tricuspid valve regurgitation, decreased left ventricular diastolic function (with a global ejection fraction of 69%), normal blood flow in artificial blood vessels, and normal aortic valve function.
diagnostic_tests: - Laboratory Tests:    * Hemoglobin: 147 g/L    * Albumin: 48.2 g/L    * Alanine transaminase: 10 u/L    * Serum troponin I: 0.022 ng/mL  - Imaging Studies:    * Computed Tomography Angiography (CTA):      Title: Transverse view and 3D reconstruction of ascending aorta      Description: Revealed a pseudoaneurysm at the distal anastomosis of the graft in the ascending aorta. The diameter of the pseudoaneurysm was around 20 mm, with a residual false lumen in the brachiocephalic artery. The coronary artery graft vessel was smooth without obvious stenosis.
final_diagnosis: Ascending aortic anastomosis pseudoaneurysm at the distal anastomosis of the Bentall graft
option_a: Ascending aortic anastomosis pseudoaneurysm at the distal anastomosis of the Bentall graft
reason: The case involves a patient with a history of cardiac surgery and current findings related to the heart, including a pseudoaneurysm in the ascending aorta and heart function assessments.

case_information: A 52-year-old male patient was hospitalized due to repeated cough for 2 months. The patient denied a history of autoimmune diseases, diabetes, hypertension, coronary disease, arrhythmia, chronic heart failure or smoking. One week after his 5th cycle of chemotherapy and immunotherapy, the patient experienced shortness of breath, loss of appetite and weight loss. The patient denied use of illegal drugs or herbs, and had no fever or cough.
physical_examination: Temperature: 36.5°C; Respiratory rate: 20/min; Blood pressure: 156/98 mmHg; SpO2: 98%. Breathing sounded normal in both lungs, without moist or dry rales. Heart rate was 115 bpm with normal rhythm. No extra cardiac sounds or pathological murmurs were heard, and no pericardial friction. No edema in either lower limb.
diagnostic_tests: - Laboratory Tests:    * CK: 4977 U/L (Reference range 41-186 U/L)    * CK-MB: 526 U/L (Reference range 0-24 U/L)    * Cardiac troponin T (cTnT): 2230 ng/L (Reference range 0-14 ng/L)    * NT-ProBNP: Slightly elevated    * D-dimer: 0.14mg/L (Reference range 0-0.50mg/L)- Imaging Studies:    * Dynamic ECG: Normal sinus rhythm without ST-segment changes    * Coronary Artery CTA: No obvious abnormality    * Chest CT: No pulmonary infection or congestion    * Cardiac Color Ultrasound: Enlarged aorta, normal left ventricular systolic function, poor diastolic function, small amount of pericardial effusion    * Cardiac MR:       Title: CMR Findings      Description: Mild decline in cardiac function with myocardial edema in signal-enhanced T2-weighted imaging and late gadolinium-enhanced T1-weighted imaging. T2 value of interventricular septum increased to 65.5 ms, T1 value prolonged to 1297.2 ms. ECV was 37%. LVEF of 64%, stroke volume of 52 mL, cardiac output of 4.6 L/min and CI of 2.9 L/min/m2.
final_diagnosis: Sintilimab-induced myocarditis
reason: The patient exhibits symptoms and test results indicative of cardiac issues, including elevated cardiac biomarkers and imaging findings suggestive of myocardial edema and impaired cardiac function.

case_information: A 60-year-old female presented with initial symptoms 7 months ago including: dizziness, slight slant of mouth corners towards left, right-sided hearing drop, and diplopia. Symptoms worsened after 12 days with increased weakness of facial muscles. Past medical history includes hypertension for 5 years (treated with nifedipine 40mg/day irregularly) and obesity for 20 years without intervention.
physical_examination: - Disappearance of nasolabial fold in right face- Left-slanted mouth corner- Incomplete right eyelid closure with visible sclera during maximal effort- No impairment of facial pain and temperature sensation- Weak muscle strength of right frontalis and orbicularis oculi- Unable to lift right eyebrow- No facial spasm or synkinesis- House-Brackmann grade V severity
diagnostic_tests: 1. Brain MRI:- Lesion located in dorsolateral right pons- Hypo-intense signal in T1-weighted images- Moderate-intense signal in T2-weighted images- No hyper-intense signals in diffusion-weighted images2. MRTA (Magnetic resonance tomographic angiography):- No vertebrobasilar artery main trunk occlusion or stenosis3. Electrophysiological Tests:- ENoG: Significantly decreased amplitude of right facial nerve compound muscular action potential compared to healthy side- EMG: Presence of insertional activity in right facial muscles with greatly reduced voluntary activity
final_diagnosis: Right peripheral-type facial palsy due to dorsolateral pontine infarction
option_d: Right peripheral-type facial palsy due to dorsolateral pontine infarction
reason: The symptoms and test results indicate a neurological issue, specifically involving the facial nerve and brainstem, consistent with a neurological disorder.

case_information: A 39-year-old woman presented with sudden onset of diffuse abdominal pain for 24 hours. Medical history included a cesarean section in 2013, with no trauma history or recent abdominal/urethral surgery. The patient reported very little daytime urination. Follow-up history revealed consumption of 500 mL of 53-degree liquor the day before symptom onset.
physical_examination: Vital signs: BP 129/86 mmHg, HR 70/min, RR 20/min, temperature 36.4°C. Physical exam showed bulging abdomen with slight muscle tension, pressure and rebound pain throughout abdomen, positive mobile turbid sounds, and no bowel sounds.
diagnostic_tests: - Laboratory tests:     - Elevated white blood cell count (10.40 × 109/L)    - Elevated serum creatinine (144 μmol/L)     - Elevated urea (378 μmol/L)      - Imaging studies:    Title: CT of the abdomen    Description: Showed extensive free fluid in the abdominal cavity      - Other tests:    - Abdominal puncture revealed bloody fluid    - Intraoperative findings showed clear peritoneal fluid and rupture in posterior bladder wall
final_diagnosis: Spontaneous rupture of the bladder (SRUB) with peritonitis
option_b: Acute peritonitis secondary to bladder rupture
option_c: Spontaneous rupture of the bladder (SRUB) with peritonitis

case_information: A 53-year-old female with a medical history significant for being on maintenance therapy with Rituximab every 8 weeks until January 2022. The patient had received two doses of viral vector vaccine (AstraZeneca), with the second dose administered in June 2021.
physical_examination: Initial presentation (March 10th, 2022):- Temperature: 38.2°C- Blood pressure: 122/78 mm Hg- Heart rate: 86 bpm- Oxygen saturation: 96% on room air- Lungs: Clear fields on auscultation- Heart: No abnormal cardiac murmurs

case_information: A 45-year-old woman presented with throat discomfort for more than 1 hour. She experienced a sore throat and hoarse voice, but no cough, expectoration, chest tightness, shortness of breath, chills, or fever. Height 160 cm, weight 60 kg. No history of alcoholism, hypertension, diabetes, cardiovascular, cerebrovascular, central nervous system or other chronic diseases. Upon questioning, symptoms occurred while eating bream 11 hours prior.
physical_examination: Initial laryngoscopy showed no obvious abnormalities.
diagnostic_tests: - Imaging Studies:    1. Plain Film:       Title: Initial X-ray       Description: Film indicated a foreign body spanning across the throat with the tip approaching the carotid artery        2. Throat CT:       Title: Initial Throat CT       Description: Showed a transverse high-density shadow in the horizontal esophagus at the level of the sixth cervical vertebra with a length of about 3.3 cm. The tip was approximately 0.29 cm from the left common carotid artery        3. Carotid CTA:       Title: Follow-up Carotid CTA       Description: Revealed the left end of the foreign body was about 0.45 cm away from the left common carotid artery, showing slight movement from initial position
final_diagnosis: Pharyngeal fish bone foreign body with penetration
option_a: Esophageal foreign body (fish bone) with risk of carotid artery injury
option_b: Pharyngeal fish bone foreign body with penetration
option_c: Retropharyngeal abscess secondary to foreign body

case_information: A 12-year-old castrated Chihuahua presented for periodic health examination. The dog had been diagnosed with tricuspid regurgitation a year prior, which was left untreated for financial reasons. The owner noted that the dog's stool contained parasites, likely nematodes or tapeworms.
physical_examination: Initial examination showed:- Body weight: 4.1 kg- Rectal temperature: 38.3°C - Heart rate: 120 beats/min- Respiratory rate: 30 breaths/min- Heart murmur heard in right heart regionOn follow-up after medication:- Tenderness noted in upper abdomen- Low rectal temperature (36.6°C)- Heart rate 120 beats/min
diagnostic_tests: Initial tests:- Laboratory findings:  * Elevated platelet count (723,000/μL)  * Increased ALT (221 U/L), ALP (159 U/L), γ-GTP (66 U/L)  * Elevated BUN (34.2 mg/dL)  * High total cholesterol (493 mg/dL) and triglycerides (494 mg/dL)  * Elevated phosphorus (5.7 mg/dL) and cystatin C (0.48 mg/dL)  * Spec cPL slightly elevated at 460 μg/dL  * High total bile acid (38.4 μmol/L)  * Negative heartworm antigen testFollow-up tests:- Imaging:  * Thoracic radiography: Enlarged cardiac silhouette  * Abdominal radiography: Hepatomegaly and increased radiopacity in upper right abdomen  * Abdominal ultrasound: Liver enlargement, gallbladder mucocele-like findings, renal cysts, enlarged adrenal glands, reduced duodenal peristalsis, hyperechoic pancreatic surrounding fat- Laboratory findings:  * Elevated ALT (3094 U/L), AST (668 U/L), ALP (311 U/L), γ-GTP (52 U/L)  * High BUN (84.6 mg/dL) and creatinine (1.87 mg/dL)  * Elevated CRP (14.1 mg/dL)  * Low Na (139 mEq/L) and Cl (91 mEq/L)  * High Spec cPL (1202 μg/dL)  * Low urine specific gravity (1.012)

case_information: An 80-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presented to the emergency department with progressive shortness of breath for one day duration, accompanied by chest tightness and non-radiating retrosternal chest pain. The patient denied previous episodes of chest pain, and no other relevant associated symptoms were previously noticed.
physical_examination: Initial vital signs showed blood pressure of 191/99 mmHg, heart rate of 114 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 68% under ambient air. The patient was slightly drowsy but conversant and oriented. Breathing sounds were bilaterally coarse upon auscultation. Normal heart sounds without obvious murmurs or pericardial rubs were recorded. The remainder of the systemic physical examination results were unremarkable.
diagnostic_tests: - Laboratory Tests: Serial Troponin-T measurements showed progressive elevation, reaching 1101 ng/L on day 4.- Imaging Studies:  1. Chest Radiography     Title: Initial chest X-ray     Description: Bilateral fine reticular opacities, widened mediastinum, cardiomegaly, and bilateral blunted costophrenic angles    2. Electrocardiogram (EKG)     Description: Sinus tachycardia with mildly elevated ST-segments at the inferior leads    3. Echocardiography     Description: Normal left atrial and ventricular sizes, good left ventricular contractility, no pericardial effusion or regional wall motion abnormalities    4. CT Angiography     Description: Right anterior mediastinal mass, well demarcated with minimal contact with surrounding great vessels and no adjoining abnormal lymph nodes    5. Coronary Angiography     Description: Diffusely slow coronary flow with patency in all three coronary arteries    6. Biopsy Results     Description: Epithelial malignancy of thymic origin, showing ovoid-to spindle neoplastic cells with nuclear atypia and mitosis
final_diagnosis: Type A thymoma with MINOCA (Myocardial Infarction with Non-Obstructive Coronary Arteries)
option_a: Thymic carcinoma with paraneoplastic syndrome (likely Myasthenia Gravis)
option_b: Type A thymoma with MINOCA (Myocardial Infarction with Non-Obstructive Coronary Arteries)
reason: The case involves a diagnosis of an epithelial malignancy of thymic origin, indicating a need for oncological evaluation and management.

case_information: A 77-year-old man presented with coma, one-week history of anorexia, and leg edema. Medical history included severe cervical-thoracic kyphosis. Initial symptoms included systemic edema and respiratory issues. The patient had been experiencing progressive hemodynamic instability.

case_information: A 43-year-old female presented with low back and left thigh pain for 10 years. She was previously diagnosed with lumbar disc herniation and denied any family history of inherited diseases. Over the past 10 years, she had been treated with symptomatic therapy including oral Celecoxib, acupuncture, and infrared irradiation therapy. Although her symptoms were relieved after treatment, she still experienced periodic throbbing pain and weakness in her left leg.

case_information: A 56-year-old male patient developed left low back pain in November 2019, which radiated to the lower abdomen and perineum. In January 2020, the pain gradually worsened, accompanied by numbness and weakness of both lower extremities, particularly on the left side.

case_information: A 43-year-old woman presented with symptoms in the right foot after removal of osteosynthesis material due to complex ankle trauma. The patient also had depressive symptoms and fear of weight gain. Current medications included l-thyroxine, SNRI, betablocker, vitamin supplements, fentanyl, and paracetamol. No smoking, alcohol, or illicit drug use. No known allergies.

case_information: A 79-year-old female patient presented with severe chest pain lasting for 4 hours. Medical history included hypertension (moderately managed), paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (treated with Betaloc for 6 months), and moderate pulmonary hypertension (pulmonary artery systolic pressure ~55 mmHg). The patient had no history of diabetes or hyperlipidemia.
physical_examination: Initial vital signs during procedure showed low blood pressure of 60/40 mmHg, which improved to 90/50 mmHg with heart rate of 96 beats/min after intervention. About 30 minutes post-procedure, patient experienced severe chest pain radiating to the back, with dyspnea and sweating. Vital signs showed blood pressure 100-111/54-70 mmHg, SpO2 84%, and heart rate 110-142 beats/min.
diagnostic_tests:
- Laboratory Tests:
  • cTnT: 0.309 ng/ml
  • CK-MB: 55 U/L
  • D-Dimer: within normal range

- ECG Findings:
  • Initial ECG showed ST-segment elevation in inferior-posterior leads
  • Post-procedure ECG showed mild ST elevation in leads II, III and AVF; mild ST depression in leads V2 and V4

- Imaging Studies:
  1. Coronary Angiography:
     Title: Emergency Coronary Angiography
     Description: Revealed occlusive thrombosis of the tiny distal left circumflex artery (LCx), with no notable lesions in remaining coronary vessels

  2. Computed Tomography Angiography (CTA):
     Title: Thoracic and Abdominal Aorta CTA
     Description: Revealed pericardial effusion and contrast leakage from myocardium to pericardial cavity

  3. Bedside Echocardiography:
     Description: Showed fluid accumulation within pericardial cavity (10mm anterior to right ventricular anterior wall, 11mm posterior to left ventricular posterior wall, 15mm lateral to left ventricular lateral wall, and 15mm at apex)
final_diagnosis: Left ventricular free wall rupture following acute myocardial infarction
option_d: Left ventricular free wall rupture following acute myocardial infarction
reason: The case involves severe chest pain, ST-segment elevation, and findings of occlusive thrombosis in the coronary artery, indicating a cardiac event, which falls under the cardiology department.

case_information: A 13-year-old female presented with vision loss and scotomas in the right eye. Five days prior, her classmate had directed an online-bought handheld high-intensity LED light (30 chip-on-board LEDs emitting 5 W, 100 lm/W at 500 mA) at her right eye multiple times at very short distance with flash mode. She sought immediate medical attention at a local hospital for blurred vision and scotomas but was referred elsewhere.
physical_examination: On initial presentation 5 days after exposure:- Best corrected visual acuity (BCVA): 6/20 right eye, 20/20 left eye- Anterior segment examination: unremarkable - Fundus examination: unremarkable
diagnostic_tests: - Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT) at 3 days post-exposure:  Image Title: Initial OCT image  Image Description: Hyperreflective area at external retinal layers, disruption of ellipsoid zone, outer segment photoreceptor and interdigitation zone. Mild eminence of retinal pigment epithelium at fovea.- Fluorescein Angiography (FA) at 5 days post-exposure:  Image Title: FA image  Image Description: No leakage observed- Serial SD-OCT findings:  At 5 days: Mosaic-like hyporeflective outer retinal space with flat RPE  At 19 days: Partial restoration of ellipsoid zone, hyporeflective defect at interdigitation zone  At 33 days: Further restoration of ellipsoid zone and partial restoration of interdigitation zone  At 3 months: Normal external retinal layers- Multifocal Electroretinography (mfERG):  At 19 days: Decreased foveal peak P1 amplitudes in right eye  At 33 days: Improved foveal peak P1 amplitudes in right eye
final_diagnosis: Photic maculopathy derived from LED light exposure
option_b: Photic maculopathy derived from LED light exposure
reason: The case involves vision loss and retinal damage, which are specific to eye health, making Ophthalmology the appropriate department.

case_information: A 53-year-old man with chronic hepatitis B virus infection (>30 years) presented with weakness, bloating, anorexia, and decreased urine output for 10 days.
