case_information: 69-year-old female with 16-year history of type II diabetes mellitus. In January 2022, patient began experiencing weakness, depression and drowsiness. On May 12, 2022, patient was admitted to EICU due to weakness, depression for more than 4 months, faint consciousness and drowsiness for 1 day.

case_information: A 40-year-old woman, G4P1, presented with pain in the right lower abdomen persisting for eight years, with recent aggravation and abdominal expansion sensation in the past month. Surgical history includes: cesarean section (2009), laparoscopic myomectomy (2012), surgeries for fibroids and ovarian cysts (2015, 2018), hysteroscopic IUD placement (2018), endometriomas puncture (2019), and total abdominal hysterectomy with right adnexectomy and left salpingectomy (2020). The pain gradually increased requiring oral painkillers. Patient has a two-year smoking history (7 cigarettes/day) but quit 5 years ago.
physical_examination: Patient appeared in visible pain with forced posture. Abdomen was soft and tender in lower part, without rebound tenderness. Pelvic examination revealed: no hymen/vaginal obstruction, smooth sutured end. A 10 cm mass was palpable in pelvic cavity, fixed to anterior rectum, with clear boundary, hard texture, significant tenderness and limited mobility. Rectal examination showed smooth mucosa with a hard, mobile, non-tender mass 7 cm from anus.
diagnostic_tests: - Laboratory Tests:  - CA125: 35.08 U/ml  - Hormone levels (post-surgery): LH 44.87 IU/L, FSH 108.8 IU/L, Prolactin 6.62 μg/L, Progesterone 0.16 ng/mL, Estradiol <15 pg/ml, Testosterone 12.08 ng/dL- Imaging Studies:  - MRI and CT findings: Irregular mass in pelvic area with multiple nodules  - Image Description: MRI showed multiple soft tissue shadows with uneven signals, blurred margin with adjacent rectum and sigmoid colon  - CT Description: Irregular lobular mass shadows behind bladder with uneven intensity and cystic regions, inhomogeneous enhancement with local ring enhancement- Pathological Findings:  - Biopsy results: Smooth muscle tumor  - Immunohistochemistry: Positive for CD34, SMA, desmin, focal CD10, ER, PR, and 2% Ki-67; Negative for CD117, S-100, and Dog-1
final_diagnosis: Leiomyomatosis peritonealis disseminata (LPD) with endometriosis

After three months, the child was admitted due to increased fever frequency and decreased fever relief time to 8-12 hours. Past medical history includes pneumonia, duodenal bulb ulcer, erosive gastritis, and surgical treatment three years ago for Staphylococcus aureus septicemia and infective endocarditis.

Abdominal MRI:- Title: Abdominal MRI of liver lesion- Description: Mass shadow with mixed signal in SIV segment of liver, measuring 55mm × 42mm × 64mm. case_information: A 39-year-old female teacher from Southwest China presented with a subcutaneous mass in the lower-left abdominal region. case_information: A 39-year-old healthy man, police officer, sustained a gunshot wound resulting in a multifragmental fracture of the femur neck and a 12 cm defect of the sciatic nerve. Within 30 months post-transplantation, there was gradual recovery of posterior thigh muscle function. Two months after a viral infection, the patient reported progressive weakness of the proximal muscles of the right lower limb.

case_information: A 4-year-old female was initially referred to the Genetics department at 20 days of age. case_information: A 66-year-old female patient with a history of Hashimoto's thyroiditis and thrombocytopenia. The patient had consistently shown leukocytopenia and thrombocytopenia in routine blood tests over the years. Initial blood test revealed a leukocyte count of 3.16 × 10^9/L and a platelet count of 109.00 × 10^9/L. No other symptoms were present, and no significant abnormalities were detected in cardiac enzymes or blood coagulation. Four hours post-procedure, the patient experienced intermittent abdominal pain and occasional nausea. Nine hours following the operation, the patient experienced recurrent right abdomen pain progressing to involve the entire abdomen, with persistent nausea and perceived increase in body temperature.

Later examination revealed diffuse tenderness with rebound tenderness, primarily in the right abdomen. Dullness to percussion was observed, while pain during percussion in the liver area was absent. Shifting dullness to percussion was negative, and normal bowel sounds were detected. Maximum body temperature was 37.8°C.

  - WBC count: 3.43 × 10^9/L
  - Neutrophil percentage: 85.40%
  - Lymphocyte percentage: 9.40%
  - Absolute lymphocytes: 0.32 × 10^9/L
  - Platelet count: 79.00 × 10^9/L
  - CRP level: 2.45 mg/L
  - Procalcitonin level: 0.58 ng/ml

- Imaging Studies:
  CT Scan Results: Edematous thickening of the intestinal wall in the ascending colon with peripheral exudative changes. No signs of intestinal perforation or obstruction.
  Follow-up CT: Distension of anterior wall of ascending colon with gas, exudation in subserosa of middle section, and small quantity of ascites.

- Bacterial Culture:
  Ascites culture yielded growth of Escherichia coli.

- Histological Examination:
  Showed edema in all layers of intestinal wall, predominant thickening and edema in submucosa, diffuse infiltration of neutrophils with presence of abscesses. Bacterial colonies observed in submucosa surrounding the ESD lesion.

case_information: A 52-year-old woman with a history of Sjogren's syndrome initially presented to a regional hospital complaining of sudden chest tightness. On day 3, the patient developed severe respiratory distress and experienced cardiac arrest characterized by severe ventricular arrhythmias refractory to conventional cardiopulmonary resuscitation efforts. Following tracheal intubation, she underwent peripheral venous-arterial extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (V-A ECMO) as a rescue therapy, accompanied by intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP) implantation. On day 4, due to worsening cardiovascular status and persistent electrical instability despite V-A ECMO and IABP, the patient was transferred to another hospital by helicopter.
physical_examination: Upon arrival at the hospital, the patient's blood pressure was 83/64 mmHg while receiving mechanical circulatory support with ECMO (operating at a flow rate of 3.5 L/min) and IABP. Bedside transthoracic echocardiography showed that the global wall motion was severely depressed, with an estimated left ventricular ejection fraction(LVEF) of approximately 10%.
diagnostic_tests:
- Laboratory Tests:
  - Platelet count: 14 × 10^9/L
  - Troponin T: 14210 ng/L (ref: 0-14 ng/L)
  - NT-proBNP: 8296 pg/mL (ref: 0-125 pg/mL)
  - ALT: 116 IU/L (ref: 0-33 IU/L)
  - Creatinine: 134 μmol/L (ref: 45-84 umol/L)
  - Arterial blood gases: pH 7.25, lactate 4.87 mmol/L (ref: 0.5-2.2 mmol/L)

- Imaging Studies:
  - ECG: Revealed ventricular tachycardia
  - Chest X-ray: Showed pulmonary edema
  - Cardiac catheterization: Revealed normal coronary arteries

- Pathological Examination:
  - Histological analysis of left ventricular apex specimen showed myocardial necrosis, interstitial edema, and fibrosis, accompanied by infiltration of diffuse monocytes and scattered multinucleated giant cells
final_diagnosis: Fulminant giant cell myocarditis
reason: The case involves severe cardiovascular issues, including cardiac arrest, ventricular arrhythmias, and myocardial necrosis, which are primarily managed by the Cardiology department.

case_information: A 4-year-old boy was referred due to global developmental delay. He showed behavioral issues including aggression, tooth grinding, hand flapping, and hyperactivity. Frequent repetitive hand movements such as clapping or jumping were observed. He avoided eye contact with parents and caretakers and sometimes exhibited self-harming behaviors, including tapping his head. Social communication remained severely limited, requiring assistance with daily activities.

case_information: An 86-year-old Caucasian female arrived at the Emergency Department following intentional ingestion of medication at 1:00 p.m., arriving at 5:30 p.m. Medical history included episodes of superficial venous thrombosis three years prior, non-critical carotid atherosclerosis, hypertension, and frequent falls with previous vertebral fractures. The patient had experienced a fall approximately thirty minutes before hospital arrival.
physical_examination: Patient was conscious with vital signs: afebrile, blood pressure 130/65 mmHg, heart rate 61 bpm, respiratory rate 16/min, and SpO2 of 96% in room air. Physical examination showed contusive trauma to the right shoulder and right hip, extensive hematoma in the bilateral lumbar region, right thigh and leg. No reported pain, no motor disturbances, and no immediate signs of external bleeding were noted.

final_diagnosis: Combined dabigatran and apixaban-induced coagulopathy with traumatic hematoma

case_information: A 75-year-old White man with a history of smoking presented with gradual onset of speech difficulty, shortness of breath, difficulty swallowing, and noisy breathing. Medical history includes hypertension for three years, diabetes mellitus for one year, ischemic heart disease for 20 years (with previous coronary artery bypass graft surgery), and heart failure with an ejection fraction of 40%. Current medications include aspirin 100 mg, bisoprolol 5 mg, dapagliflozin 10 mg, atorvastatin 40 mg, Entresto (sacubitril/valsartan) 100 mg, and tamsulosin 0.4 mg. The patient had been on Entresto for over two years. No history of similar conditions, allergies, or atopy.
physical_examination: Patient was conscious with stable vital signs. Examination revealed a swollen uvula with normal tongue shape and movement. Biphasic stridor was heard over the trachea on auscultation. No palpable masses or rashes were noted.
diagnostic_tests: - Imaging Studies:    CT scan of the neck:    Title: Neck CT Findings    Description: Pedunculated soft tissue mass measuring approximately 5 × 2 cm in the oropharynx, attached to the soft palate
final_diagnosis: Quincke's disease (isolated angioedema of the uvula) secondary to Entresto (Valsartan/Sacubitril) use
option_d: Quincke's disease (isolated angioedema of the uvula) secondary to Entresto (Valsartan/Sacubitril) use
reason: The patient presents with symptoms related to the oropharynx, including difficulty swallowing and noisy breathing, along with a CT finding of a mass in the oropharynx, which is within the scope of Otolaryngology.

case_information: A 70-year-old male presented with a five-day history of dysuria and urgency. Medical history included hypertension, persistent atrial fibrillation, and cerebral infarction diagnosed 5 years prior, as well as previous cholecystectomy for gallbladder stones. The patient was on antihypertensive, antiplatelet, and antiarrhythmic drugs. He had no significant allergies, denied smoking or alcohol use, and reported no exposure to cats or aquariums. The patient had maintained good health prior to the illness with no difficulty walking, speaking, or swallowing.
physical_examination: Initial vital signs: temperature 35.8°C, blood pressure 89/55 mmHg, pulse rate 93 beats/min. Height 188.0 cm, weight 75.0 kg. Patient appeared exhausted but non-cachectic. Physical examination revealed no abnormal heart or respiratory sounds, no abdominal tenderness, and no costovertebral angle tenderness. Palpation showed no abnormalities of the neck, axilla, or abdomen. No skin lesions were observed.
diagnostic_tests: Laboratory Findings:- Complete Blood Count: hemoglobin 11.6 g/dL, WBC 39,310/μL (neutrophil 46%, myelocyte 2%, metamyelocyte 9%, band neutrophil 41%, lymphocyte 1%, monocyte 1%), platelets 789,000/μL- Chemistry: C-reactive protein 148.47 mg/L, procalcitonin 12.8 μg/L, BUN 64.3 mg/dL, creatinine 3.75 mg/dL, AST 114 IU/L, ALT 79 IU/L, total bilirubin 2.19 mg/dL- Urinalysis: Showed red and white blood cells, proteinuria, and bacterial infection- HIV Ag/Ab: Negative- Immunological tests: Natural killer cell activity, antinuclear antibodies, and complement components 3 and 4 within normal rangeImaging Studies:- Abdominal CT: Revealed choledocholithiasis and splenomegaly measuring 15.8 cm- Chest CT Image Title: Multiple lymphadenopathy and lung consolidation  Description: Multiple enlarged and conglomerated lymph nodes in paratracheal, right perihilar, and right supraclavicular areas with patchy consolidation in right upper lobe- PET/CT Image Title: Hypermetabolic lymphadenopathy  Description: Enlarged lymph nodes in right supraclavicular and mediastinal regions with hypermetabolic consolidation in right lungPathology:- Lymph node biopsy showed numerous neutrophils- AFB staining revealed positive bacilli- Culture results: Positive for acid-fast bacilli in urine, sputum, and FNA pus specimens
final_diagnosis: Disseminated Mycobacterium kansasii infection
option_a: Lymphoproliferative disorder (e.g., lymphoma) with superimposed mycobacterial infection
option_b: Non-tuberculous mycobacterial infection (e.g., Mycobacterium avium complex)
reason: The patient presents with dysuria, urgency, and significant laboratory findings indicating a bacterial infection, along with positive acid-fast bacilli in multiple specimens, suggesting a possible infectious disease process, likely tuberculosis.

case_information: A 48-year-old Ethiopian woman presented with:- Progressive swelling in lower extremities, abdomen, and rest of body for 4 months- Pain in multiple joints in upper and lower extremities- High-grade fever, loss of appetite, night sweats- Unexplained weight loss- Whitish sputum and coughing for three months- Easy fatiguability and breathing difficulties when lying flat- No prior history of tuberculosis, asthma, cardiac illness, or hypertension- No family history of similar illnesses- No history of smoking, alcohol consumption, or drug use
physical_examination: - Vital signs: Pulse rate 120/min, respiratory rate 28/min, oxygen saturation 96%, blood pressure 130/80 mmHg, temperature 37.8°C- Periorbital puffiness- Pink conjunctiva and non-icteric sclera- Multiple enlarged, firm, non-tender lymph nodes in neck, axillary, and inguinal areas bilaterally- Abdominal fluid accumulation- Grade 2 bilateral pitting edema in legs
diagnostic_tests: Laboratory Tests:- Complete blood count: WBC 6820, neutrophils 4890/mcl, hemoglobin 8.3 g/dl- ESR: 108 mm/hr- TSH: normal- ANA: non-reactive- Renal function: creatinine 2.11, BUN 88- Normal liver function tests and serum electrolytesImaging Studies:- Abdominal ultrasound: Shows ascites and left-sided pleural effusion, organs grossly normal- Chest X-ray: Shows multifocal consolidation  Image Title: Posteroanterior chest x-ray  Image Description: Multifocal consolidation suggestive of multifocal pneumoniaPathology:- Pleural fluid analysis: Abundant lymphocytes, few macrophages against proteinaceous background- FNAC: Markedly increased eosinophils, mixed inflammatory cells including lymphocytes, plasma cells, and histiocytes- Lymph node biopsy: Hyperplastic lymphoid follicles with reactive germinal centers and prominent mantle zone, increased eosinophils mixed with lymphocytes and histiocytes

reason: The patient presents with symptoms suggestive of a systemic infection, including fever, night sweats, weight loss, and respiratory issues, along with significant lymphadenopathy and pleural effusion, which are often associated with infectious processes.

case_information: A 61-year-old woman who underwent bilateral lung transplantation in November 2020. Initially received standard triple immunosuppressive regimen, adjusted six months post-transplantation due to renal insufficiency. At 29 months post-transplant (April 2023), she developed nausea, vomiting and general weakness after catching a cold. The patient exhibited personality change with increased irritability. Her condition rapidly worsened with confusion and inability to speak within a few days.
physical_examination: Neurological examination revealed:- Gaze deviation towards the right side in both eyes- Nuchal rigidity - Muscle strength in extremities at grade 1-2 out of 5 on MRC scale- Increased muscle tone- Bilateral positive Babinski sign
diagnostic_tests: - Laboratory Tests:  * Severe hyponatremia (SNa = 104mmol/L)  * Tacrolimus blood level: 5.5 ng/ml  * Sirolimus blood level: 4.78 ng/ml  * CSF analysis: Normal pressure and composition  * Negative tests for EBV, CMV, JC virus in CSF and blood  * Negative for demyelination antibodies (AQP4, MOG, GFAP, MBP)  * Negative for autoimmune encephalitis antibodies- Imaging Studies:  * Brain MRI: Periventricular white matter lesions slightly more extensive than pre-transplant  Image Title: Brain MRI T2-weighted images  Image Description: Shows progression of small patchy abnormal signals in white matter around bilateral ventricles compared to pre-transplant imaging  * PET-CT: No tumors or lymph node enlargement detected
final_diagnosis: Tacrolimus-induced encephalopathy
reason: The patient's symptoms, including personality changes, confusion, and neurological deficits, along with imaging findings of white matter lesions, suggest a neurological condition that requires evaluation by a neurologist.

case_information: A 42-year-old male presented with thoracalgia for 10-h, dysphoria and unconsciousness for 5-min. He had ventricular fibrillation with no spontaneous breathing and heartbeat, requiring defibrillation and CPR. Past medical history included coronary atherosclerotic heart disease for 2 years. On day 11 post-procedure, he lost consciousness again and was found to have dark brown urine for 2 days prior.
physical_examination: Initial presentation showed no spontaneous breathing and heartbeat. After resuscitation, patient was intubated and placed on ventilator support. Later examination on day 11 showed severe anemia requiring blood transfusion.
diagnostic_tests: - Laboratory tests:    Initial: hs-TnI: 0.031 mg/L (elevated), Pro-BNP: 200.0 pg/mL (elevated), LDH: 283 U/L (elevated)    Day 11: RBC: 0.56 × 10^12/L (low), Hb: 61.0 g/L (low), PLT: 654 × 10^9/L (elevated), WBC: 32.24 × 10^9/L (elevated)    Additional findings: Elevated reticulocyte (328.0 × 10^9/L) and unconjugated bilirubin (27.67 μmol/L)      - Imaging:    ECG: Significant ST-segment depression    Coronary angiography: Proximal LAD occlusion, proximal RCA 90% stenosis, middle RCA occlusion    Blood smear: Showed RBCs of different volumes and abnormal morphologies      - Other tests:    Positive glucose and sucrose hemolysis tests    Blood type: B positive
final_diagnosis: Hemolytic anemia following percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI)

option_c: Hemolytic anemia following percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI)

case_information: A 13-year-old French girl presented with excruciating pain in the left heel. Medical history includes hyperkalemia treated with hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg/day (started at age 11). Pain suddenly appeared at age 12, described as 'stabbing', present day and night (VAS 6/10, with paroxysms 9/10), worsened by pressure, touch, contact with water (allodynia), and walking. By age 18, pain extended to left knee. Patient adapted by walking on tiptoes or using crutches. Multiple pain medications were ineffective. Family history: Mother had chronic hyperkalemia treated with furosemide. Grandfather had chronic hyperkalemia treated with sodium polystyrene sulfonate.
physical_examination: Normal motor strength in all four limbs, normal deep tendon reflexes, no upper motor neuron syndrome. Slight hypopallesthesia of four distal limbs, slight oscillations in Romberg maneuver. Mild distal sensory loss of left foot and leg, not attributable to specific nerve territory. Normal protopathic, thermic, and analgesic sensitivity, including painful area. Mild episodes of hand and foot erythrosis and excessive sweating. Normal left heel appearance.
diagnostic_tests: - Nerve Conduction Studies (NCS):    * Proband: Diffuse reduction of sensory nerve action potential (SNAP) amplitude in four limbs in non-length dependent pattern. Normal compound muscle action potentials (CMAPs) and needle electromyography.    * Mother: Bilateral reduction of SNAP amplitude in lower limbs, reduced SNAP amplitudes in median nerves, normal CMAPs except left extensor digitorum brevis muscle.    * Grandfather: Diffuse reduction of SNAP amplitude in four limbs, decreased CMAPs in left sciatic nerve-innervated muscles.  - Genetic Testing:    * Excluded variants in PMP22 and RFC1 genes    * Exome sequencing performed on three patients and one asymptomatic relative
final_diagnosis: Pseudohypoaldosteronism type II (PHAII) with associated sensory neuronopathy due to KLHL3 gene mutation (c.1582C > T, p.(Arg528Cys))
option_a: Hereditary sensory and autonomic neuropathy (HSAN) type I
option_c: Pseudohypoaldosteronism type II (PHAII) with associated sensory neuronopathy due to KLHL3 gene mutation (c.1582C > T, p.(Arg528Cys))
option_d: Pseudohypoaldosteronism type II (Gordon’s syndrome) with associated neuropathy
reason: The case presents with neurological symptoms such as pain, sensory loss, and abnormal nerve conduction studies, indicating a possible neuropathy, which falls under the domain of neurology.

case_information: A 27-year-old Colombian female factory worker with a 5-year history of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) presented with a 10-day history of recurrent episodes of vomiting containing food particles and bile, accompanied by localized epigastric pain and dysphagia for both solids and liquids. Past medical history included articular involvement (inflammatory polyarthritis), hematological involvement (Coombs-positive anemia), renal involvement (lupus nephritis), and immunological involvement. Seven months after SLE diagnosis, she completed 6 doses of cyclophosphamide with adequate symptom control. Current medications included azathioprine 50 mg BID, chloroquine 250 mg QD, and losartan 50 mg QD.
physical_examination: Vital signs were within normal limits. Weight 58 kg, height 1.62 m. Slightly dry oral mucosa was observed, isocoric pupils reactive to light, 3 mm in diameter, with both direct and consensual photomotor reflexes present. No visual field defects and no ophthalmoparesis.
diagnostic_tests: - Laboratory tests: Elevated serum lipase and amylase levels, borderline complement C3 levels, increased anti-DNA antibodies. Lumbar puncture showed opening pressure of 26 cmH2O, one lymphocyte, glucose 56 mg/dL, protein 26 mg/dL. Negative results for Gram stain, India ink, molecular panel for meningitis, cultures, RT-PCR for tuberculosis, and oligoclonal bands. Anti-aquaporin 4 antibodies were negative (0.32, positive >1).- Imaging studies:  1. Abdominal contrast-enhanced CT scan: No pathological findings  2. Abdominal ultrasound: No pathological findings  3. Endoscopy: No pathological findings  4. Brain MRI: Single hyperintense lesion on T2-weighted sequence in the area postrema with significant gadolinium enhancement  5. Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP): Negative  6. Spine MRI: Right-sided mid-thoracic scoliosis, normal spinal cord morphology and signal intensity
final_diagnosis: Area postrema syndrome associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
option_a: Area postrema syndrome associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
option_d: Neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder (NMOSD) with area postrema syndrome
reason: The patient presents with gastrointestinal symptoms such as vomiting, dysphagia, and localized epigastric pain, which are indicative of potential gastrointestinal involvement, especially considering her history of systemic lupus erythematosus.

case_information: A 42-year-old female was referred to a nephrologist at age 37. She presented with proteinuria (2.61 g/24h) and stage 3b chronic kidney disease. Family history revealed that her father received dialysis at age 50 and was transplanted at age 55, while her paternal grandfather died at age 31 from renal failure. Current medical conditions include blood hypertension, dyslipidemia, and one renal cyst (2 cm).
physical_examination: No specific physical examination findings were reported in the case.

case_information: A 64-year-old female presented with a one-week history of febrile fever, altered mental status, nausea, and non-bloody diarrhea 3-4 times per day. The patient had recently fainted. Medical history included multiple myeloma treated with chemotherapy (last course 10 days prior). No recent travel history, insect bites, or contact with sick people. Patient reported eating raw unwashed fruits but denied consuming processed foods or dairy products.
physical_examination: Patient was lethargic, febrile (37.3°C), and appeared acutely ill. Examination revealed:- Hemorrhagic rash on right leg, hand, and left shoulder- Abscess on right thumb- Nuchal rigidity- Abnormal finger-nose test- Vital signs: pulse 90 beats/min, BP 160/68 mmHg

case_information: A 2-year-old boy, one of three siblings from a non-consanguineous marriage, presented with various episodes of seizures since birth. First onset occurred on the second day of life. Until 4 months, the patient had several episodes of tonic-clonic convulsions of upper and lower extremities in the form of periodic rhythmic twitches and myoclonic spasms. By age 1, seizures exacerbated, manifesting as myoclonus and fading lasting more than 5 minutes, increasing to 30-40 minutes. The child had poor sleep, disturbing awakenings, nightmares, and sudden movements of upper limbs during sleep. At age 2, seizures reappeared with new symptoms including twitching of mimic and chewing muscles. Family history revealed no relatives with similar conditions, with both parents and siblings being phenotypically normal.
physical_examination: The patient exhibited involuntary movements and developmental delay. Motor activity artifacts were noted during examination.
diagnostic_tests: - Imaging Studies:    MRI Title: Brain MRI    MRI Description: Revealed signs of cerebral hemisphere sub-atrophy. Bilateral subdural hygromas present (right side 18mm, left side 5mm). Biconvex lens-shaped liquid formation in left parietal-occipital region (1.2 × 2.6 cm). Small retro cerebellar cyst present.    - Electroencephalography (EEG):    Title: Sleep-wake cycle EEG    Description: Showed disrupted bioelectrical activity with diffuse beta waves, left central epileptiform discharges, and fragmented sleep with reduced spindles and sharp-slow wave complexes. During wakefulness, diffuse beta-wave activity throughout recording. Epileptiform activity in left central leads spreading to parietal and temporal leads. During sleep, diffuse theta/alpha-like waves observed in fronto-central leads with diffuse beta-wave activity.    - Genetic Testing:    Title: Whole Genome Sequencing    Description: Identified heterozygous stop-gain variant c.612G > A (p.Trp204∗) in CHRNA2 gene, located in exon 6.
final_diagnosis: Epileptic encephalopathy with polymorphic seizures, resistant form
option_d: Epileptic encephalopathy with polymorphic seizures, resistant form
reason: The case involves a 2-year-old boy with a history of seizures, developmental delay, and specific EEG findings, indicating a neurological disorder.

case_information: A 43-year-old gentleman presented with a 3-year history of progressive dyspnoea on exertion. His background included a splenectomy and portosystemic shunt formation as a child due to complications related to hypersplenism. His medical history also included mild kyphoscoliosis. He was a lifelong nonsmoker and denied alcohol consumption or illicit drug use. He reported New York Heart Association functional class II dyspnoea and denied other cardiorespiratory symptoms including chest pain, orthopnoea, limb oedema, or syncope.

case_information: A 27-year-old female smoker was referred to our Rapid Access Lung Clinic following an abnormal CT scan. The scan was performed after she experienced acute desaturation to 85% with sudden onset dyspnoea on the antenatal ward, following an emergency laparoscopic caesarean section. These symptoms were transient in nature. The patient had no respiratory or systemic symptoms one week after the event. Family history was significant for lung carcinoma, and she had a penicillin allergy. Past medical history included a road traffic accident 10 years prior, complicated by left hemi-diaphragmatic rupture and splenic injury, requiring diaphragmatic repair and splenectomy via laparotomy. No known exposure to asbestos or tuberculosis.
physical_examination: Cardiorespiratory examination was unremarkable.

CT/CTPA Findings:     Image Title: CT axial and coronal views     Image Description: Shows a large pleural-based mass in the left upper lobe and an ipsilateral hilar-based mass extending down to the diaphragm. No evidence of pulmonary embolism or intrapulmonary lesions.  2. Nuclear Imaging:     Image Title: Technetium-99m heat-damaged erythrocyte nuclear study     Image Description: Confirmed pleural-based masses were of splenic origin  3. Biopsy Results:     Description: Histology revealed lymphoid tissue with large follicles, central reactive germinal centres, and surrounding marginal zones. The lesion was consistent with splenic tissue.
final_diagnosis: Thoracic splenosis

case_information: A 66-year-old male, never-smoker, labourer presented with right-sided chest pain and dyspnoea for 1 month. The pain was dull aching, gradually progressive, increasing with respiration, and relieved with analgesics. The dyspnoea was exertional and gradual in onset, progressively increasing from mMRC grade 1 to 3. No fever, cough, expectoration, or wheeze. Past history included right-sided pleural effusion 3 years ago treated for 6 months. History of blunt chest trauma 5 years ago from buffalo impact. No comorbidities, recent instrumentation or surgery.

case_information: A 51-year-old man presented with a 6-year history of chronic cough. The cough was productive (egg cup full of sputum daily), present day and night, and associated with numerous triggers. He denied haemoptysis or breathlessness, and his weight was stable. The cough was rated 9/10 in severity and occurred largely in bouts, often associated with retching and dizziness. It had worsened in severity in the 2 years prior. Past medical history included a 15-year history of ulcerative colitis, initially managed medically, with a subsequent total colectomy (2017) and re-anastomosis (2018). He was an ex-smoker, having quit in 1999, with a 5 pack-years smoking history. He worked in construction, with occasional exposure to spray paints.
physical_examination: Body mass index was 25 kg·m−2, no clubbing present, and chest examination was unremarkable.

final_diagnosis: IBD-associated airways disease and inflammatory bronchiectasis
option_c: IBD-associated airways disease and inflammatory bronchiectasis

case_information: A 61-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease presented with a 10-day history of dyspnoea during mild physical activity. His medical history included ulcerative colitis diagnosed three years ago, with treatment including anti-TNF-α (infliximab) and mesalazine for the past six months. One month after the last dose of anti-TNF-α and six months after initiating therapy, he was hospitalized due to fever and severe respiratory failure.

case_information: A 33-year-old man with inflammatory ileocolonic Crohn's disease with perianal involvement presented with arthralgias, petechiae, and purpura. Three months prior, after attending an outdoor wedding, he noticed small, painless, nonpruritic petechiae over his bilateral legs. He had not taken any new medications and was otherwise in his usual state of health. Over the next two weeks, the petechiae progressed to palpable purpura extending to his bilateral thighs. He also developed malaise and severe arthralgia of his bilateral hips, knees, and Achilles tendons. At urgent care, he was diagnosed with a chigger rash and tendonitis and was prescribed a low-dose methylprednisolone pack with minimal alleviation of symptoms.
